Description: Alanine racemase, biosynthetic, PLP-binding
Comments: Alr has a covalently PLP-modified K34 residue N6-(pyridoxal phosphate)lysine.

Protein: molybdate ABC transporter permease; chlorate resistance protein
Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Anions
Description: Molybdate ABC transporter permease; chlorate resistance
Comments: Null

Function: Putative transport; Transport of small molecules: Anions
Description: Sulfate transporter, sulfite inhibited
Comments: CysZ is a sulfite-inhibited pH-dependent sulfate transporter that is specialized for sulfate import for cysteine synthesis (Zhang, 2014). cysZ mutants are defective in sulfate assimilation, thought to be due to a defect in sulfate transport (Britton, 1983; Parra, 1983; Aguilar-Barajas, 2011). The etoposide-induced protein 2.4 family (EI24, PF0726), formerly known as DUF540, is named after the eukaryotic EI24 protein induced by the cytotoxic drug etoposide; ei24 is a p53 response gene involved in growth suppression and apoptosis (Gu, 2000). CysZ is an inner membrane protein with the C-terminus in the cytoplasm (Daley, 2005). otherPDB (I. loihiensis): 3TX3.

Description: Coenzyme A biosynthesis, bifunctional enzyme; phosphopantothenoylcysteine decarboxylase (N) and phosphopantothenoylcysteine synthase (C)
Comments: Dfp was originally identified as a flavoprotein affecting DNA synthesis and pantothenate metabolism. The N-terminal domain of Dfp catalyzes the decarboxylation of (R)-4'-phospho-N-pantothenoylcysteine to 4'-phosphopantetheine.

Protein: fused fructose-specific PTS enzymes: IIA component/HPr component
Function: Enzyme; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: Multiphosphoryl transfer protein: fructose PTS EIIA and FPr; MTP-Fru; diphosphoryl transfer protein (DTP)
Comments: FruB has an N-terminal fructose-specific EIIA domain and a C-terminal HPr-like FPr (fructose-inducible HPr) domain. In the probable fructose-specific PTS kinase cascade, the autophosphorylated enzyme I (PtsI) His189-P transfers a phosphate to His299 in the HPr-like FPr domain of FruB; His299-P transfers a phosphate to His62 of the FruB EIIA domain; His62-P transfers its phosphate to Cys112 of the EIIB domain of FruA and from EIIB to fructose during sugar uptake. 3/70 FruB peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is not removed (Maillet, 2007).

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: C4-dicarboxylate transporter, anaerobic; DcuS co-sensor
Comments: DcuB is a bifunctional protein with both transporter and co-sensor functions; some mutations affect DcuRS-mediated transcriptional regulation but not transport and vice-versa (Kleefeld, 2009; Bauer, 2011). IT (Ion Transporter) superfamily (Prakash, 2003). ST(3) structural class based on hydropathy profile (Lolkema, 2003). DcuB is required for D-tartrate anaerobic transport (Kim, 2007).

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Histidine ABC transporter permease
Comments: Null

Protein: sensory histidine kinase in two-component regulatory system with ZraR
Description: Two component sensor kinase for ZraP; responsive to Zn(2+) and Pb(2+); autoregulated; regulation of Hyd-3 activity is probably due to crosstalk of overexpressed protein
Comments: Null

Protein: pseudogene, isocitrate dehydrogenase C-terminal gene fragment
Description: Pseudogene, isocitrate dehydrogenase, e14 attachment site
Comments: icdC' encodes the C-terminal 54 amino acid fragment of icd created during e14 prophage insertion. The inntact homolog icdE is a hybrid protein and this is the original C-terminus of icd.

Description: Pseudogene, Rhs family protein with putative toxin domain
Comments: It has been suggested that all Rhs systems are involved in intercellular growth inhibition, suggesting that the Rhs proteins are secreted from E. coli and that the variable C-terminal domains are toxic to neighboring cells when secreted to the outside of the cell (Koskiniemi, 2013).

Protein: peroxide resistance protein, lowers intracellular iron
Description: Peroxide resistance protein, lowers intracellular iron
Comments: Mutants of yaaA in an Hpx- background (katE katG ahpCF) grow poorly, have extensive DNA damage and are filamentous; these phenotypes are due to elevated unincorporated intracellular iron levels that are suppressible by iron chelators (Liu, 2011). Although previous microarray results demonstrated a 4-fold elevation of yaaA expression by hydrogen peroxide in an oxyR mutant, this activation could not be reproduced with LacZ fusions or real time PCR (Zheng, 2001; Liu, 2011). Low abundance protein. UPF0246 family.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Other
Description: Glutathione/cysteine ABC transporter permease/ATPase; exports glutathione and cysteine to the periplasm as required for cytochrome assembly
Comments: Glutathione transport is more efficient than cysteine transport (Pittman, 2005). Exogenous glutathione or cysteine rescues the swarming motility defect and benzylpenicillin hypersensitivity of cydDC mutants (Pittman, 2002; Pittman, 2005).

Protein: murein DD-endopeptidase, space-maker hydrolase, septation protein
Description: Murein DD-endopeptidase, space-maker hydrolase, septation protein; ampicillin sensitivity
Comments: The probably membrane-anchored periplasmic protein MepM(YebA) is one of three D-alanine-meso-DAP specific murein DD-endopeptidases, including MepS(Spr) and MepH(YdhO), which are the long predicted space-maker hydrolases needed to cleave peptide cross-bridges in murein so that the murein sacculus can be elongated by murein synthases; MepM(YebA) can act on intact murein sacculi and soluble cross-linked muropeptide dimers; MepM(YebA) activity requires divalent cations, optimally Zn(2+); cloned mepM(yebA) complements an mepS(spr) deletion; an mepS(spr)-mepH(ydhO)-mepM(yebA) triple mutation is lethal and an mepS(spr)-mepM(yebA) double mutant fails to grow on rich media but grows on minimal media (Singh, 2012). MepM(YebA) is needed for normal septation; mepM(yebA) mutants are more resistant to ampicillin, have septal defects and alleviate the growth defects associated with amiC, ampD and other murein hydrolases (Babu, 2011). NlpD, YgeR, MepM(YebA) and EnvC are members of the M23 clan of predicted metallopeptidases that have C-terminal LytM domains; mutating all four LytM domain genes produces a strain with a severe filamentous phenotype, similar to an amiABC triple mutant, of over 20 times the normal cell length and more than 70 times the normal amount of septa/cell, from 0.5 to 36 septa/cell; also similar to the amiABC mutant, the nlpD-envC-mepM(yebA)-ygeR mutant has altered morphology and delayed onset of lysis after beta-lactam antibiotic treatment (Uehara, 2009). MepM(YebA) must be in the periplasm as that is where its substrate is, but SignalP does not indicate a signal peptide cleavage site; nonetheless there is a single predicted transmembrane segment at positions 21-40 that likely serves as a signal anchor after membrane translocation. The spr, yebA, and ydhO genes have been renamed as mepS, mepM, and mepH, respectively (M. Reddy, personal communication).

Description: Aminoglycoside efflux pump; RND-type transporter
Comments: An acrD mutation confers increased sensitivity to aminoglycosides. acrD is paralogous to acrB. EvgAS regulon.

Description: Cytoskeletal protein required for MreB assembly; required for swarming phenotype; transmembrane protein
Comments: rodZ(yfgA) double mutants with yciB, yciM or yhcB could not be constructed indicating that they are synthetic lethal combinations (Niba, 2007).

Description: 2-dehydro-3-deoxygalactarate aldolase; homohexameric
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Menaquinone, ubiquinone
Description: Octaprenyl diphosphate synthase, isoprenoid biosynthesis
Comments: Null

Protein: targeting factor for csrBC sRNA degradation
Description: Targeting factor for csrBC sRNA degradation by RNase E; degenerate GGDEF/EAL protein; carbon flux regulator; indirectly affects CsrA function
Comments: In its c-di-GMP domains CsrD has HRSDF instead of GGDEF and ELM instead of EAL and does not appear to have either diguanylate cyclase or cyclic-di-GMP phosphodiesterase activities and the role of CsrD in csrB/C destabilization does not involve cyclic-di-GMP metabolism (Suzuki, 2006). There is a very low level of CsrD expression and CsrD may work at substoichiometric concentrations (Suzuki, 2006). False positive lipoprotein prediction, Cys not conserved.

Protein: response regulator in two-component regulatory system with CpxA
Description: Response regulator, periplasmic stress response; CpxA is cognate sensor protein
Comments: Null

Description: Metal-binding GTPase, function unknown; GTP-binding protein; may have role in zinc homeostasis
Comments: YjiA binds metals near its GTPase site, which may modulate its GTPase activity (Sydor, 2013). yjiA and yjiS are widely shared genes flanking the variable Immigration Control Region (ICR) restriction-modification cassettes of enterobacterial genomes (Sibley, 2004). Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004).

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Glyoxylate bypass
Description: Isocitrate lyase, acetate utilization, glyoxylate shunt; tetrameric
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Glyoxylate bypass
Description: Malate synthase A; glyoxylate shunt enzyme
Comments: Null

Protein: pyruvate dehydrogenase, decarboxylase component E1, thiamine triphosphate-binding
Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: Pyruvate dehydrogenase
Description: Pyruvate dehydrogenase, decarboxylase component E1; acetate requirement
Comments: The pyruvate dehydrogenase holoenzyme is AceE(24)+AceF(24)+Lpd(12).

Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: Pyruvate dehydrogenase
Description: Pyruvate dehydrogenase, dihydrolipoamide acetyltransferase E2; acetate requirement
Comments: The crystal structure of AceF (PDB: 4N72) is derived from E. coli O157:H7 but is identical to the K-12 sequence (Wang, 2014). The pyruvate dehydrogenase holoenzyme is AceE(24)+AceF(24)+Lpd(12). HT_Cmplx3_Cyt: AceF+Lpd.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Glyoxylate bypass
Description: Isocitrate dehydrogenase kinase/phosphatase
Comments: Null

Protein: acetate kinase A and propionate kinase 2
Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: Electron transport
Description: Acetate kinase, produces acetyl phosphate; mutants are fluoroacetate resistant; creBC regulon; binds Zn(II)
Comments: The AckA N-terminus has been reported to be blocked (Fox, 1986). The AckA N-terminus has been reportedly determined by protein sequencing, but the actual sequence data was not provided so it is not known if the intitial Met is cleaved or not, therefore AckA is not in the Verified Set (Katayama, 2002). OtherPDB(S.typhimurium): 3SLC, 3SK3 (Chittori, 2012).

Protein: pyruvate formate-lyase 1-activating enzyme; [formate-C-acetyltransferase 1]-activating enzyme; PFL activase
Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: Anaerobic respiration
Description: Pyruvate formate-lyase 1-activating enzyme; [formate-C-acetyltransferase 1]-activating enzyme; PFL activase
Comments: Radical SAM superfamily.

Protein: fused DNA-binding transcriptional dual regulator/O6-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase
Description: O6-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase, transcription factor; inducible; DNA repair against methylating and alkylating agents; binds Zn(II)
Comments: The Ada N-terminal domain acts as a transcriptional activator of ada, alkA, alkB and aidB. Ogt, Ada-C and YbaZ are homologous.

Function: Enzyme; Salvage of nucleosides and nucleotides
Description: Adenosine deaminase
Comments: Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004). An add mutation affects growth on deoxyadenosine as carbon source in purA purB mutant background. 17/286 Add peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is not removed (Maillet, 2007).

Protein: fused acetaldehyde-CoA dehydrogenase/iron-dependent alcohol dehydrogenase/pyruvate-formate lyase deactivase
Description: Alcohol dehydrogenase, largely anaerobic; aerobic antioxidant; acetaldehyde-CoA dehydrogenase, CoA-linked; allyl alcohol resistance
Comments: The reported PFL deactivase activity of AdhE (Kessler, 1991, 1992) could not be reproduced (Nnyepi, 2007).

Description: Adenylate kinase; weak nucleoside diphosphate kinase activity; pleiotropic effects on glycerol-3-phosphate acyltransferase activity; monomeric
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Pool, multipurpose conversions
Description: Periplasmic glucose-1-phosphatase, acidic; has inositol phosphatase activity
Comments: Requires DsbA for activity.

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Alanine--tRNA ligase, autorepressor
Comments: alaS is an essential gene (Jasin, 1984). The alaS mutants in the Keio collection have been shown to harbor an intact copy of alaS in addition to the deletion allele (Yamamoto, 2009). AlaS binds to the alaS promoter region and autoregulates its own gene expression in response to the intracellular alanine concentration (Putney, 1981a).

Description: Aldehyde dehydrogenase, NAD-dependent; active on lactaldehyde, glycolaldehyde, and other aldehydes
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: Gamma-glutamyl-gamma-aminobutyraldehyde dehydrogenase; succinate semialdehyde dehydrogenase; putrescine utilization pathway
Comments: PatD and PuuC account for 55% and 30%, respectively, of the cellular gamma-aminobutyraldehyde dehydrogenase activity (Schneider, 2012). PuuC accounts for 75% of the cellular NAD-dependent succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase activity (Schneider, 2012).

Protein: oxidative demethylase of N1-methyladenine or N3-methylcytosine DNA lesions
Function: Putative enzyme; DNA - replication, repair, restriction/modification
Description: Alkylated DNA repair enzyme; alpha-ketoglutarate- and Fe(II)-dependent dioxygenase; releases replication blocks by oxidative demethylation of 1-methyladenine and 3-methylcytosine residues in ssDNA and dsDNA
Comments: AlkB mutants are extremely sensitive to MMS. Also repairs alkylated mRNA and tRNA in vivo and in vitro, the first example of direct RNA repair. Repairs epsilonA and epsilonC. Ada regulon.

Function: Enzyme; Salvage of nucleosides and nucleotides
Description: AMP nucleosidase
Comments: PhoB regulon (Baek, 2006).

Description: Penicillin-binding protein; beta-lactamase, intrinsically weak; penicillin resistance; affects morphology
Comments: AmpC is a penicillin-binding protein (Henderson, 1997). AmpC has a false positive lipoprotein prediction. AmpC is a verified SPI substrate (Jaurin, 1981).

Description: 1,6-anhydro-N-acetylmuramyl-L-alanine amidase, Zn-dependent; murein amidase
Comments: 2/87 AmpD peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is not removed (Maillet, 2007).

Protein: ampicillin resistance inner membrane protein; putative signaling protein in beta-lactamase regulation
Description: Ampicillin resistance inner membrane protein; putative signaling protein in beta-lactamase regulation
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Sulfur metabolism
Description: 3'(2'),5'-bisphosphate nucleotidase; converts pAp to AMP; lithium- and calcium-inhbited; putative PAPS (adenosine 3'-phosphate 5'-phosphosulfate) 3'(2'),5'-bisphosphate nucleotidase
Comments: CysQ is a main target of lithium toxicity in vivo. CysQ (AmtA) was originally thought to be involved in ammonium transport. CysQ may be part of a futile sulfur cycle with APS kinase CysC. CysQ is also known as 3'-phosphoadenosine 5'-phosphate (pAp) phosphatase. 6/78 CysQ peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is not removed (Maillet, 2007).

Description: Osmotically inducible lipoprotein, function unknown
Comments: osmE is also regulated by growth phase. Promoter overlaps divergent nadE promoter. The first 20 aa of osmE cosntitute a type II signal peptide. HT_Cmplx43_Mem: DcrB+MoaB+OsmE+Slp+YajG+YraP.

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Amino acids
Description: L-asparaginase 1, cytoplasmic, low affinity
Comments: AnsA is required for utilization of L-asparagine as the sole source of nitrogen (Del Casale, 1983).

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Amino acids
Description: L-asparaginase 2, periplasmic, high affinity
Comments: ansB is regulated by Crp and FNR. AnsB can provide an anaerobic electron acceptor and allows growth on asparagine and glycerol anaerobically (Yogitha, 2013).

Protein: protein associated with Co2+ and Mg2+ efflux
Description: Expressed as part of complex ksgA operon, function unknown; Salmonella ortholog involved in Co2+ and Mg2+ efflux; upstream of apaH
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Salvage of nucleosides and nucleotides
Description: Dinucleoside tetraphosphatase, symmetrical; diadenosine tetraphosphatase; bis(5'-nucleosyl)-tetraphosphatase, symmetrical
Comments: Required for invasion of cultured mammalian cells by S. typhimurium. Stress response. Complex operon.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Pool, multipurpose conversions
Description: Acid phosphatase, pH 2.5, exopolyphosphatase; phytase
Comments: EvgAS regulon. AppA requires DsbA for activity.

Function: Regulator; Central intermediary metabolism: Pool, multipurpose conversions; Phage or Prophage Related
Description: Global transcription regulator, AraC family, DLP12 prophage
Comments: The global transcriptional regulator AppY stimulates expression of the anaerobically-induced energy metabolism operons hyaA-F and cbdABX-appA (Br√∏ndsted, 1996; Atlung, 1996; Atlung, 1997). appY expression is induced by phosphate starvation and stationary phase. AppY activates cbdABX-appA transcription as growth slows, and AppY either activates or repressses other genes during exponential or stationary phase.

Function: Enzyme; Salvage of nucleosides and nucleotides
Description: Adenine phosphoribosyltransferase; adenine salvage, AMP from PRPP + Ade
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: L-arabinose isomerase; first step in arabinose catabolism; converts L-arabinose to L-ribulose
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: Ribulokinase
Comments: Null

Function: Regulator; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: Transcriptional activator for the ara regulon; autorepressor in the absence of arabinose co-activator
Comments: AraC activates transcrption for araE and the araBAD and araFGH operons; AraC transcriptional activator family prototype.

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: L-ribulose-5-phosphate 4-epimerase
Comments: AraD is a masked class II aldolase.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: Low-affinity L-arabinose transport; L-arabinose proton symport
Comments: Major Facilitator Superfamily (MFS).

Protein: L-arabinose ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein
Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: L-arabinose ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein
Comments: Null

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: L-arabinose ABC transporter ATPase
Comments: Null

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: L-arabinose ABC transporter permease
Comments: Null

Function: Transport; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: L-arabinose-inducible MFS family transporter, function unknown; not involved in arabinose uptake or utilization
Comments: A mutation in araJ does not affect arabinose uptake or utilization and does not affect the kinetics of arabinose induction, implying it is not an arabinose exporter either; the AraJ transport substrate is unknown (Reeder, 1991). Ara regulon.

Syn: cpxC, dye, fexA, msp, seg, sfrA
Protein: response regulator in two-component regulatory system with ArcB or CpxA
Description: Response regulator, represses aerobic genes during anaerobic growth; auto-activator; activates some anaerobic genes; phosphorylated by two-component sensor kinase ArcB; RpoS represssor
Comments: The phosphorylated aerobic respiration control response regulator ArcA is also a direct repressor of rpoS transcription, binding at the promoter region (Mika, 2005). The arcA promoter region binds ArcA and ArcA activates arcA exression (Federowicz, 2014).

Protein: aerobic respiration control sensor histidine protein kinase, cognate to two-component response regulators ArcA and RssB
Description: Aerobic respiration control sensor histidine protein kinase; phosphorylates response regulator proteins ArcA and RssB
Comments: The ArcAB two-component regulatory system represses aerobic genes and activates some anerobic genes under anaerobic growth conditions. ArcB has has one receiver domain and two transmitter domains facilitating a four-step phosphorelay to ArcA and RssB.

Protein: amino acid N-acetyltransferase and inactive acetylglutamate kinase
Description: N-acetylglutamate synthase; first step in arginine biosynthesis; amino-acid acetyltransferase; L-glutamate N-acetyltransferase; growth on acetylornithine; feedback inhibited by L-arginine
Comments: Null

Description: N-acetylglutamate kinase
Comments: Null

Description: N-acetyl-gamma-glutamyl-phosphate reductase
Comments: 4/125 ArgC peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is not removed (Maillet, 2007).

Protein: bifunctional acetylornithine aminotransferase and succinyldiaminopimelate aminotransferase
Description: Acetylornithine aminotransferase; succinyldiaminopimelate aminotransferase, PLP-dependent
Comments: OtherPDB(S. typhimurium): 2PB0,2PB2 (Rajaram, 2007). HT_Cmplx34_Cyt: ArgD+CbpA+PepT.

Protein: ornithine carbamoyltransferase 2, chain F; CP4-6 prophage
Function: Enzyme; Amino acid biosynthesis: Arginine; Phage or Prophage Related
Description: Ornithine carbamoyltransferase; ornithine transcarbamylase; OTCase; CP4-6 putative prophage remnant
Comments: argI and argF have same enzyme activity. ArgF and ArgI form both homotrimers and heterotrimers (Legrain, 1972).

Description: Argininosuccinate synthase
Comments: Null

Description: Ornithine carbamoyltransferase; ornithine transcarbamylase; OTCase
Comments: argI and argF have same enzyme activity. ArgF and ArgI form both homotrimers and heterotrimers (Legrain, 1972).

Protein: l-arginine-responsive arginine metabolism regulon transcriptional regulator
Description: Repressor of Arg regulon; cer-mediated site-specific recombination in plasmid ColE1; hexameric
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Arginine--tRNA ligase
Comments: Null

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Lys-, Arg-, and Orn-binding protein, periplasmic
Comments: After four hours of Zn(II) stress, ArgT protein levels decreased (Easton, 2006).

Description: 5-enolpyruvyl shikimate-3-phosphate synthase; ESPS synthase; 3-phosphoshikimate-1-carboxyvinyltransferase
Comments: The N-terminus of AroA was sequenced in Duncan et al., FEBS Lett. 170:59-63 (1984) but this citation is not in Medline; the sequencing result is noted in pmid 3518706, which is cited in the Verified Set.

Description: 3-Dehydroquinate synthase
Comments: aroB is a multi-copy suppressor of a pdxB deletion (Kim, 2010).

Description: Chorismate synthase
Comments: Null

Description: 3-Dehydroquinate dehydratase
Comments: Null

Description: Shikimate 5-dehydrogenase
Comments: AroE is also called dehydroshikimate reductase. AroE is paralogous to YdiB.

Description: 3-deoxy-D-arabino-heptulosonate 7-phosphate (DAHP) synthase; tyrosine repressible; TyrR regulon
Comments: The 40 N-terminal amino acids of AroF were also determined by Shultz et al., FEBS Lett. 131:108-110 (1981) but this citation in not in Medline so it is not included in the Verified Set references.

Description: 3-deoxy-D-arabino-heptulosonate-7-phosphate (DAHP) synthase; phenylalanine repressible; TyrR regulon
Comments: The 40 N-terminal amino acids of AroG were also determined by Shultz et al., FEBS Lett. 131:108-110 (1981) but this citation in not in Medline so it is not included in the Verified Set references.

Description: 3-deoxy-D-arabino-heptulosonate-7-phosphate (DAHP) synthase; tryptophan repressible
Comments: aroH is in the PurR regulon (Marbach, 2012). The 40 N-terminal amino acids of AroH were also determined by Shultz et al., FEBS Lett. 131:108-110 (1981) but this citation in not in Medline so it is not included in the Verified Set references.

Description: Shikimate kinase I; alkali-inducible
Comments: Null

Description: Shikimate kinase II
Comments: Null

Description: Function unknown
Comments: aroM is downstream of aroL.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: General aromatic amino acid transport permease
Comments: AroP imports phenylalanine, tyrosine, and tryptophan across the cytoplasmic membrane. APC superfamily. Tyr regulon.

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: Phospho-beta-glucosidase; inducer unknown; expressed when repressor AscG is mutated
Comments: bglA, bglB and ascB are paralogs.

Protein: cellobiose/arbutin/salicin-specific PTS enzymes, IIB and IC components
Function: Enzyme; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: PTS system EIIBC enzyme, beta-glucoside phosphotransferase; paralogous to bglF; cryptic unless AscG is mutated
Comments: Null

Protein: asc operon transcriptional repressor; prpBC operon repressor
Function: Regulator; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: Repressor of asc operon; inducer unknown; prpBC operon repressor
Comments: An alternative ascG ATG start codon that precedes the annotated start codon might be utilized to form a 337 aa primary AscG translation product.

Description: Aspartate semialdehyde dehydrogenase
Comments: The asd-yhgN divergent genes promoter region binds FNR (Federowicz, 2014).

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Sulfur metabolism
Description: Predicted periplasmic non-aryl sulfatase, Ser-type; possible periplasmic mucin-desulfating sulfatase
Comments: E. coli K-12 cells exhibit mucin-desulfating sulfatase activity but not arylsulfatase activity (Yamada, 1978; Jansen, 1999). It is not known if one or both of the predicted periplasmic sulfatases AslA and YdeN are responsible for the observed mucin-desulfating sulfatase activity, but it is possible. AslB is predicted to be the anaerobic sulfatase-maturating enzyme converting Ser136 to 3-oxoalanine in AslA. 3-oxoalanine is also known as Calpha-formylglycine (FGly). The first 24 aa of AslA are predicted to be a type I signal peptide.

Description: Predicted AslA-specific anaerobic sulfatase-maturating enzyme; Radical SAM enzyme
Comments: AslB is predicted to be the anaerobic sulfatase-maturating enzyme (anSME) responsible for the conversion of Ser136 to Calpha-formylglycine (FGly), also known as 3-oxoalanine, in the predicted periplasmic sulfatase AslA (Berteau, 2006). E. coli K-12 cells exhibit mucin-desulfating sulfatase activity but not arylsulfatase activity (Jansen, 1999). anSMEs are also known as Radical SAM superfamily sulfatase-maturases. Rob regulon.

Description: Asparagine synthase A; aspartate-ammonia ligase
Comments: AsnA is related to class II aa-tRNA synthetases (Nakatsu, 1998). AsnA and AsnB are redundant; an asparagine auxotrophy requires that both genes be mutated. AsnA uses ammonia as the nitrogen source. Residues 199-203 of zwf encode a NNWDN peptide involved in MazF(ChpA) toxicity that is likely converted to NNWNN by AsnA since an asnA deletion prevents NNWNN activity (Kolodkin-Gal, 2007).

Description: Asparagine synthase B [glutamine-hydrolyzing]
Comments: AsnA and AsnB are redundant; an asparagine auxotrophy requires that both the asnA and the asnB genes be mutated. Although ammonia can be utilized by AsnB, glutamine is the preferred substrate.

Description: Regulatory gene for asnA, asnC, gidA, Lrp family
Comments: Feast/famine regulatory protein.

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Asparagine--tRNA ligase
Comments: asnS is in the PurR regulon (Marbach, 2012).

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Pool, multipurpose conversions
Description: L-aspartate ammonia-lyase; L-aspartase
Comments: Tetrameric enzyme. Repressed by nitrate via NarXL mediated repression.

Description: Aspartate aminotransferase, AspAT; kynurenine aminotransferase; glutamine transaminase K
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Aspartate--tRNA ligase
Comments: Null

Protein: F1 sector of membrane-bound ATP synthase, alpha subunit
Description: ATP synthase subunit alpha, membrane-bound, F1 sector
Comments: Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004). HT_Cmplx10_Mem: AtpA+AtpD+AtpG. HT_Cmplx1_Cyt: AtpA+AtpD.

Comments: Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004). HT_Cmplx10_Mem: AtpA+AtpD+AtpG. HT_Cmplx1_Cyt: AtpA+AtpD.

Description: ATP synthase subunit c, membrane-bound, F0 sector; DCCD-binding
Comments: Null

Description: ATP synthase subunit b, membrane-bound, F0 sector
Comments: Null

Protein: F1 sector of membrane-bound ATP synthase, gamma subunit
Description: ATP synthase subunit gamma, membrane-bound, F1 sector
Comments: HT_Cmplx10_Mem: AtpA+AtpD+AtpG.

Protein: F1 sector of membrane-bound ATP synthase, delta subunit
Description: ATP synthase subunit delta, membrane-bound, F1 sector
Comments: Null

Description: ATP synthase, membrane-bound accessory factor
Comments: AtpI is not required for ATP synthase activity and is not present in the ATP synthase complex, although atpI mutants have a lower growth yield indicating an accessory role in ATP synthase function, perhaps as a non-essential membrane assembly factor (von Meyenburg, 1982; Gay, 1984). atpI has numerous rare codons and is poorly expressed. atpI is contained within one of the 20 regions of extreme structure (RES15) probably representing a highly curved DNA segment (Pedersen, 2000).

Protein: valine-pyruvate aminotransferase; transaminase C; alanine-valine transaminase
Description: Valine-pyruvate aminotransferase; transaminase C; alanine-valine transaminase
Comments: 3/30 AvtA peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is removed (Maillet, 2007).

Description: Peroxiredoxin, thioredoxin-dependent thiol peroxidase; peroxide hypersensitivity; Prx
Comments: Downregulated twofold by GSNO in defined medium (anaerobic).

Description: Choline dehydrogenase, oxygen-dependent; bet genes confer protection against osmotic stress by making the osmoprotectant glycine betaine from choline
Comments: The bet genes are induced by choline, oxygen, and osmotic stress. ArcA regulon.

Description: Betaine aldehyde dehydrogenase, NAD-dependent; bet genes confer protection against osmotic stress by making the osmoprotectant glycine betaine from choline; tetrameric
Comments: The bet genes are induced by choline, oxygen, and osmotic stress. ArcA regulon.

Protein: choline-inducible betIBA-betT divergent operon transcriptional repressor
Description: Transcriptional repressor for the betIBA-betT divergent operon, choline-inducible
Comments: The bet genes confer protection against osmotic stress by making the osmoprotectant glycine betaine from choline. TetR family. ArcA regulon. BetI is bound to its operator in both repressed and induced cells. The bet genes are induced by choline, oxygen, and osmotic stress.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Other
Description: High-affinity choline transporter; BCCT family; bet genes confer protection against osmotic stress by making the osmoprotectant glycine betaine from choline
Comments: The bet genes are induced by choline, oxygen, and osmotic stress. ArcA regulon.

Protein: bacterioferritin, iron storage and detoxification protein
Function: Carrier; Transport of small molecules: Cations
Description: Bacterioferritin; negatively regulated by ryhB RNA as part of indirect positive regulation by Fur; 24-mer
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: Phospho-beta-glucosidase B; allows growth on arbutin or salicin when activated
Comments: bglB is part of the cryptic bglGFBH operon. The bgl operon promoter is silenced by H-NS, represssed by Fis and activated by CRP-cAMP. bglA, bglB and ascB are paralogs.

Protein: fused beta-glucoside-specific PTS enzymes: IIA component/IIB component/IIC component
Function: Enzyme; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: PTS system EIIABC enzyme, beta-glucoside phosphotransferase; BglG kinase/dephosphorylase; membrane-bound protein; binds BglG
Comments: BglF is probably phosphorylated at His547 in the C-terminal EIIA domain by phospho-HPr (PtsH); His547 then transfers the phosphate to Cys24 in the N-terminal EIIB domain which then transfers the phosphate to BglG, inactivating it in the absence of the beta glucoside sugar, or to the sugar during transport. bglF is part of the cryptic bglGFBH operon. The bgl operon promoter is silenced by H-NS, represssed by Fis and activated by CRP-cAMP.

Protein: transcriptional antiterminator of the bgl operon
Function: Regulator; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: Transcription antiterminator for cryptic bglGFBH operon; RNA-binding protein; dimerization and activity modulated by phosphorylation state; binds kinase/dephosphorylase BglF
Comments: The non-phosphorylated BglG dimer binds to RNA and allows readthrough of transcription. BglG has an N-terminal RNA-binding domain followed by two PTS-regulation and dimerization (PRD) domains, PRD1 and PRD2, which contain the phosphorylated sites. BglG is activated by phospho-HPr(PtsH)-mediated phosphorylation and is deactivated by BglF-mediated phosphorylation at a second site; the inducing beta-glucoside sugar causes BglF to dephosphylate BglG at the second site, leading to cytoplasmic localization of BglG, BglG dimerization, and activation of BglG-mediated antitermination of the bgl operon (Amster-Choder, 1992; G√∂rke, 1999). BglG is homologus to LicT of B. subtilis.

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Biotin
Description: 7,8-diaminopelargonic acid aminotransferase
Comments: 7/66 BioA peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is not removed (Maillet, 2007).

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Biotin
Description: Biotin synthase; dethiobiotin to biotin pathway; iron-sulfur enzyme
Comments: Radical SAM superfamily. BioB contains two distinct Fe-S cluster binding sites, one site accommodates a [2Fe-2S](2+) cluster with partial noncysteinyl ligation, the other site accommodates a [4Fe-4S](2+,+) cluster that binds S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) at a unique Fe site of the [4Fe-4S](2+) cluster and undergoes O(2)-induced degradation via a distinct type of [2Fe-2S](2+) cluster intermediate.

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Biotin
Description: Malonyl-ACP O-methyltransferase, SAM-dependent; biotin synthesis blocked prior to pimeloyl CoA formation
Comments: A previous suggestion that BioC may methylate malonyl-ACP instead of malonyl-CoA was confirmed using the BioC enzyme from B. cereus and E. coli malonyl-ACP in vitro because active native BioC cannot be purified; the B. cereus enyzme complements an E. coli bioC mutation thus validating the function of the E. coli BioC enzyme in vivo (Lin, 2012). BioC and BioH are required to synthesize pimeloyl-ACP, a biotin precursor, utilizing the enzymes of fatty acid synthesis to add acyl groups to malonyl-CoA in two cycles to form pimeloyl-ACP methyl ester; BioC may methylate malonyl-ACP instead of malonyl-CoA (Lin, 2010).

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Biotin
Description: Dethiobiotin synthase
Comments: False positive lipoprotein prediction, verified amino terminus, Met is cleaved. BioD is 50% identical to paralog YnfK.

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Biotin
Description: 7-keto-8-amino pelargonic acid synthase
Comments: The N-terminal methionine of overexpressed BioF is removed, as confirmed by protein sequencing, but the native RBS was not included in the pET cloning, so BioB is omitted from the Verified Set (Alexeev, 1998).

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Biotin
Description: Pimeloyl-ACP methyl ester carboxylesterase; short acyl chain carboxylesterase, binds CoA; biotin synthesis blocked prior to pimeloyl CoA formation
Comments: BioC and BioH are required to synthesize pimeloyl-ACP, a biotin precursor, utilizing the enzymes of fatty acid synthesis to add acyl groups to malonyl-CoA in two cycles to form pimeloyl-ACP methyl ester, which is hydrolyzed by BioH (Lin, 2010). S. marcescens bioH complements E. coli bioH. The N-terminal methionine is not removed, as indicated by the intact mass of the overexpressed protein.

Protein: bifunctional biotin-[acetylCoA carboxylase] holoenzyme synthetase/ DNA-binding transcriptional repressor, bio-5'-AMP-binding
Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Biotin
Description: Bifunctional biotin protein ligase, biotin operon repressor; biotin-[acetyl-CoA carboxylase] holoenzyme synthase; monomeric
Comments: Biotinyl-5'-AMP is the co-repressor and is also synthesized by BirA (Cronan, 1988). BirA biotinylates AccB on K122. The biotin operon is regulated by the rate of protein biotination (Cronan, 1989).

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Biotin
Description: Biotin sulfoxide and methionine (S) sulfoxide reductase; cytoplasmic
Comments: BisC is sufficient for growth on Met-S-SO. BisC is unable to act on protein bound Met-S-SO. The N-terminal 39 amino acids are required for activity and anchor BisC to the cytoplasmic side of the inner membrane.

Protein: stationary-phase morphogene, transcriptional repressor for mreB; also regulator for dacA, dacC, and ampC
Description: Stationary-phase morphogene, transcriptional repressor; predicted reductase; regulates mreB, dacA, dacC, and ampC transcription; shape determinant; FtsZ dependent; induced by AI-2 pheromone
Comments: BolA overexpression produces osmotically stable spherical cells. BolA can form a heterodimer in vitro with FeS-bound monothiol glutaredoxin Grx4 but this complex is much less efficient than the FeS-bound Grx4 homodimer in FeS cluster transfer to Fdx (Yeung, 2011). bolA and ibaG(yrbA) are paralogs. BolA and OsmC are distant homologs, although BolA does not have the conserved cysteines of OsmC; BolA is predicted to be a monothiol glutaredoxin-interacting reductase (Huynen, 2005). RpoS regulon.

Description: Vitamin B12 outer membrane receptor; receptor for E colicins, phages BF23 and C1
Comments: BtuB translation is regulated by adenosylcobalamin binding directly to btuB mRNA which contains a vitamin B12-responsive riboswitch (Nou, 2000; Nahvi, 2002; Johnson, 2012). The btuB mutants in the Keio collection have been shown to harbor an intact copy of btuB in addition to the deletion allele (Yamamoto, 2009). btuB is a non-essential gene (Koster, 1991). btuB deletions in the Keio collection also disable the 5' end of the downstream essential murI gene due to an unusually large 56 bp gene overlap, explaining why the btuB Keio mutants are merodiploid (Aufr√®re, 1986; Zhou, 2012).

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Other
Description: Vitamin B12 ABC transporter permease
Comments: Null

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Other
Description: Vitamin B12 ABC transporter ATPase
Comments: Null

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Other
Description: Glutathione peroxidase; Gpx; non-specific peroxidase activity
Comments: BtuE uses GSH, TrxA or TrxC as reducing agents in vitro; lipid peroxides could be the physiologically-relevant substrates for BtuE (Arenas, 2010). BtuE is not required for vitamin B12 import (Rioux, 1989).

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Cobalamin
Description: Cobinamide adenosyltransferase
Comments: BtuR enzyme activity has been characterized in Salmonella (Suh, 1993).

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Amino acids
Description: Lysine decarboxylase, inducible; decameric
Comments: ppGpp binds to and inhibits CadA(LdcI) in vitro and in vivo (Kanjee, 2011). Induction of the cadAB operon under acidic conditions and in the presence of lysine neutralized the extracellular environment and enables production of CO(2); production of cadaverine and aminopropylcadaverine instead of putrescine and spermidine also resulted. cadAB operon induction also generated a proton motive force. Lack of cadBA operon induction results in an increase in speF-potE operon expression. CadA(LdcI) is required for full pathogenicity of Salmonella and Vibrio. CadA(LdcI) and RavA ATPase form a complex.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Lysine-cadaverine antiporter
Comments: Induction of the cadBA operon under acidic conditions and in the presence of lycine neutralized extracellualr environment and enabled production of CO(2); production of cadaverine and aminopropylcadaverine instead of putrescine and spermidine also resulted. cadAB operon induction also generates a proton motive force. Lack of cadBA opereon induction results in an increase in speF-potE operon expression.

Function: Regulator; Degradation of small molecules: Amino acids
Description: Transcriptional activator for cadBA, low external pH-, low oxygen-, excess lysine-responsive; homodimeric
Comments: cadC transcription is repressed by multicopy leuO. CadC is a membrane spanning protein with a TM helix predicted from 155 to 180. The C-terminal periplasmic domain senses external stimuli and the N-terminal domain activates transcription.

Protein: carbamoyl phosphate synthetase small subunit, glutamine amidotransferase
Description: Carbamoyl phosphate synthase, small subunit; glutamine-hydrolyzing, tetramer of heterodimers
Comments: Null

Description: Carbamoyl phosphate synthase, ammonia, large subunit; tetramer of heterodimers
Comments: Null

Protein: fused tRNA nucleotidyl transferase/2'3'-cyclic phosphodiesterase/2'nucleotidase and phosphatase
Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: tRNA nucleotidyltransferase, repairs terminal CCA of tRNAs
Comments: The CCA C-terminal HD domain has Ni(2+)-dependent phosphatase activity toward pyrophosphate, canonical 5'-nucleoside tri- and diphosphates, NADP, and 2'-AMP. It also has metal-independent phosphodiesterase activity toward 2',3'-cAMP, -cGMP, and -cCMP (Yakunin, 2004).

Function: Enzyme; Salvage of nucleosides and nucleotides
Description: Cytidine deaminase; 2-deoxycytidine deaminase; mutants are 5-fluorodeoxycytidine resistant; binds Zn(II)
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Fatty acid and phosphatidic acid biosynthesis
Description: CDP-diglyceride hydrolase; Salmonella ortholog has both UDP sugar hydrolase (UshB) and NAD pyrophosphatase (PnuE) activities
Comments: It is unclear if Cdh(E.c.) has UshB or PnuE activity. E. coli is UshB- and cloned cdh does not confer UshB activity, but protein expression is undetectable due to poor translation of cdh(ushB) mRNA

Function: Enzyme; Fatty acid and phosphatidic acid biosynthesis
Description: CDP-diglyceride synthase, integral membrane protein with eight transmembrane helices; also known as phosphatidate cytidylyltransferase
Comments: Null

Protein: N,N'-diacetylchitobiose-specific enzyme IIB component of PTS
Function: Enzyme; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: N,N'-diacetylchitobiose utilization, enzyme IIB(Chb) of the PTS transport system
Comments: The chb operon is induced by N,N'-diacetylchitobiose. The chb operon was previously thought to encode a cryptic cel operon for a cellobiose degradation system. The Cel+ phenotype is due to mutations making expression chitobiose-independent, but a fully induced operon did not support growth on cellobiose, implying a mutation altering the substrate specificity is needed; several candidate mutations were noted in Genbank, but not proven to alter the specificity of the system (Keyhani, 1997). In contrast, a later study claim that mutations making the operon expression high-level constitutive by chbR and nagC mutations are sufficient for the Cel+ phenotype and that no mutations altering substrate specificity are required (Kachroo, 2007). The chbBC intergenic region contains an RNA decoy (trap-mRNA) which is antisense to the chiX(micM) sRNA; induction of the chb operon leads to chiX(micM) degradation and consequently to chiP induction as chiX(micM) repression is relieved (Overgaard, 2009). In Salmonella, chiX(micM) is also inactivated by the chbBC intergenic region, which in Salmonella (and possibly in E. coli also) is processed by RNase E to a ~3000 bp fragment (Figuera-Bossi (2009).

Protein: N,N'-diacetylchitobiose-specific enzyme IIC component of PTS
Function: Enzyme; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: PTS Enzyme IIC(Chb) for N,N'-diacetylchitobiose utilization
Comments: The chb operon is induced by N,N'-diacetylchitobiose. The chb operon was previously thought to encode a cryptic cel operon for a cellobiose degradation system. The Cel+ phenotype is due to mutations making expression chitobiose-independent, but a fully induced operon did not support growth on cellobiose, implying a mutation altering the substrate specificity is needed; several candidate mutations were noted in Genbank, but not proven to alter the specificity of the system (Keyhani, 1997). In contrast, a later study claim that mutations making the operon expression high-level constitutive by chbR and nagC mutations are sufficient for the Cel+ phenotype and that no mutations altering substrate specificity are required (Kachroo, 2007). The chbBC intergenic region contains an RNA decoy (trap-mRNA) which is antisense to the chiX(micM) sRNA; induction of the chb operon leads to chiX(micM) degradation and consequently to chiP induction as chiX(micM) repression is relieved (Overgaard, 2009). In Salmonella, chiX(micM) is also inactivated by the chbBC intergenic region, which in Salmonella (and possibly in E. coli also) is processed by RNase E to a ~3000 bp fragment (Figuera-Bossi (2009).

Protein: N,N'-diacetylchitobiose-specific enzyme IIA component of PTS
Function: Enzyme; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: PTS Enzyme IIA(Chb), N,N'-diacetylchitobiose utilization; trimeric
Comments: The chb operon is induced by N,N'-diacetylchitobiose. The chb operon was previously thought to encode a cryptic cel operon for a cellobiose degradation system. The Cel+ phenotype is due to mutations making expression chitobiose-independent, but a fully induced operon did not support growth on cellobiose, implying a mutation altering the substrate specificity is needed; several candidate mutations were noted in Genbank, but not proven to alter the specificity of the system (Keyhani, 1997). In contrast, a later study claim that mutations making the operon expression high-level constitutive by chbR and nagC mutations are sufficient for the Cel+ phenotype and that no mutations altering substrate specificity are required (Kachroo, 2007). The overexpressed, but native sequence, ChbA N-terminus was protein sequenced and the methionine is not removed, but the native RBS was not used in a pET vector so ChbA is not in the Verified Set (Keyhani, 2000).

Protein: repressor of chb operon for N,N'-diacetylchitobiose utilization
Function: Regulator; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: Repressor for chb operon, N,N'-diacetylchitobiose utilization
Comments: The Cel+ phenotype is due to mutations making expression chitobiose-independent, but a fully induced operon did not support growth on cellobiose, implying a mutation altering the substrate specificity is needed; several candidate mutations were noted in Genbank, but not proven to alter the specificity of the system (Keyhani, 1997). In contrast, a later study claim that mutations making the operon expression high-level constitutive by chbR and nagC mutations are sufficient for the Cel+ phenotype and that no mutations altering substrate specificity are required (Kachroo, 2007). ChbR has an N-terminal Cupin_2 domain (PF07883) and a C-terminal AraC-like HTH_18 DNA-binding domain (Pfam PF12833).

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: N,N'-diacetylchitobiose
Description: N,N'-diacetylchitobiose utilization, phospho-chitobiase; can hydrolyze a variety of phospho-beta-glucosides
Comments: The chb operon is induced by N,N'-diacetylchitobiose. The chb operon was previously thought to encode a cryptic cel operon for a cellobiose degradation system. The Cel+ phenotype is due to mutations making expression chitobiose-independent, but a fully induced operon did not support growth on cellobiose, implying a mutation altering the substrate specificity is needed; several candidate mutations were noted in Genbank, but not proven to alter the specificity of the system (Keyhani, 1997). In contrast, a later study claim that mutations making the operon expression high-level constitutive by chbR and nagC mutations are sufficient for the Cel+ phenotype and that no mutations altering substrate specificity are required (Kachroo, 2007).

Description: Inner membrane protein, function unknown
Comments: CreBC regulon. Overproduction of CreD was previously associated with colicin E2 tolerance, but has been shown to be not involved in colicin E2 tolerance (Cariss, 2010). CreD is the prototype for the CreD/Cet family of inner membrane proteins of unknown function (PF05981).

Protein: fused chemotactic sensory histidine kinase in two-component regulatory system with CheB and CheY: sensory histidine kinase/signal sensing protein
Description: Histidine protein kinase sensor of chemotactic response; CheY is cognate response regulator; autophosphorylating
Comments: CheA is required for polar localization of CheZ. CheAS (CheA-short) is a short form of full-length CheA (also known as CheAL for CheA-long) translated using an internal start at codon 98. Fla regulon.

Protein: fused chemotaxis regulator: protein-glutamate methylesterase in two-component regulatory system with CheA
Description: Chemotaxis MCP protein-glutamate methylesterase; reverses CheR methylation at specific MCP glutamates
Comments: otherPDB (S. typhimurium): 1CHD, 1A2O. N-terminal response regulator domain inhibits C-terminal methylesterase unless phosphorylated at D56 by CheA. Flagellar regulon.

Description: Chemotaxis MCP protein methyltransferase, SAM-dependent; binds C-terminus of chemoreceptors; makes glutamate methyl esters
Comments: Overexpression causes filamentous biofilm formation. otherPDB (S .typhimurium): 1AF7, 1BC5. Flagellar regulon.

Description: Chemotaxis signal transducer; bridges CheA to chemoreceptors to regulate phophotransfer to CheY and CheB
Comments: Flagellar regulon.

Protein: chemotaxis regulator transmitting signal to flagellar motor component
Description: Response regulator for chemotactic signal transduction; single-domain response regulator lacking an output domain; CheA is the cognate sensor protein; autoacetylase
Comments: The proposed mechanism for optimum chemotaxis suggests alteration of side chain signaling state by rotation of Tyr106 side chain; this is presumably modulated by phosphorylation state of the molecule. A mutation resulting in a tyrosine to tryptophan substitution at position 106 results in a hyperactive phenotype, while a double mutation T87I/Y106W resulted in loss of activity. Substitutions at ILE95 affect FliM binding. CheY can be reversibly acetylated at lysine residues 91, 92, 109, 119, 122, and 126 by acetyl-CoA synthase (Acs) in vitro (Barak, 1992; Barak, 2004). CheY can autoacetylate lysines in its C-terminal region in vitro (Barak, 2006). A high level of lysine acetylation of CheY is detected in vivo, and both Acs-dependent, acetate-stimulated acetylation and Acs-independent acetylation occurs (Yan, 2008). In vivo Acs-dependent lysine acetylation of CheY is consistent with the chemotaxis defects observed in Acs mutants and CheY Lys92 mutants (Barak, 2001) Acs-independent acetylation of CheY could be due to autoacetylation or the activity of a second lysine acetyltransferase such as the lysine acetyltransferase Pka(YfiQ) that has been shown to acetylate Acs lysines in vivo in Salmonella. CobB can deacetylate CheY in vitro and in vivo, reducing FliM binding and chemotaxis (Li, 2010). cobB is a mutational phenotypic suppressor of a cheA cheZ double mutation (Li, 2010). Flagellar regulon.

Protein: chemotaxis regulator, protein phosphatase for CheY
Description: CheY-P phosphatase
Comments: Polar localization is dependent on CheA-short. Flagellar regulon.

Protein: molybdate ABC transporter ATPase; chlorate resistance protein
Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Anions
Description: Molybdate ABC transporter ATPase; chlorate resistance
Comments: ModC mutants are unable to reduce selenate.

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Molybdopterin
Description: Molybdopterin molybdenumtransferase; molybdopterin (MPT) synthesis; incorporation of molybdenum into MPT; chlorate resistance
Comments: Human gephyrin resembles a fused MoeA and Mog. MoeA is paralogous to YfaY. MoeA mutants are unable to reduce selenate.

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Molybdopterin
Description: Molybdopterin-synthase sulfurylase; adenylation of MoaD C-terminus; chlorate resistance; zinc-containing enyzyme
Comments: YnjE, IscS, MoaD and MoeB form a complex in vivo (Dahl, 2011).

Protein: colicin IA outer membrane receptor and translocator; ferric iron-catecholate transporter
Description: Colicin IA outer membrane receptor and translocator; ferric iron-catecholate transporter
Comments: CirA transports ferric iron-catecholates into cells and the primary function of CirA may be to recapture the hydrolytic products of enterobactin, such as 2,3-dihydroxybenzoic acid and 2,3-dihydroxybenzoylserine (Nikaido, 1990). CirA mediates TonB-dependent translocation of Colicin IA into cells (Jakes, 2010). CirA is a member of the Outer Membrane Receptor (OMR) family of ligand-gated protein channels that utilizes the proton motive force (PMF) and the TonB-ExbB-ExbD complex for iron-siderophore, colicin and microcin uptake. The OMR family belongs to the Porin superfamily and deletions in OMR family proteins can restore a passive diffusion channel function typical of normal OM porins.

Protein: ATPase and specificity subunit of ClpA-ClpP ATP-dependent serine protease, chaperone activity
Function: Enzyme; Degradation of proteins, peptides, glyco
Description: ATPase subunit of ClpAP ATP-dependent protease; protease Ti; molecular chaperone
Comments: Null

Function: Putative enzyme; Degradation of proteins, peptides, glyco
Description: Bichaperone with DnaK for protein disaggregation; disaggregase; protein-dependent ATPase; role in de novo protein folding under mild stress conditions
Comments: ClpB and DnaK cooperate (with DnaJ and GrpE) in the bichaperone-mediated, ATP-dependent unfolding of protein aggregates (Zolkiewski, 1999; Goloubinoff, 1999). ClpB exists in two isoforms, long ClpB(alpha)[ClpB93] and short ClpB(beta3[ClpB79], which is initiated from an internal GUG start at codon 149; both starts have been verified by N-terminal protein sequencing (Squires, 1991; Pontis, 1991). The dual translation initiation sites for ClpB have been confirmed using site-directed mutagenesis (Park, 1993). The N-terminal domain, present only in the ClpB long form, is required for efficient binding to protein aggregates and fully effective chaperone function (Barnett, 2005; Chow, 2005). Coordinated expression of both long and short forms of ClpB is required for the protection from thermal killing; the ratio of short form to long form ClpB is 0.4 to 0.5 under a variety of stress conditions (Chow, 2005). ClpB is heat shock protein F84.1 (Squires, 1991). ClpB is regulated by RpoH (Kitagawa, 1991). clpB is required for growth below 8C, which is enabled by transgenic Oleispira antarctica Cpn10/60. HT_Cmplx30_Mem: ClpB+DnaK+InfB+RpsA.

Protein: proteolytic subunit of ClpA-ClpP and ClpX-ClpP ATP-dependent serine proteases
Function: Enzyme; Degradation of proteins, peptides, glyco
Description: Proteolytic subunit of ClpXP and ClpAP ATP-dependent proteases; protease Ti
Comments: ClpP can simultaneously bind ClpX and ClpA to form a heteromeric complex. Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004). ClpP is required for MazF-mediated cell death after either DNA damage or inhibition of translation (Amitai, 2009). The first 14 aa of ClpP are proteolytically processed in trans by another ClpP molecule (Maurizi, 1990).

Protein: ATPase and specificity subunit of ClpX-ClpP ATP-dependent serine protease
Function: Enzyme; Degradation of proteins, peptides, glyco
Description: ATPase subunit of ClpXP protease; ClpXP degrades ssrA-tagged proteins; molecular chaperone
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Salvage of nucleosides and nucleotides
Description: 2',3'-cyclic nucleotide 2'-phosphodiesterase, periplasmic
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Sugar-nucleotide biosynthesis, conversions
Description: Mannose 1-P guanyltransferase synthesis; extracellular capsule polysaccharide ccolanic acid biosynthesis
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Pool, multipurpose conversions
Description: Phosphomannomutase isozyme; colanic acid biosynthesis synthesis
Comments: Null

Protein: sensory histidine kinase in two-component regulatory system with CpxR
Description: Histidine protein kinase, periplasmic stress sensor; inner membrane protein; CpxR is the two-component cognate response regulator; Kan-R, phage Q resistant; L-serine growth
Comments: Null

Protein: cAMP-activated global transcription factor, mediator of catabolite repression
Description: cAMP-activated global transcription factor; mediator of catabolite repression; CRP; CAP
Comments: Null

Protein: glucose-specific enzyme IIA component of PTS
Function: Enzyme; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: EIIA(Glc), phosphocarrier for glucose PTS transport; negative control of rpoS
Comments: Phosphorylation of Enzyme IIAGlc is necessary for direct translational control of rpoS. Formerly EIII(glc), EIIAGlc is also known as EIIACrr. Dephosphorylation of Enzyme IIAGlc causes inhibition of uptake of a number of non-PTS carbon sources, a process called inducer exclusion. PTS is the phosphoenolpyruvate:carbohydrate phosphotransferase system for the uptake of carbohydrates that are phosphorylated during transport. Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004).

Description: Cold-inducible RNA chaperone and antiterminator; aids gene expression at low temperature; cold shock protein CS7.4; binds ssRNA and ssDNA
Comments: CspA is a transcription antiterminator (Bae, 2000). The cspABEG deletion strain BX04 is cold-sensitive for growth and forms filaments at 15C (Xia, 2001). A cspA deletion grows slow below 8C (as enabled by transgenic Oleispira antarctica Cpn10/60). CspA is similar to Y-box DNA binding proteins of eukaryotes. Mutant has increased aggregation. Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004).

Protein: carbon starvation protein involved in peptide utilization; APC peptide transporter family protein
Description: Predicted APC superfamily peptide transporter; carbon starvation protein involved in peptide utilization
Comments: cstA opp double mutants grow slower than opp single mutants with tryptone, but not casamino acids, as carbon source (Schultz, 1991). A dppG (originally called dpp) mutation involved in dipeptide transport was mapped near cstA and may be allelic to cstA, with the caveat that a cstA opp double mutant does not display the valyl dipeptide resistance phenotype observed for dpp mutants (Schultz, 1991). Paralogs cstA and yjiY are both in operons with paralogous small proteins of unknown function, ybdD and yjiX, respectively. CstA has an N-terminal CstA domain (PF02554) and a C-terminal CstA-associated DUF4161 domain (PF13722) of unknown function; the CstA domain is a member of the APC clan (CL0062) of APC (Amino acid-Polyamine-organoCation) superfamily transporters.

Function: Enzyme; Transport of small molecules: Cations
Description: Apolipoprotein N-acyltransferase; copper sensitivity
Comments: lnt is a conditionally essential gene: lnt can be deleted if LolACDE is overexpressed in an lpp deletion strain, producing lipoproteins without acyl chains (apolipoproteins); a triple mutant lacking all three L,D-transpeptidases linking Lpp to murein [ldtA(erfK),ldtB(ybiS),ldtC(ycfS)] is also permissive (Narita, 2011).

Description: Colicin V production protein
Comments: The physiological host function of CvpA is unknown. cvpA is the first gene in the purF operon and a cvpA polar insertion mutant requires adenine (Fath, 1989).

Description: Adenylate cyclase
Comments: Polyamine modulon (Igarashi, 2006).

Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: Electron transport
Description: Cytochrome b561
Comments: Null

Protein: cytochrome d terminal oxidase, subunit I
Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: Electron transport
Description: Cytochrome d (bd-I) ubiquinol oxidase subunit 1; upregulated in biofilms and microaerobic conditions; aerobically repressed by H-NS; anaerobically repressed by FNR
Comments: H-NS, FNR and ArcA regulons. ArcA-P antagonizes H-NS repression of cydAB in response to limiting oxygen. Biofilm microarray result was validated with RT-PCR. HT_Cmplx29_Mem: CbdA+CydA.

Protein: cytochrome d terminal oxidase, subunit II
Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: Electron transport
Description: Cytochrome d (bd-I) ubiquinol oxidase subunit 2; upregulated in biofilms and microaerobic conditions; aerobically repressed by H-NS; anaerobically repressed by FNR
Comments: FNR and ArcA regulons. ArcA-P antagonizes H-NS repression of cydAB in response to limiting oxygen.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Pool, multipurpose conversions
Description: Cyanate aminohydrolase
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Pool, multipurpose conversions
Description: Carbonic anhydrase, beta class
Comments: Null

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Anions
Description: Putative transporter, function unknown, cyn operon
Comments: 75% of the in vivo transcripts end at a terminator inside the cynX gene; although CynT and CynX wer readily detectble in mincells, CynX was barely detectable (Sung, 1988). Major Facilitator Superfamily (MFS). A cynX mutant does not appear to be defective in cyanate sensitivity or utilization (Guilloton, 1993).

Protein: cytochrome o ubiquinol oxidase subunit II
Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: Aerobic respiration
Description: Cytochrome o oxidase subunit II, lipoprotein; also called cytochrome bo(3) ubiquinol oxidase subunit II
Comments: The first 24 aa of CyoA are a type II signal peptide. The first 25 aa and the last 200 aa of the mature CyoA protein are in the periplasm. Translocation of the N-terminal domain od CyoA requires YidC; translocation of the large C-terminal domain of CyoA requires both YidC and the Sec translocon, and is dependent upon prior translocation of the N-terminal CyoA domain.

Protein: cytochrome o ubiquinol oxidase subunit I
Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: Aerobic respiration
Description: Cytochrome o oxidase subunit I, quinone-binding domain; cytochrome bo(3) ubiquinol oxidase subunit I
Comments: Subunit I (CyoB) of cytochrome o(bo3) oxidase contains the high-affinity ubiquinone binding site QH; residues R71, D75, H98 and Q101 are implicated in quinone binding using site-directed mutagenesis; a low-affinity binding site QL is also present, not precisely located but probably near the QH site (MacMillan, 2011; Yap, 2010; Hellwig, 2002). Cytochrome bo undergoes redox-linked structural alterations.

Protein: cytochrome o ubiquinol oxidase subunit III
Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: Aerobic respiration
Description: Cytochrome o oxidase subunit III; cytochrome bo(3) ubiquinol oxidase subunit III
Comments: Null

Protein: cytochrome o ubiquinol oxidase subunit IV
Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: Aerobic respiration
Description: Cytochrome o oxidase subunit IV; cytochrome bo(3) ubiquinol oxidase subunit IV
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: Aerobic respiration
Description: Cytochrome o oxidase protoheme IX farnesyltransferase subunit
Comments: Null

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Anions
Description: Sulfate/thiosulfate ABC transporter ATPase subunit
Comments: CysA is part of the CysAWUP-Sbp ABC transporter, also known as CysAWTP. cysA mutations are chromate resistant.

Protein: N-acetylserine-responsive cysteine regulon transcriptional activator; autorepressor
Description: Transcriptional activator for the Cys regulon; N-acetylserine induced; autorepressor
Comments: LysR family.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Sulfur metabolism
Description: Adenylylsulfate kinase, APS kinase
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Sulfur metabolism
Description: Sulfate adenylyltransferase subunit 2
Comments: Null

Description: Serine acetyltransferase (SAT); first step in cysteine synthesis; feedback inhibited by cysteine; hexameric
Comments: CysE forms a bienzyme complex with the CysK cysteine synthase A. CysE contains 13 hexapeptide repeats. The cysX gene downstream of cysE is the reverse complement of trmL and is probably not a real gene (Tei, 1990).

Protein: fused siroheme synthase 1,3-dimethyluroporphyriongen III dehydrogenase and siroheme ferrochelatase/uroporphyrinogen methyltransferase
Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Heme, porphyrin
Description: Siroheme synthase, multifunctional enzyme; has three activities: uroporphyrinogen III methyltransferase, SAM-dependent; precorrin-2 dehydrogenase; sirohydrochlorin ferrochelatase
Comments: YraL is homologous to the C-terminal methyltransferase domain of CysG. cysG is transcribed from the nirB operon and from cysG promoters.

Protein: phosphoadenosine phosphosulfate reductase; PAPS reductase, thioredoxin dependent
Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Sulfur metabolism
Description: Phosphoadenosine phosphosulfate reductase; PAPS reductase, thioredoxin dependent
Comments: CysH has a PP-loop superfamily domain.

Protein: sulfite reductase, beta subunit, NAD(P)-binding, heme-binding
Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Sulfur metabolism
Description: Sulfite reductase [NADPH] hemoprotein beta-component; has 4Fe-4S iron-sulfur center
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Sulfur metabolism
Description: Sulfite reductase [NADPH] flavoprotein alpha-component; binds FMN and FAD
Comments: CysJ is a partner of the YcbX molybdoenzyme, probably functioning to provide the NADPH:flavin reductase activity needed for detoxification at the YcbX molybdocenter (Kozmin, 2010).

Protein: cysteine synthase A, O-acetylserine sulfhydrolase A subunit
Description: Cysteine synthase A, O-acetylserine sulfhydrylase A; homodimeric; selenate, azaserine, chromate resistance; alkali-inducible, sulfate starvation-inducible protein SSI5; cysteine desulfhydrase
Comments: CysK forms a bienzyme complex with CysE.

Description: Cysteine synthase B, O-acetylserine sulfhydrylase B
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Sulfur metabolism
Description: Sulfate adenylyltransferase subunit 1; putative ATP sulfurylase GTPase subunit
Comments: ATP sulfurylase is also called ATP:sulfate adenylyltransferase.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Anions
Description: Thiosulfate-binding protein, periplasmic
Comments: CysP is part of the CysAWUP-Sbp ABC transporter, also known as CysAWTP. Sbp is the periplasmic binding protein for sulfate, but genetic evidence suggests that CysP can partially compensate for a loss of Sbp.

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Cysteine--tRNA ligase; binds Zn(II)
Comments: Null

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Anions
Description: Sulfate/thiosulfate ABC transporter permease
Comments: CysU is part of the CysAWUP-Sbp ABC transporter, also known as CysAWTP. cysT is a tRNA gene but has also been used to describe the CysU gene. Although CysT is widely used to describe the CysU permease because it was used in the original transporter publications, we use CysU, not CysT, to describe this permease protein.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Anions
Description: Sulfate/thiosulfate ABC transporter permease
Comments: CysW is part of the CysAWUP-Sbp ABC transporter, also known as CysAWTP.

Protein: Anti-activator for CytR-CRP nucleoside utilization regulon
Description: Anti-activator for nucleoside utilization regulon
Comments: CytR and CRP cooperate to regulate genes involved in nucleoside utiization; CytR binds DNA weakly by itself but CytR binding directly to CRP stabilizes CytR binding to DNA and blocks CRP-mediated activation although CRP remains bound to DNA; release of CytR by cytidine binding allows for re-activation of transcription by CRP-cAMP (Valentin-Hansen, 1996) The CytR-CRP complex is a dual regulation transcription factor complex that is able to activate some promoters rather than repress, depending on the DNA context (Rasmussen, 1996). cytR mutants show improved growth on uridine. Eight target genes (deoC, cdd, ppiA, tsx, nupC, nupG, udp, rpoH) and auto-regulation of cytR constitute the CytR regulon; a tenth gene encoding an inner membrane protein, ycdZ(nupT), is predicted to be regulated by CytR-CRP based on conserved CytR and CRP binding sites but there is no experimental evidence for either YcdZ function or regulation of ycdZ (Sernova, 2012).

Description: D-alanine D-alanine carboxypeptidase PBP5, cell morphology; penicillin-binding protein 5; beta-lactamase activity
Comments: A dacA deletion suppresses ftsK (Ts). DacA-deficient cells have a branching growth pattern and biofilm defect.

Description: D-alanine D-alanine carboxypeptidase PBP4; penicillin-binding protein 4
Comments: False positive lipoprotein prediction, verified SPI substrate. Mutant has biofilm defect.

Description: D-alanine D-alanine carboxypeptidase PBP6; penicillin-binding protein 6
Comments: DacC(PBP6) is a tail-anchored protein with strong hydrophobic interactions between the inner membrane and a C-terminal DacC region that is not integrated into the inner membrane, and thus DacC can be be considered to be a peripheral inner membrane protein largely located in the periplasm (van der Linden, 1992; Harris, 1997; Siligardi, 1997, Harris, 1998; Harris, 2002).

Description: DNA-(adenine-N6)-methyltransferase, methylates GATC; role in repair and replication
Comments: Dam is a base flipping enzyme. GATC sites can be visualized as DpnI cut sites.

Description: Dihydrodipicolinate synthase
Comments: DapA levels may be influenced by GroES and GroEL. A dapA mutant is not in the Keio collection; DAP auxotrophs require added DAP to grow and since no DAP was added during mutant construction, no auxotrophic mutants were recovered; dapA is not an essential gene (Baba, 2006).

Description: Dihydrodipicolinate reductase
Comments: A dapB mutant is not in the Keio collection; DAP auxotrophs require added DAP to grow and since no DAP was added during mutant construction, no auxotrophic mutants were recovered; dapB is not an essential gene (Baba, 2006).

Description: 2,3,4,5-tetrahydropyridine-2-carboxylate N-succinyltransferase; mutations suppress growth defects of strains lacking superoxide dismutase
Comments: A dapD mutant is not in the Keio collection; DAP auxotrophs require added DAP to grow and since no DAP was added during mutant construction, no auxotrophic mutants were recovered; dapD is not an essential gene (Baba, 2006). DapD contains hexapeptide repeats. Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004). HT_Cmplx35_Cyt: DapD+SpeB.

Description: N-succinyl-diaminopimelate desuccinylase, DAP/lysine biosynthesis, contains Zn(2+)/Co(2+)
Comments: A dapE mutant is not in the Keio collection; DAP auxotrophs require added DAP to grow and since no DAP was added during mutant construction, no auxotrophic mutants were recovered. dapE(msgB) is a multicopy suppressor of grpE(Ts). Salmonella DapE also has Zn(2+)/Mn(2+)-dependent Asp-X dipeptidase activity. 7/81 DapE peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is removed (Maillet, 2007).

Description: Diaminopimelate epimerase
Comments: Dimerization of DapF is required for enzyme activity (Hor, 2013).

Protein: ATP-dependent RNA helicase, specific for 23S rRNA
Function: Enzyme; RNA synthesis, modification, DNA transcription
Description: ATP-dependent 3'-5' RNA helicase, specific for 23S rRNA
Comments: Despite earlier report that DbpA is an ATP-independent RNA helicase, DbpA has been shown to be an ATP-dependent RNA helicase (Diges, 2001).

Description: DNA cytosine methyltransferase; internal cytosine methylated
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of proteins, peptides, glyco
Description: Dipeptidyl carboxypeptidase II
Comments: Null

Description: D-alanine:D-alanine ligase A, ADP-forming
Comments: Null

Description: D-alanine:D-alanine ligase B, ADP-forming
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; RNA synthesis, modification, DNA transcription
Description: ATP-dependent RNA helicase, 50S ribosomal subunit biogenesis; translation factor W2; factor X; facilitates translation of mRNAs with 5' secondary structures; multicopy suppressor of rpsB(Ts) mutations
Comments: RNA-stimulated ATPase activity and ATP-dependent RNA helciase activities have been demonstrated in vitro for DeaD(CsdA) (Bizebard, 2004). Mechanism of DeaD 50S biogenesis differs from that for SrmB 50S biogenesis. DeaD stabilizes exposed mRNA, possibly by protecting or destabilizing secondary structure of RNase E sites. Cold shock-inducible; acid-inducible.

Description: DedA family inner membrane protein, function unknown
Comments: DedA superfamily proteins YqjA and YghB likely have redundant functions since only a double mutant has defects; DedA superfamily members yabI or yohD can complement the yqjA yghB double mutant when overproduced, but a dedA clone cannot complement (Thompkins, 2008). The E. coli K-12 DedA superfamily (SNARE associated Golgi protein/PF09335) has eight paralogs in two families, the COG0586 DedA/YghB family (including the DedA/YabI/YohD subfamily and the general envelope maintenance protein YghB/YqjA subfamily) and the YdjX family (including the COG0398 YdjX/YdjZ subfamily and the COG1238 YqaA subfamily) (Doerrler, 2013; K.E.R.).

Function: Enzyme; Fatty acid and phosphatidic acid biosynthesis
Description: Acetyl-CoA carboxylase, carboxyltransferase beta subunit
Comments: Acetyl-CoA carboxylase AccA(2)AccD(2) represses its own translation, mediated by the beta subunit (AccD) binding to the accA and accD mRNAs; translation repression is relieved by acetyl-CoA (Meades, 2010).

Protein: membrane-anchored periplasmic protein involved in septation
Description: Membrane-anchored periplasmic protein involved in septation
Comments: DedD has a single N-terminal transmembrane domain and a C-terminal periplasmic SPOR domain. DedD localizes to the septal ring and dedD mutants are defective in cell division (Gerding, 2009; Arends, 2010).

Function: Enzyme; Salvage of nucleosides and nucleotides
Description: Thymidine phosphorylase; homodimeric
Comments: 7/91 DeoA peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is not removed (Maillet, 2007).

Function: Enzyme; Salvage of nucleosides and nucleotides
Description: Phosphopentomutase; deoxyribouratase
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Salvage of nucleosides and nucleotides
Description: 2-deoxy-D-ribose 5-phosphate aldolase (DERA); deoxyriboaldolase
Comments: DeoC binds selenium tightly even after denaturation, possibly as a perselenide to a cysteine residue such as the conserved Cys47, perhaps indicative of a role in selenium transport (Lacourciere, 2002). DeoC is a survival protein required for MazF-mediated survival of a small subpopulation after inhibition of translation (Amitai, 2009). Half of the native protein still retains the initial Met.

Function: Enzyme; Salvage of nucleosides and nucleotides
Description: Purine nucleoside phosphorylase 1; PNP-I; nicotinamide 1-beta-D-riboside phosphorylase; hexameric
Comments: Purine nucleoside phosphorylase 1 (DeoD) also has nicotinamide 1-beta-D-riboside phosphorylase activity in vitro (Wielgus-Kutrowska, 1997).

Protein: deoxyribose-5-phosphate-inducible deoxyribose operon transcriptional repressor; repressor of nupG and tsx
Function: Regulator; Salvage of nucleosides and nucleotides
Description: Repressor for deo operon, nupG and tsx; deoxyribose-5-phosphate inducible
Comments: The deo operon transcriptional repressor DeoR is also a repressor of the nucleoside transport gene nupG and of the nucleoside porin gene tsx.

Function: Enzyme; Fatty acid and phosphatidic acid biosynthesis
Description: Diacylglycerol kinase
Comments: DgkA is an integral membrane protein.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Nucleotide hydrolysis
Description: Deoxyguanosine 5'-triphosphate triphosphohydrolase; dGTPase
Comments: Null

Protein: Qin prophage; putative regulator for DicB
Function: Regulator; Cell division; Phage or Prophage Related
Description: Transcriptional repressor for dicB, Qin prophage
Comments: PF01381 family.

Protein: Qin prophage; cell division inhibition protein
Function: Regulator; Cell division; Phage or Prophage Related
Description: Control of cell division, activates MinC, Qin prophage
Comments: Overexpression causes filamentous biofilm formation.

Protein: Qin prophage; DNA-binding transcriptional regulator for DicB
Function: Regulator; Cell division; Phage or Prophage Related
Description: Transcriptional repressor for dicB, Qin prophage
Comments: Null

Description: Prevents premature secretion of FlgM; senses flagellar assembly stage
Comments: Flk was characterized in Salmonella. Flk is transcribed divergently from pdxB; their promoters overlap. C-terminal membrane anchor is required for function.

Protein: transcriptional regulator of rRNA transcription; DnaK suppressor protein
Description: RNAP-binding protein modulating ppGpp and iNTP regulation; reduces open complex half-life on rRNA promoters; removes transcriptional roadblocks to replication
Comments: DksA regulates its own repression (Edwards, 2011; Chandrangsu, 2011). High copy dksA suppresses mukB and TS growth and filamentation of a dnaK mutant. dksA is also a multicopy suppressor of dnaJ, grpE and prc. dksA transcription is alkali-inducible. dksA mutations affect chromosomal supercoiling.
