Comments: The first 23 aa of osmB are a type II signal peptide.

Protein: lipoyl-dependent Cys-based peroxidase, hydroperoxide resistance; salt-shock inducible membrane protein; peroxiredoxin
Description: Lipoyl-dependent Cys-based peroxidase, hydroperoxide resistance; stress-induced peroxiredoxin; salt-shock inducible membrane protein; required for long-term survival in stationary phase
Comments: OsmC metabolizes and protects against organic hydroperoxides (Lesniak, 2003). OsmC is directly reduced by lipoylated enzymes (Cussiol, 2010). OsmC contains a conserved CxxS redox motif. Regulated by NhaR, RcsBDC, Lrp, Hns and RpoS. Nonessential gene.

Protein: oxidative and nitrosative stress transcriptional regulator
Description: Oxidative and nitrosative stress transcriptional regulator
Comments: OxyR responds to hydrogen peroxide by forming a Cys109-Cys208 disulphide bond which activates OxyR to up-regulate transcription of the oxidative stress regulon and the oxyS sRNA; OxyS then regulates expression of additional genes (Tao, 1989; Storz, 1990; Christman, 1989; Altuvia, 1997; Zheng, 1998; Lee, 2004). Both oxidized and reduced OxyR negatively auto-represses its own transcription, hence OxyR is a dual mode transcriptional regulator (Christman, 1989; Tao, 1991). During anaerobic respiration OxyR is S-nitrosylated due to nitrosative stress, activating OxyR to up-regulate genes in a distinct regulon that protect against S-nitrosothiols (Hausladen, 1996; Seth, 2012). Glutathionylation of OxyR in response to redox signaling may activate a third distinct OxyR regulon (Kim, 2002). Transcription of the catalase inhibitor protein YchF mRNA is repressed by OxyR (Wenk, 2012).

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Folic acid
Description: Sulfonamide resistance; p-aminobenzoate biosynthesis
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Folic acid
Description: Sulfonamide resistance; p-aminobenzoate biosynthesis
Comments: Null

Description: Lipoprotein associated with peptidoglycan; involved in maintaining cell membrane integrity
Comments: Cell envelope integrity is stabilized by the Tol-Pal system linking inner and outer membranes. The first 21 aa of Pal are a type II signal peptide. Pal restores the outer membrane integrity of an lpp mutant, but overproduced Lpp has no effect on a pal mutant phenotype. Mutants have elevated OM vesiculation (McBroom, 2006).

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Cations
Description: Pantothenate permease
Comments: PanF is a symporter.

Description: Topoisomerase IV, subunit A, ATP-dependent, type II; chromosome decatenase; relaxes both positive and negative supercoils; DNA unknotting activity; heterotetrameric
Comments: parC is an essential gene (Kato, 1990). The parC mutants in the Keio collection have been shown to harbor an intact copy of parC in addition to the deletion allele (Yamamoto, 2009). ParC physically interacts with SeqA; Topo IV is stimulated by SeqA (Kang, 2003).

Description: Topoisomerase IV, subunit B, ATP-dependent, type II; chromosome decatenase; relaxes positive supercoils much faster than negative supercoils; DNA unknotting activity; heterotetrameric
Comments: Topo IV is stimulated by SeqA.

Description: Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase [ATP]
Comments: The yhgE-pck divergent promoter region binds ArcA (Federowicz, 2014).

Description: Protein-L-isoaspartate O-methyltransferase, SAM-dependent; repair of isoaspartyl residues; mutant is suseptible to secondary stresses and has a competitive disadvantage in stationary phase; monomeric; overexpression confers tolerance to thermal str
Comments: Pcm may work with SurE: they are co-transcribed and have addictive effects on isoaspartyl accumulation during stationary phase. Pcm was originally thought to be required for stationary phase and heat-stress survival, but this was due to a secondary rpoS mutation. otherPDB (P. furiosus): 1JG1.

Function: Enzyme; RNA synthesis, modification, DNA transcription
Description: Poly(A) polymerase; controls plasmid copy number; rare AUU start codon, growth-rate regulated; monomeric; degradosome component in stationary phase
Comments: AUU start proven by mutagenesis analysis. PcnB can polyadenylate many mRNAs and it is proposed that Rho-independent transcription terminators serve as polyadenylation signals (Mohanty, 2006). The first 10 amino acids of PcnB are processed off by an unknown protease (Cao, 1992). RssB(SprE) is required to maintain the association of PcnB with the degradosome during stationary phase (Carabetta, 2010).

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Pyridoxine
Description: 4-hydroxythreonine-4-phosphate dehydrogenase; fourth step in pyridoxal 5-phosphate biosynthesis; isoniazid resistance; requires divalent cations and NAD(P)+
Comments: Converts 4-hydroxy-L-threonine phosphate (HTP) to 3-amino-2-oxopropyl phosphate. pdxA is a multi-copy suppressor of a pdxB deletion (Kim, 2010).

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Pyridoxine
Description: 2-hydroxyacid dehydrogenase involved in pyridoxine biosynthesis upstream of 4-phospho-hydroxy-threonine; isoniazid resistance
Comments: pdxA, aroB, thrB, nudL(yeaB), hisB, php, and yjbQ were identified as multi-copy suppressors of a pdxB deletion (Kim, 2010).

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Pyridoxine
Description: Pyridoxine 5'-phosphate (PNP) synthase; homo-octamer
Comments: Null

Protein: multifunctional aminopeptidase A: a cyteinylglycinase, transcription regulator and site-specific recombination factor
Function: Enzyme; Degradation of proteins, peptides, glyco
Description: Multifunctional Aminopeptidase A; transcriptional regulator of carAB; DNA-binding role in site-specific recombination mediating ColE1 plasmid multimer resolution; homohexameric
Comments: PepA has a broad specificity for successive removal of many N-terminal amino acids, although leucine is preferred as the residue N-terminal to the cleavage site.

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of proteins, peptides, glyco
Description: Peptidase D, Xaa-His dipeptidase
Comments: CsgD regulon, repressed. HT_Cmplx19_Cyt: PepD+Pgm+Zwf. HT_Cmplx41_Mem: Gnd+PepD.

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of proteins, peptides, glyco
Description: Aminopeptidase N
Comments: The pepN-pncB diverent operon promoter region binds ArcA and ArcA represses pepN expression (Federowicz, 2014).

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of proteins, peptides, glyco
Description: Proline aminopeptidase, homotetrameric; aminopeptidase P
Comments: Overexpression causes abnormal biofilm architecture. Mutants have reduced OM vesiculation (McBroom, 2006).

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of proteins, peptides, glyco
Description: Proline dipeptidase; prolidase; Xaa-Pro dipeptidase
Comments: 3/1146 PepQ peptide masses from MS analysis are consistent with this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is removed, but the second residue is Asp which usually precludes cleavage by methionine aminopeptidase (Maillet, 2007).

Description: 6-phosphofructokinase-1; allosteric: activated by MgNDPs, inhibited by PEP; homoterameric
Comments: Null

Description: 6-phosphofructokinase-2; homotetrameric; allosteric: inhibited by MgATP
Comments: A promoter activation mutation increases expression and suppresses pfkA mutations.

Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: Anaerobic respiration
Description: Formate C-acetyltransferase 1; pyruvate formate-lyase 1; induced anaerobically; radical activated by PflA; deactivated by AdhE
Comments: PflB lysines K63, K107, K117, K124, K195, K454, K467 and K654 can be modified to N6-succinyllysine (Zhang, 2011). PflB lysines K63, K117, K124, K195, K454, K541 and K591 can be modified to N6-acetyllysine (Zhang, 2009). HT_Cmplx8_Cyt: GcrA(YfiD)+PflB.

Description: Glucose-6-phosphate isomerase
Comments: Pgi is also called phosphoglucose isomerase.

Description: Phosphoglycerate kinase
Comments: HT_Cmplx50_Mem: Pgk+Usg.

Description: Phosphatidylglycerophosphatase A, membrane bound
Comments: A pgpA pgpB mutant is viable and still makes phosphatidylglycerol; a pgpABC triple mutant is non-viable (Lu, 2011).

Description: Phosphatidylglycerophosphatase B, membrane bound; minor undecaprenyl pyrophosphate phosphatase (UppP) activity
Comments: A pgpA pgpB mutant is viable and still makes phosphatidylglycerol; a pgpA pgpB pgpC triple mutant is non-viable (Lu, 2011). The pgpB gene is nonessential, but is synthetically lethal with a bacA ybjG double mutant; all three genes encode undecaprenyl pyrophosphate phosphatase (UppP) activity, which is essential; overexpression of pgpB confers bacitracin resistance. (El-Ghachi, 2005). ybjG, pgpB, and lpxT are paralogs.

Description: Phosphatidylglycerophosphate synthase
Comments: pgsA mutants are non-motile due to elevated RpoS levels that repress flhDC transcription; pgsA3 multicopy suppressers gadW, metE and nudL(yeaB) act by increasing RpoS levels (Uchiyama, 2010). PgsA overexpression causes filamentous biofilm formation.

Protein: chorismate mutase and prephenate dehydratase, P-protein
Description: Chorismate mutase and prephenate dehydratase, P-protein; phenylalanine synthesis; FPA resistance
Comments: PheA has an N-terminal chorismate mutase domain, a central prephenate dehydratase domain and a C-terminal Phe-binding regulatory domain.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Phenylalanine-specific permease
Comments: The pheP GTG start was verified by start codon mutagenesis (Pi, 1991). pheP is in the PurR regulon (Marbach, 2012).

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Phenylalanine--tRNA ligase, alpha-subunit
Comments: HT_Cmplx7_Cyt: PheS+PheT. 5/522 PheS peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is removed (Maillet, 2007).

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Phenylalanine--tRNA ligase, beta-subunit
Comments: HT_Cmplx7_Cyt: PheS+PheT.

Description: Zinc-ribbon family protein, function unknown
Comments: phnA was originally thought to be part of the phn operon, but it has no phn phenotype (Metcalf, 1993). YjdM(PhnA) has an N-terminal Zn ribbon domain (PF08274) and a C-terminal domain of unknown function (PF03831).

Description: Metalloprotein superfamily protein, function unknown
Comments: phnB was originally thought to be part of the phn operon, but it has no phn phenotype (Metcalf, 1993). The Glo_EDI_BRP_like_8 superfamily profile (NCBI CDD cd07246) unites several metalloenzyme families including the bleomycin resistance protein, glyoxalase I, and ring-cleaving dioxygenase, although PhnB does not belong to any of theose families.

Function: Transport; Central intermediary metabolism: Phosphorus compounds
Description: Phosphonate ABC transporter ATPase; phosphonate catabolism
Comments: PhnCDE is a probable phosphonate ABC transporter; the phnE' pseudogene is defective in K-12; phosphonate utilization is cryptic in K-12. Pho regulon.

Protein: phosphonate ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein
Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Anions
Description: Phosphonate ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein; phosphonate catabolism
Comments: PhnCDE is a probable phosphonate ABC transporter; the phnE' pseudogene is defective in K-12; phosphonate utilization is cryptic in K-12. PhnD binds 2-aminoethylphosphonate and other phosphonates. The first 26 aa of PhnD are predicted to be a type I signal peptide.

Protein: putative DNA-binding transcriptional regulator of phosphonate uptake and biodegradation
Description: Phosphonate utilization, probable regulatory gene
Comments: GntR family. Pho regulon. Phosphonate utilization is cryptic in K-12.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Phosphorus compounds
Description: Ribophosphonate triphosphate synthase subunit; phosphonate catabolism
Comments: Ribophosphonate triphosphate (RPnTP; alpha-D-ribose-1-methylphosphonate-5'-triphosphate) is formed from ATP and methylphosphonate [CH(4)PO(3)] in vitro by PhnIGHL, releasing adenine; PhnI itself is a nucleosidase, suggesting it is the catalytic subunit of the PhnIGHL complex; the specific roles of PhnGHL in the ribophosphonate triphosphate synthase reaction are unknown but they may be substrate-specificity factors (Kamat, 2011). PhnG is part of a phosphonate-utilization PhnGHIJK enzyme complex (Jochimsen, 2011). Phosphonate utilization is cryptic in K-12.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Phosphorus compounds
Description: Ribophosphonate triphosphate synthase subunit; phosphonate catabolism
Comments: Ribophosphonate triphosphate (RPnTP; alpha-D-ribose-1-methylphosphonate-5'-triphosphate) is formed from ATP and methylphosphonate [CH(4)PO(3)] in vitro by PhnIGHL, releasing adenine; PhnI itself is a nucleosidase, suggesting it is the catalytic subunit of the PhnIGHL complex; the specific roles of PhnGHL in the ribophosphonate triphosphate synthase reaction are unknown but they may be substrate-specificity factors (Kamat, 2011). PhnH is part of a phosphonate-utilization PhnGHIJK enzyme complex (Jochimsen, 2011). Phosphonate utilization is cryptic in K-12.

Protein: ribophosphonate triphosphate synthase complex putative catalytic subunit
Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Phosphorus compounds
Description: Ribophosphonate triphosphate synthase complex, probable catalytic subunit; phosphonate catabolism
Comments: Ribophosphonate triphosphate (RPnTP; alpha-D-ribose-1-methylphosphonate-5'-triphosphate, also known as 5'-triphospho-alpha-d-ribosyl 1'-phosphonate) is formed from ATP and methylphosphonate [CH(4)PO(3)] in vitro by PhnIGHL, releasing adenine; PhnI itself is a nucleosidase, suggesting it is the catalytic subunit of the PhnIGHL complex (Kamat, 2011). PhnI is part of a phosphonate-utilization PhnGHIJK enzyme complex (Jochimsen, 2011). Phosphonate utilization is cryptic in K-12.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Phosphorus compounds
Description: Phosphoribosyl phosphonate carbon-phosphorus lyase; SAM-dependent; phosphonate catabolism
Comments: PhnJ is the SAM-dependent carbon-phosphorous lyase enzyme containing a [4Fe-4S] iron-sulfur cluster required for activity that cleaves the C-P bond in phosphoribosyl phosphonate (PRPn, alpha-D-ribose-1-methylphosphonate-5-phosphate) to form alpha-D-ribose-1,2-cyclic-phosphate-5-phosphate (PRcP), releasing methane, during phosphonate catabolism (Kamat, 2011). PhnJ is part of a phosphonate-utilization PhnGHIJK enzyme complex (Jochimsen, 2011). Phosphonate utilization is cryptic in K-12.

Protein: carbon-phosphorus lyase complex subunit, putative ATP transporter ATP-binding protein
Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Phosphorus compounds
Description: Putative phosphonate ABC transporter ATP-binding subunit; phosphonate catabolism
Comments: PhnK is not required for the ribophosphonate triphosphate synthase reaction (Kamat, 2011). PhnK is part of a phosphonate-utilization PhnGHIJK enzyme complex (Jochimsen, 2011). PhnK is related to ATP transporter ATP-binding subunits and may have a role in either phosphonate catbolism or transport. Phosphonate utilization is cryptic in K-12.

Protein: ribophosphonate triphosphate synthase subunit; putative ABC transporter-related ATPase
Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Phosphorus compounds
Description: Ribophosphonate triphosphate synthase subunit; phosphonate catabolism
Comments: Ribophosphonate triphosphate (RPnTP; alpha-D-ribose-1-methylphosphonate-5'-triphosphate) is formed from ATP and methylphosphonate [CH(4)PO(3)] in vitro by PhnIGHL, releasing adenine; PhnI itself is a nucleosidase, suggesting it is the catalytic subunit of the PhnIGHL complex; the specific roles of PhnGHL in the ribophosphonate triphosphate synthase reaction are unknown but they may be substrate-specificity factors (Kamat, 2011). PhnL is related to ATP transporter ATP-binding subunits and may also have a role in phosphonate transport. Phosphonate utilization is cryptic in K-12.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Phosphorus compounds
Description: Ribophosphonate triphosphate hydrolase
Comments: PhnM cleaves pyrophosphate from ribophosphonate triphosphate (RPnTP; alpha-D-ribose-1-methylphosphonate-5'-triphosphate), an intermediate in methylphosphonate catabolism, to form phosphoribosyl phosphonate (PRPn, alpha-D-ribose-1-methylphosphonate-5-phosphate) (Kamat, 2011). Phosphonate utilization is cryptic in K-12.

Function: Transport; Central intermediary metabolism: Phosphorus compounds
Description: Carbon-phosphorus lyase complex, ribose 1,5-bisphosphokinase subunit; also functions in an alternative pathway for PRPP formation
Comments: Phosphonate utilization is cryptic in K-12. ATP is the phosphoryl donor.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Phosphorus compounds
Description: Aminoalkylphosphonate N-acetyltransferase
Comments: PhnO is an aminoalkylphosphonate N-acetyltransferase whose physiological roles include detoxification of the D-alanine analog (S)-1-aminoethylphosphonate, as well as (S)-1-aminoethylphosphonate and aminomethylphosphonate catabolism (Hove-Jensen, 2012). The PhnO enzymatic activity was initially characterized in Salmonella typhimurium and is activated by a divalent cation (Errey, 2006). The Salmonella typhimurium N-terminal methionine is cleaved as determined by whole protein mass spectrometry (observed MW of 16,499 daltons) (Errey, 2006). Phosphonate utilization is cryptic in K-12. PhnO is a member of the GNAT acetyltransferase family.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Phosphorus compounds
Description: 5-phospho-alpha-D-ribosyl 1,2-cyclic phosphate phosphodiesterase; phosphonate catabolism
Comments: PhnP is a 5-phospho-alpha-D-ribosyl 1,2-cyclic phosphate phosphodiesterase, cleaving an intermediate in phosphonate catabolism (Hove-Jensen, 2011). PhnP displays 2',3'-cyclic nucleotide phosphodiesterase and bis(p-nitrophenyl)phosphate phosphodiesterase activities in vitro (Podzelinska, 2009). Phosphonate utilization is cryptic in K-12.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Phosphorus compounds
Description: Alkaline phosphatase, periplasmic; binds Zn(II); dimeric
Comments: Arg22 is removed from the mature enzyme by Iap to form isozyme 3. Isozyme 2 is a heterodimer of isozymes 1 and 3 subunits. PhoA requires the reducing environment of the periplasm and DsbA for activity; cysteine bonds C190-C200 and C308-C358 are needed. PhoA fusions are used to indicate periplasmic location of hybrid proteins.

Protein: response regulator in two-component regulatory system with PhoR
Description: Positive response regulator for pho regulon, two-component system
Comments: Null

Description: Outer membrane phosphoporin protein E; trimeric
Comments: Null

Protein: sensory histidine kinase in two-component regulatory system with CreB or PhoB
Description: Sensor kinase for CreBC regulon; induced by growth in minimal medium
Comments: CreC(PhoM) can also phosphorylate PhoB (Amemura, 1990).

Protein: response regulator in two-component regulatory system with PhoQ
Description: Response regulator, two-component system; cognate to phoQ; response to extracellular divalent cations, pH, and acetate; DNA-binding protein
Comments: PhoPQ has been primarily characterized in Salmonella, with significant differences from E. coli. Mg(2+) stimulon-PhoPQ regulon, EvgAS-PhoPQ cascade enhanced-expression subset.

Protein: sensory histidine kinase in two-component regulatory system with PhoP
Description: Histidine protein kinase sensor protein, two-component system; cognate to phoP; response to extracellular divalent cations, pH, and acetate
Comments: PhoPQ has been primarily characterized in Salmonella, with significant differences from E. coli. Mg(2+) stimulon-PhoPQ regulon, EvgAS-PhoPQ cascade enhanced-expression subset.

Protein: sensory histidine kinase in two-component regulatory system with PhoB
Description: Sensor histidine kinase/phosphatase for pho regulon; cognate to phoB
Comments: Null

Protein: phosphate ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein
Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Anions
Description: Phosphate ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein
Comments: Null

Protein: negative regulator of PhoR/PhoB two-component regulator
Description: Negative regulator of pho regulon; may have additional role in phosphate metabolism
Comments: Null

Description: Deoxyribodipyrimidine photolyase; DNA photolyase; monomeric
Comments: The flavoprotein DNA photolyase uses light to repair cyclobutylpyrimidine dimers in DNA. The lesion is flipped out of the DNA double helix. Phr contains FADH2 and 5,10-MTHF chromophores.

Description: DNA-invertase, site-specific recombination, e14 prophage
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Phosphorus compounds
Description: Outer-membrane phospholipase A; phospholipase A1; OmpLA
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Phosphorus compounds
Description: Lysophospholipase L2
Comments: Null

Description: Glycerol-3-phosphate acyltransferase
Comments: HT_Cmplx46_Mem: MdoH+PlsB.

Protein: putative antibiotic peptide MccB17 maturation peptidase
Description: Probable peptidase required for the maturation and secretion of the antibiotic peptide MccB17; involved in CcdA antidote degradation; tolerance for effects on DNA gyrase by sex factor F gene letD
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Pyridine nucleotide
Description: Nicotinate phosphoribosyltransferase
Comments: pncB is probably in the PurR regulon (weak support) (Marbach, 2012). The pepN-pncB diverent operon promoter region binds ArcA (Federowicz, 2014).

Function: Enzyme; RNA synthesis, modification, DNA transcription
Description: Polynucleotide phosphorylase; exoribonuclease; PNPase component of RNA degradosome; cold shock protein required for growth at low temperatures
Comments: Four ribonucleases, Rnc, Rnr, Pnp and Rph, redundantly process the 3' 33 nucleotides of 16S rRNA (Sulthana, 2013). PNPase activity is modulated by citrate binding (Nurmohamed, 2011). PNPase activity is modulated by c-di-GMP and PNPase is in a degradosome complexed with DosCP (Tuckerman, 2011). Cold induction occurs by reversal of post-translational autoregulation. The pnp mRNA leader is cleaved by RNase III, allowing PNPase to repress its own translation. Mutation of Gly454 impairs autogenous regulation without affecting catalytic activity. Mutants have elevated OM vesiculation (McBroom, 2006). Pnp can add long polynucleotide tails to mRNAs terminated by Rho factor (Mohanty, 2006). The overexpression of the Pnp S1 domain suppresses the cold growth defect of quadruple cspABEG mutant strain BX04 (Xia, 2001). 3/836 peptide masses from MS analysis indicate that an upstream start codon is utilized, but this contradicts N-terminal sequencing data and the upstream sequences are not conserved (Maillet, 2007). In Salmonella, a pnp mutant shows decreased expresssion of csgD, csgA and increased expression of yjcC; an nlpI mutant shows the opposite response as a pnp mutant (Rouf, 2011).

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Pool, multipurpose conversions
Description: Proton-translocating NAD(P) transhydrogenase, alpha subunit; membrane protein
Comments: PntAB couples the inward translocation of protons across the cytoplasmic membrane to the reduction of NADP+ by NADH

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Pool, multipurpose conversions
Description: Proton-translocating NAD(P) transhydrogenase, beta subunit; membrane protein
Comments: PntAB couples the inward translocation of protons across the cytoplasmic membrane to the reduction of NADP+ by NADH

Protein: 5' to 3' DNA polymerase and 3' to 5'/5' to 3' exonuclease
Description: DNA polymerase I; required for plasmid replication; translesion synthesis; synthetic lethal with ygdG
Comments: polA is an essential gene (Joyce, 1984). The polA mutants in the Keio collection have been shown to harbor an intact copy of polA in addition to the deletion allele (Yamamoto, 2009). Residues 324-928 of PolA constitute the Klenow fragment.

Description: DNA polymerase II, capable of translesion synthesis; role in the resumption of DNA synthesis after UV irradiation
Comments: Null

Protein: penicillin-binding protein 1a, murein transglycosylase and transpeptidase
Description: Murein polymerase, PBP1A; bifunctional murein transglycosylase and transpeptidase; penicillin-binding protein 1A; dimeric
Comments: LpoA binds to and stimulates PBP1A (MrcA) to synthesize more peptidoglycan (murein) (Paradis-Bleau, 2010; Typas, 2010; Young, 2010). The N-terminal transglycosylase activity polymerizes the glycan backbone and is penicillin-insensitive. The C-terminal transpeptidase activity crosslinks the muramic peptides and is penicillin-sensitive. Several phenotypes were associated with an mrcA deletion strain that inadvertantly deleted two neighboring genes, nudE(yrfE) and yrfF. One or both of these other genes turned out to be responsible for the observed mrcA-associated phenotypes. Murein polymerase is an essential function satisfied by either MrcA or MrcB. MrcA contains a PDZ domain involved in substrate recognition. MrcA is a membrane-bound periplasmic enzyme that has an uncleaved signal anchor.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Spermidine/putrescine ABC transporter ATPase
Comments: PotBCAD spermidine/putrescine ABC transport system.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Spermidine/putrescine ABC transporter permease
Comments: PotBCAD spermidine/putrescine ABC transport system.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Spermidine/putrescine ABC transporter permease
Comments: PotBCAD spermidine/putrescine ABC transport system.

Protein: spermidine/putrescine ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein
Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Spermidine/putrescine ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein
Comments: PotBCAD spermidine/putrescine ABC transport system.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Putrescine-lyase antiporter
Comments: Lack of cadBA opereon induction results in an increase in speF-potE operon expression.

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: Pyruvate oxidase
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Pool, multipurpose conversions
Description: Inorganic pyrophosphatase; binds Zn(II); homohexameric, dimer of trimers
Comments: Null

Description: Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxylase; monomeric
Comments: Mutant has reduced growth rate with little acetate excretion, decreased glucose consumption and a decreased carbon dioxide evolution rate.

Description: Peptidylprolyl-cis-trans-isomerase A, rotamase; periplasmic
Comments: Overexpression of cloned ppiA induces filamentation (Burke, 2013).

Description: Periplasmic peptidylprolyl-cis-trans-isomerase B, rotamase
Comments: An fkpA, surA, ppiB, ppiD quadruple mutant is viable (Justice, 2005). PpiB is down 6X during growth at 4C (enabled by Oleispira antarctica Cpn10/60 transgene).

Description: Phosphoenolpyruvate synthase; PEP synthase
Comments: PEP synthase is inactivated by an ADP-dependent (additional) phosphorylation of the phosphorylated active site His421 residue, a reaction mediated by PSRP(YdiA); PEP synthase is activated by a Pi-dependent pyrophosphorylase reaction also mediated by PSRP(YdiA) (Burnell, 2010).

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of proteins, peptides, glyco
Description: Periplasmic carboxy-terminal protease with specificity for non-polar C-termini
Comments: Penicillin-binding protein PBP3 is a typical Prc substrate. Prc contains a PDZ domain involved in substrate recognition. Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004).

Description: Peptide chain release factor 1, RF-1; translation termination factor recognizes UAG and UAA.
Comments: Although prfA is essential in K-12 strains, prfA can be deleted in E. coli strains with wildtype prfB function, either non-K-12 strains or K-12 strains with the repair of the presumably laboratory-acquired A246T point mutation in prfB (Johnson, 2011; Johnson, 2012; Ohtake, 2012). The K-12 prfB A246T mutation lowers the release activity of RF2 for UAA by five-fold (Uno, 1996; Dincbas-Renqvist, 2000). prfA can be deleted in MG1655 when 321 UAG stop codons are reassigned to UAA stop codons (Lajoie, 2013).

Description: Peptide chain release factor 2, RF-2; translation termination factor recognizes UGA and UAA; slightly defective allele
Comments: Although prfA is essential in K-12 strains, prfA can be deleted in E. coli strains with wildtype prfB function, either non-K-12 strains or K-12 strains with the repair of the presumably laboratory-acquired A246T point mutation in prfB (Johnson, 2011; Johnson, 2012; Ohtake, 2012). The K-12 prfB A246T mutation lowers the release activity of RF2 for UAA by five-fold (Uno, 1996; Dincbas-Renqvist, 2000). prfA can be deleted in MG1655 when 321 UAG stop codons are reassigned to UAA stop codons (Lajoie, 2013). The ribosome changes reading frame after codon 25 of the frameshifted prfB gene, an example of programmed frameshifting. The very poor growth of rluD deletion mutants in E. coli K-12 can be suppressed by a point mutation in prfB and a role in translation termination for the 23S rRNA helix 69 pseudouridines has been demonstrated (Ejby, 2007). The very poor growth of rluD deletions in all E. coli K-12 strains is due to their having a defective prfB gene with Thr246 instead of the Ala246 or Ser246 found in all other E. coli and Salmonella strains; rluD deletions have little effect on growth or stop codon recognition in a prfB Ala246 background (Uno, 1996; Din√ßbas-Renqvist, 2000; Heurgu√©-Hamard, 2002; Dreyfus, 2011; O'Connor, 2011; Schaub, 2011). The very poor growth of rluD mutants in E. coli K-12 is due to increased translational readthrough and can be suppressed by point mutations in prfB or prfC (O'Connor, 2011). The very poor growth of rluD prfB mutants in E. coli K-12 is largely due to rpsG translation readthrough (and polar effects) and can be suppressed by restoring the rpsG stop codon, which is mutated to a Leu codon in K-12, leading to a 23 aa extension of ribosomal protein S7 (Dreyfus, 2011; Schaub, 2011). prfB is essential (Kawakami, 1988). The prfB mutants in the Keio collection have been shown to harbor an intact copy of prfB in addition to the deletion allele (Yamamoto, 2009).

Description: Primosome factor Y, also called protein n'; ATP-dependent DNA helicase activity required for recA-dependent stable DNA replication mode; also involved in double-strand break repair
Comments: Null

Description: Primosomal protein n; ssDNA-binding protein
Comments: priB is a non-essential gene, but a priB priC double mutant grows poorly, indicating redundant functionality; an unusually careful approach was successfully utilized to construct the priB302 deletion without disturbing the downstream rpsR-rplI genes (Yamamoto, 2009). PriB is structurally similar to Ssb.

Description: Primosomal protein n
Comments: priC is a non-essential gene, but a priB priC double mutant grows poorly, indicating redundant functionality (Sandler, 1999).

Description: SecYEG inner membrane translocon core subunit; preprotein translocase secAYEG subunit; core translocon secYE subunit
Comments: SecYEG complex interacts with SecDFyajC to form a hexameric holocomplex. The N-terminus of SecY is blocked. Overexpression of SecY causes a decrease in the amount of biofilm formed and decreases motility.

Description: Gamma-glutamyl phosphate reductase, proline biosynthesis
Comments: Null

Description: Glutamate 5-kinase, proline biosynthesis; dimeric; feedback inhibition by proline
Comments: Contains PUA domain, required for proline-triggered aggregation.

Description: Pyrroline-5-carboxylate reductase, proline biosynthesis
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Proline--tRNA ligase
Comments: An insertion domain (248-393) in ProS is homologous to YeaK and YbaK.

Protein: glycine betaine/proline ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein
Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Glycine betaine/proline ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein
Comments: Null

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Glycine betaine/proline ABC transporter permease
Comments: Null

Protein: glycine betaine/proline ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein; cold shock protein
Description: Glycine betaine/proline ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein; cold shock protein
Comments: The cold-inducibility of proX is dependent on the presence of the pnp gene.

Description: Phosphoribosylpyrophosphate synthase
Comments: HT_Cmplx20_Cyt: Prs+RbsK.

Description: Phosphatidylserine decarboxylase, phospholipid biosynthesis
Comments: Native Psd is cleaved: residues 1-253 comprise the beta chain; the C-terminal 69 aa is the alpha chain. The N-terminal residue of the alpha subunit (Ser254) is modified to pyruvic acid, a point mutation here results in reduced proteolytic processing.

Description: Phage shock protein A, negative regulator of psp operon; stress-inducible; binds PspB and PspC; enhances protein export through Tat pathway
Comments: A pspA deletion grows slow below 8C (as enabled by transgenic Oleispira antarctica Cpn10/60). Co-expression of pspA with pspC mitigates the growth inhibition by pspC; pspA-pspC has been suggested to be a possible toxin-antitoxin pair (Brown, 2003).

Function: IS, phage, Tn; Phage-related functions and prophages
Description: Positive regulator, with PspC, activates expression of psp operon; binds PspA; membrane protein
Comments: Null

Description: Positive regulatory gene, cooperatively with PspB; facilitates binding of PspA to PspB; membrane protein; dimer
Comments: Overexpression of PspC causes abnormal biofilm architecture. Overexpression of PspC is reported to inhibit growth (Brown, 2003).

Function: IS, phage, Tn; Phage-related functions and prophages
Description: Expressed protein in psp operon; peripheral inner membrane protein
Comments: Null

Function: IS, phage, Tn; Phage-related functions and prophages
Description: Rhodanese, thiosulfate:cyanide sulfurtransferase; expressed in response to stress as part of psp operon, but also transcribed independently
Comments: Null

Description: Phosphatidylserine synthase
Comments: Null

Description: Phosphate ABC transporter permease
Comments: Topology mapped using protein fusions.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Anions
Description: Phosphate ABC transporter ATPase
Comments: Null

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Anions
Description: Phosphate ABC transporter permease
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Peptidyl-tRNA hydrolase; required for phage lambda growth
Comments: Histidine 20 acts as the catalytic base during hydrolysis.

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of proteins, peptides, glyco
Description: Protease III, periplasmic; zinc metalloprotease, protease Pi, pitrilysin; perhaps some specificity for 10 to 30 residue peptides
Comments: PqqL, PtrA and YhjJ belong to the M16 zinc metalloendopeptidase family. PtrA has two M16 protease two-domain modules, the first module has an N-terminal M16 domain (PF000675), including the HXXEH consensus active site, and a structurally homologous C-terminal M-16 inactive domain (PF05193); the second module has a highly degenerate N-terminal M16-like domain that has lost the HXXEH consensus active site and has a C-terminal M-16 inactive domain (PF05193) (K.E.R.).

Syn: car, cat, CR, glcA, tgl, umg, umgC
Protein: fused glucose-specific PTS enzymes: IIB component/IIC component
Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols

Function: Enzyme; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: PTS system histidine phosphocarrier protein HPr; phosphohistidinoprotein-hexose phosphotransferase
Comments: PtsI is autophosphorylated at His189 with the phosphate from PEP, producing pyruvate; the N-terminus of PtsI binds PtsH(HPr) and transfers the His189 phosphate group to His15 of the phosphorelay protein PtsH(HPr). PtsH(HPr) then phosphorylates and activates a variety of sugar-specific PTS system permease Enzyme IIB domains.

Protein: PEP-protein phosphotransferase of PTS system (enzyme I)

Description: Phosphoribosyl-aminoimidazole-succinocarboxamide synthase; SAICAR synthase; purine synthesis

Description: Phosphoribosylamine-glycine ligase, purine synthesis; phosphoribosylglycinamide synthase; glycinamide ribonucleotide synthase (GARS)
Comments: Null

Comments: PurE was previously thought to be the catalytic subunit of phosphoribosylaminoimidazole carboxylase, with ATPase subunit PurK (Tiedeman, 1989). PurE is a separate N-CAIR mutase (Mueller, 1994; Meyer, 1999).

Description: Amidophosphoribosyltransferase, purine synthesis; also known as glutamine 5'-phosphoribosylpyrophosphate amidotransferase, GPATase

Protein: fused DNA-binding transcriptional regulator/proline dehydrogenase/pyrroline-5-carboxylate dehydrogenase
Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Amino acids
Description: Proline dehydrogenase and repressor for the putAP divergon
Comments: PutA is a multifunctional membrane-associated flavoprotein involved in proline catabolism: the central proline dehydrogenese domain feeds its product to the C-terminal Delta(1)-pyrroline-5-carboxylate dehydrogenese domain, to produce glutamate. The N-terminal 90 residue domain is the DNA-binding repressor domain. A divergon is a regulon comprised of two adjacent divergent operons or genes. Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004).

Description: S-adenosylmethionine:tRNA ribosyltransferase-isomerase; queuosine biosynthesis
Comments: Asn, Asp, Tyr, and His tRNA anticodons are modified. QueA converts 7-deazaguanine (preQ1-tRNA) to epoxyqueuosine (oQ-tRNA) in the penultimate step of Q-tRNA biosynthesis. The final step to make Q-tRNA from oQ-tRNA may be a cobamide-dependent reduction, but the gene is unknown (Frey, 1988). tgt mutants lack queuosine and are have reduced survival in stationary phase. (Noguchi, 1982).

Comments: RbsB binds D-ribose and mediates chemotaxis to D-ribose through the Trg chemoreceptor. Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004). HT_Cmplx28_Mem: AlsB+RbsB. After four hours of Zn(II) stress, RbsB protein levels decreased (Easton, 2006).

Comments: RbsC has 10 TM helices, with the N- and C-termini in the cytoplasm.

Protein: response regulator in two-component regulatory system with RcsC and YojN
Description: Positive regulatory gene for capsule (colanic acid) synthesis
Comments: RcsB is acetylated at Lys180 by Pka(YfiQ) in vitro blocking its ability to bind to DNA, and Lys180 is deacetylated by CobB in vitro (Thao, 2010). GadE and phosphorylated RcsB form a protein complex to regulate glutamate-, arginine- and lysine-dependent acid resistance (Krin, 2010). Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004). HT_Cmplx42_Mem: RcsB+YfgM (Lasserre, 2006). YfgM may be an anti-RcsB factor (Westphal, 2012). 2/22 RcsB peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is not removed (Maillet, 2007). When RcsB is overexpressed, it reverses the ftsZ84 growth defect on low-salt medium. RcsB is required for the inducible acid resistance response (Johnson, 2011).

Protein: hybrid sensory kinase in two-component regulatory system with RcsB and YojN
Description: Negative regulatory gene for capsule (colanic acid) synthesis; contains TerF; predicted histidine kinase
Comments: Null

Syn: lexB, recH, rnmB, srf, tif, umuB, umuR, zab
Protein: DNA recombination and repair protein; ssDNA-dependent ATPase; synaptase; ssDNA and dsDNA binding protein; ATP-dependent homologous DNA strand exchanger; recombinase A; LexA autocleavage cofactor
Description: Multifunctional DNA recombination and repair protein; ssDNA-dependent ATPase; synaptase; ssDNA and dsDNA binding protein forming filaments; ATP-dependent homologous DNA strand exchanger; recombinase A; LexA autocleavage cofactor
Comments: The recA gene was initially identified by a mutation confering UV-sensitivity and causing more than a 1000-fold drop in conjugation recombination frequencies (Clark, 1965). RecA protein was initially observed as Protein X, a membrane protein induced after inhibition of cell division and DNA synthesis (Inouye, 1970). Protein X has been demonstrated to be the product of the recA gene (McEntee, 1977; Gudas, 1977; Emmerson, 1977; Little, 1977). Protein X (RecA) is transcriptionally induced by the inhibition of DNA synthesis to comprise 4% of total cell protein, 10% of which is membrane-bound (Gudas, 1976). RecA is an ATP-dependent dsDNA binding protein and is an ATP-independent, SSB-stimulated ssDNA binding protein, however the ssDNA-RecA complex is stabilized by NTPs (Gudas, 1976; McEntee, 1979; McEntee, 1981). The RecA C-terminal dsDNA binding domain contacts dsDNA at conserved residues W290, I298, G301 and K302 (Aihara, 1997). The dsDNA binding site of RecA also binds the displaced ssDNA strand (Mazin, 1998). RecA R244Q and K246N mutants are proficient in ssDNA binding but are defective in dsDNA binding (Kurumizaka, 1999). RecA does not bind to DNA with extensive cruciform structures, except in the presence of SSB. RecA-dependent autocleavage of the LexA repressor also requires ATP and DNA and signals the SOS response to DNA damage by inducing the LexA regulon. RecA-dependent autocleavage of UmuD is required for polV (UmuD'C) lesion bypass. RecA filamentation is inhibited by RecX. RecA-dependent autocleavage of phage repressors mediates prophage induction after exposure to DNA damaging agents such as UV irradiation. Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004).

Description: RecBCD Exonuclease V subunit, recombination and repair; chi-activated RecBCD recombinase subunit; RecBCD 3'-5' slow helicase subunit; contains nuclease active site and ATP-binding site; RecB alone has 3'-5' helicase activity; binds RecC
Comments: RecBCD is a bipolar helicase.

Description: RecBCD Exonuclease V subunit, recombination and repair; chi-activated RecBCD recombinase subunit; binds RecB and RecD; may confer processivity on holoenzyme
Comments: RecBCD is a bipolar helicase.

Description: RecBCD Exonuclease V subunit, recombination and repair; recD mutants are constitutively activated for recombination; RecBCD 5'-3' fast helicase subunit; RecD alone has 5'-3' helicase activity; contains ATP-binding site; binds RecC; inhibits RecA loading
Comments: RecBCD is a bipolar helicase.

Protein: Rac prophage; exonuclease VIII, 5' to 3' specific dsDNA exonuclease
Function: Enzyme; Degradation of DNA; Phage or Prophage Related
Description: RecET recombinase, exonuclease VIII, Rac prophage; recombination and repair; degrades one strand 5'-3' in duplex DNA
Comments: RecET promotes homologous recombinarion between short regions of homology, analagous to the lambda Red recombinase. sbcA suppressor mutations allow expression of recE, in some cases by fusing to the upstream racC gene.

Description: Recombination and repair; antagonizes RecX inhibition of RecA filament formation
Comments: Null

Description: Junction-specific ATP-dependent DNA helicase; facilitates branch migration of Holliday junctions; rewinding enzyme
Comments: Overexpression of RecG improves resistance to weak organic acids. recG and radC are allelic. See the ruvABC entries for additional information. otherPDB (T. maritima): 1GM5.

Description: ssDNA 5'-3' exonuclease involved in recombination
Comments: RecJ has been N-terminally sequenced, but the native RBS was not used to direct translation, so it has been removed from the Verified Set (Lovett and Kolodner, 1989). The GTG start codon has been confirmed by mutational analysis (Haggerty and Lovett, 1997). OtherPDB (T. thermophilus): 2ZXP, 2ZXO, 2ZXR.

Function: Putative enzyme; DNA - replication, repair, restriction/modification
Description: Recombination and repair
Comments: LexA regulon.

Description: Conjugational recombination and repair; DNA-binding protein; RecA-like strand assimilation
Comments: Null

Description: DNA helicase involved in recombination, replication, repair; ATP-dependent; monomeric
Comments: SSB binds to RecQ and stimulates DNA unwinding (Shereda, 2007). LexA regulon. The RecQ domain protein Psyr_3804 from Pseudomonas syringae has been identified as a toxin with the Smf domain protein Psyr_3805 as the antitoxin, although there is no indication that the E. coli RecQ/Smf form a toxin-antitoxin pair (Sberro, 2013).

Function: Putative enzyme; DNA - replication, repair, restriction/modification
Description: Recombination and DNA repair
Comments: Null

Description: ATP:GTP 3'-pyrophosphotransferase, ppGpp synthase I; GTP pyrophosphokinase; required for ppGpp synthesis during stringent response to amino acid starvation; self-regulated
Comments: RelA has two physically and functionally distinct domains, the N-terminal domain, amino acids 1 to 455, is responsible for (p)ppGpp synthesis, and the C-terminal domain, amino acids 456 to 744, is responsible for self-regulation.

Protein: antitoxin of the RelE-RelB toxin-antitoxin syste; transcriptional repressor
Function: Regulator; Global regulatory functions; Phage or Prophage Related
Description: Antitoxin for RelE, Qin prophage; transcriptional repressor of relB operon; mutants have a delayed relaxed regulation of RNA synthesis and slow recovery from starvation

Comments: The non-null mbrA4 allele of rep(mbrA) confers resistance to camphor and increases cellular DNA content (Trun, 1990; Trun, 2003). The mbrA4 allele is a synthetic lethal with rnhA (Trun, 1990).

Comments: RfaH is recruited by JUMPstart/ops sequence elements.

Comments: Flagellar regulon.

Comments: A GTG start codon 31 codons internal to the previously annotated start codon is predicted based on conservation with Salmonella, eliminating the overlap with rhaS, and having a better RBS (E. Pradel, personal communication, July, 2007).

Function: Factor; RNA synthesis, modification, DNA transcription
Description: Transcription termination factor Rho; hexameric; RNA-dependent ATPase; ATP-dependent RNA helicase; bicyclomycin target
Comments: rho has been shown to be an essential gene (Das, 1976; Bubunenko, 2007).The rho mutants in the Keio collection have been shown to harbor an intact copy of rho in addition to the deletion allele (Yamamoto, 2009).

Protein: Rhs protein with putative toxin 55 domain; putative polysaccharide synthesis/export protein; putative neighboring cell growth inhibitor
Description: Rhs protein with putative toxin 55 domain; putative polysaccharide synthesis/export protein; putative neighboring cell growth inhibitor
Comments: It has been suggested that all Rhs systems are involved in intercellular growth inhibition, suggesting that the Rhs proteins are secreted from E. coli and that the variable C-terminal domains are toxic to neighboring cells when secreted to the outside of the cell (Koskiniemi, 2013). RhsA could be cross-linked to Kps proteins in a K5+ K-12 strain; an rhsA mutant has reduced K5 polysaccharide biosynthesis in K-12 K5+ strain (McNulty, 2006). RhsA has 28 core RHS repeats including several repeats with YD dipeptides (Feulner, 1990). RhsA is a predicted polymorphic toxin that has a C-terminal conserved Toxin 55 domain that is a predicted RNase toxin (Pfam PF15606) that might be an intercellular growth inhibition module in that it also occurs in secreted bacterial insecticidal toxins and intercellular signaling proteins; the downstream yibA gene is predicted to encode an immunity gene (Zhang, 2012).

Protein: Rhs protein with DUF4329 family putative toxin domain; putative neighboring cell growth inhibitor
Description: Rhs protein with DUF4329 family putative toxin domain; putative neighboring cell growth inhibitor
Comments: It has been suggested that all Rhs systems are involved in intercellular growth inhibition, suggesting that the Rhs proteins are secreted from E. coli and that the variable C-terminal domains are toxic to neighboring cells when secreted to the outside of the cell (Koskiniemi, 2013). rhsB is predicted to encode a polymorphic toxin and the downstream gene yhhH is predicted to encode an immunity protein (Zhang, 2012).

Protein: Rhs protein with putative toxin domain; putative neighboring cell growth inhibitor
Description: Rhs protein with putative toxin domain; putative neighboring cell growth inhibitor
Comments: It has been suggested that all Rhs systems are involved in intercellular growth inhibition, suggesting that the Rhs proteins are secreted from E. coli and that the variable C-terminal domains are toxic to neighboring cells when secreted to the outside of the cell (Koskiniemi, 2013).

Protein: Rhs protein with DUF4329 family putative toxin domain; putative neighboring cell growth inhibitor
Description: Rhs protein with DUF4329 family putative toxin domain; putative neighboring cell growth inhibitor
Comments: It has been suggested that all Rhs systems are involved in intercellular growth inhibition, suggesting that the Rhs proteins are secreted from E. coli and that the variable C-terminal domains are toxic to neighboring cells when secreted to the outside of the cell (Koskiniemi, 2013). rhsD has been predicted to encode a polymorphic toxin and the downstream gene encodes YbbC, a predicted immunity protein (Zhang, 2012).

Description: Ribosomal protein S18 N-acetyltransferase; modification of 30S ribosomal subunit protein S18; acetylation of N-terminal alanine
Comments: Null

Description: Ribosomal protein S5 N-acetyltransferase; modification of 30S ribosomal subunit protein S5; acetylation of N-terminal alanine
Comments: Null

Function: Structural component; Ribosomes - maturation and modification
Description: Ribosomal protein S6 modification, C-terminal glutmate addition; polyglutamate synthase
Comments: RimK has poly-alpha-glutamic acid synthase activity in vitro, using glutamate as substrate (Kino, 2011).

Description: Ribosomal protein L7/L12 N-acetyltransferase; acetylation of N-terminal serine; microcin C and albomycin detoxifying acetyltransferase
Comments: RimL can acetylate and detoxify the peptide-nucleotide antibiotic microcin C, which is converted to an analog of aspartyl-adenylate in the cell and the antibiotic albomycin, which is converted to a seryl-thioribosyl pyrimidine in the cell (Kazakov, 2014). The acetylation of the N-terminal residue Ser-2 to N-acetylserine by RimL converts L12 to L7 (Terhorst, 1973).

Protein: septal ring protein, suppressor of prc, minor lipoprotein
Description: Septal ring protein, suppressor of prc, minor lipoprotein
Comments: RlpA from P. aeruginosa is a lytic transglycosylase (Jorgenson, 2014). RlpA is a periplasmic lipoprotein with a C-terminal SPOR domain and rlpA is in a cluster of cell wall synthesis genes. RlpA localizes to the septal ring and to foci along the cell cylinder, but rlpA mutants do not have a cell division phenotype (Gerding, 2009; Arends, 2010). The first 17 aa are a type II signal peptide.

Protein: LPS assembly OM complex LptDE, lipoprotein component
Description: LPS assembly OM complex LptDE, LPS-binding lipoprotein component
Comments: LptDE is the terminal LPS OM receptor for ABC LPS exporter complex LptBFGC; LptE binds LPS (Chng, 2010). The first 18 aa of LptE are a type II signal peptide. The LptDE structure from S. flexneri (an E. coli strain) in PDB 4Q35 differs in only 3 amino acids out of 784 for LptD and 1/175 for LptE (Qiao, 2014).

Description: RNase I, periplasmic; endoribonuclease; RNase A; RNase M; RNase T2
Comments: Null

Description: RNase III; cleaves double-stranded RNA
Comments: Four ribonucleases, Rnc, Rnr, Pnp and Rph, redundantly process the 3' 33 nucleotides of 16S rRNA (Sulthana, 2013). rnc is a non-essential gene and the failure to obtain a viable deletion mutant in the Keio collection is due to a polar effect on the downstream essential era gene (Takiff, 1989; Yu, 2000; Baba, 2006; Bubunenko, 2007).

Description: RNase D, processes tRNA precursors
Comments: Null

Description: RNase E; component of RNA degradosome; mRNA turnover; 5S and 16S RNA maturation
Comments: The degradosome is organized with a helical cytoskeletal localization (Taghbalout, 2007).

Comments: The mbrA4 allele is a synthetic lethal with rnhA (Trun, 1990).

Protein: protein C5 component of RNase P
Description: RNase P, C5 protein component; involved in tRNA and 4.5S RNA-processing
Comments: A small peptide corresponding to the translation of an ORF antisense to the rnpA-yidD overlap was detected in a shotgun MS experiment (Krug, 2013). RnpA has leadzyme properties.

Description: Pseudogene reconstruction, RNase PH
Comments: Four ribonucleases, Rnc, Rnr, Pnp and Rph, redundantly process the 3' 33 nucleotides of 16S rRNA in rph(wt) derivatives of E. coli K-12 (Sulthana, 2013). MG1655 has the rph-1 C-terminal frameshift mutation that severely reduces Rph activity. The wildtype protein sequence has been reconstructed and is presented. The rph-1 mutation is polar on the downstream pyrE gene, reducing PyrE activity and causing partial pyrimidine starvation when grown in minimal medium. The mutant protein is shorter (228 aa) and has a C-terminal sequence of ESNPL replacing GIESIVATQKAALAN. The frameshift is caused by a one base pair deletion of the first base (G) of codon 223.

Comments: RplA lysines K105, K154, K186 and K197 can be modified to N6-succinyllysine (Zhang, 2011). RplA lysine K197 can be modified to N6-acetyllysine (Yu, 2008).

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 50S ribosomal subunit protein L11; kasugamycin sensitivity
Comments: rplK is non-essential (St√∂ffler, 1980; St√∂ffler, 1981; van Dyke, 2003). rplK null mutants grow slowly, exhibiting high-temperature lethality and UAG suppression (van Dyke, 2003). The relC allele of rplK has a relaxed phenotype (Friesen, 1974; Parker, 1976). RplK has three residues trimethylated by the non-essential PrmA methyltransferase forming a blocking N-terminal N,N,N-trimethylalanine at residue A2 and forming two N6,N6,N6-trimethyllysines at residues K4 and K40 (Chang, 1975; Lederer, 1977; Dognin, 1980; Jerez, 1980; Vanet, 1994; Arnold, 1999). RplK lysines K72 and K81 can be modified to N6-succinyllysine (Zhang, 2011). Probably due to the slow growth phenotype of rplK mutations, the rplK mutants in the Keio collection have been shown to harbor an intact copy of rplK in addition to the deletion allele (Yamamoto, 2009).

Description: RNA polymerase, beta subunit; binds Zn(II)
Comments: HT_Cmplx11_Mem: RpoA+RpoB+RpoC. HT_Cmplx2_Cyt: RpoA+RpoB+RpoC.

Function: Enzyme; RNA synthesis, modification, DNA transcription
Description: RNA polymerase, beta' subunit; binds Zn(II)
Comments: HT_Cmplx11_Mem: RpoA+RpoB+RpoC. HT_Cmplx2_Cyt: RpoA+RpoB+RpoC.

Description: RNA polymerase subunit, sigma 70, initiates transcription; housekeeping sigma
Comments: rpoD is an essential gene (Nakamura, 1983). The rpoD mutants in the Keio collection have been shown to harbor an intact copy of rpoD in addition to the deletion allele (Yamamoto, 2009). The tsaD-rpsUdnaGrpoD divergent operon promoter region binds ArcA and rpsU-dnaG-rpoD operon expression is activated by ArcA (Federowicz, 2014).

Description: RNA polymerase subunit, sigma 32, heat shock transcription
Comments: RpoH is phosphorylated at Tyr-260, in HTH DNA-binding region 4.2, attenuating activity. RpoH is de-phosphorylated by Etp. rpoH can be deleted, but null mutants do not grow above 20C (Zhou, 1988). Because a deletion was not isolated, it was classified as an essential gene by Baba (2006).

Description: RNA polymerase subunit, sigma 54; needed for expression of various regulons, promoter specificity set by various activator proteins required for sigma 54 recruitment
Comments: RpoN, aslo called sigma N, was originally identified as the sigma factor for nitrogen-controlled genes. The rpoN operon contains rpoN-hpf-ptsN-yhbJ-npr.

Function: Enzyme; RNA synthesis, modification, DNA transcription
Description: RNA polymerase subunit, omega subunit; assembly factor; chaperone-like function stabilizes RNAP
Comments: Stimulates ppGpp responsiveness of RNAP in vitro. Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004).

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S1; subunit of RNA phage Q beta replicase; binds and stimulates RNAP
Comments: Coliphage Q beta replicase is comprised of the phage-encoded beta subunit and three bacterial proteins: TufB, Tsf and RpsA (Kondo, 1970; Kamen, 1970; Blumenthal, 1972; Wahba, 1974). RpsA is dispensible for RNA synthesis by coliphage Q beta replicase and is not part of the core replicase (Kamen, 1972; Hori, 1974; Landers, 1974). HT_Cmplx22_Cyt: DnaK+GrpE+GyrA+RpsA. HT_Cmplx30_Mem: ClpB+DnaK+InfB+RpsA.

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S2; binds Zn(II)
Comments: RpsB lysine K115 can be modified to N6-succinyllysine (Zhang, 2011). RpsB lysines K45 and K59 can be modified to N6-acetyllysine (Yu, 2008). rpsB is required for growth below 8C, which is enabled by transgenic Oleispira antarctica Cpn10/60. Lon substrate.

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S3
Comments: Null

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S4; NusA-like antitermination factor
Comments: RpsD can be modified by lysine acetylation in vitro using purified E. coli Pka(YfiQ) (Thao, 2010).

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S5
Comments: Null

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S6; suppressor of dnaG-Ts
Comments: RpsF is modified posttranslationally by RimK, which adds four glutamic acid residues to the RpsF C-terminus.

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S7, mutated stop codon
Comments: The rpsG gene of K-12 has a mutation converting its stop codon to a Leu codon and extending S7 by 23 amino acids (Reinbolt, 1979). The extended rpsG UGA stop codon in K-12 is poorly recognized and an rluD mutation causes a severe growth defect in K-12 due to UGA readthrough and SsrA tagging; the rluD defect is further exacerbated by a prfB mutation also specific to K-12 (Dreyfus, 2011; Schaub, 2011). HT_Cmplx17_Mem: InfC+RpsG.

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S8
Comments: Null

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S9
Comments: rpsI can be deleted, but null mutants grow slowly and express kanamycin resistance weakly (Bubunenko, 2007). Possibly because mutants grow poorly on kanamycin plates, an rpsI deletion is not present in the Keio collection, leading to its misclassification as an essential gene (Baba, 2006).

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S10
Comments: Null

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S11
Comments: Null

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S12; RNA chaperone
Comments: RimO catalyzes the methylthiolation of Asp-89 of ribosomal protein S12 to form 3-methylthioaspartic acid (Kowalak, 1996; Anton, 2008). YcaO is required for the efficient in vivo RimO-dependent beta-methylthiolation of ribosomal protein S12 (RpsL) on Asp-89 (Strader, 2011). Asp-88 of the mature RpsL is Asp-89 of the unmodified protein. RpsL lysine K108 can be modifed to N6-acetyllysine (Zhang, 2009). Mutations in regions 41-45 (except when Lys42 is replaced with Arg), 87-93 and 53 result in streptomycin resistance. A point mutation at basepair 262 from A to G sustains protein synthesis in late stationary phase and increases the stability of the 70S complex in low magnesium concentrations.

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S13
Comments: rpsM can be deleted, but null mutants grow slowly and express kanamycin resistance weakly (Bubunenko, 2007), which may explain why a deletion was not isolated by Baba (2006), leading to its misclassification as an essential gene.

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S14
Comments: Null

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S15
Comments: rpsO can be deleted, but null mutants grow slowly (Bubunenko, 2007). Probably due to the slow growth phenotype of rpsO mutations, the rpsO mutants in the Keio collection have been shown to harbor an intact copy of rpsO in addition to the deletion allele (Yamamoto, 2009).

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S16; endonuclease
Comments: Null

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S17
Comments: rpsQ can be deleted, but null mutants grow slowly and express kanamycin resistance weakly (Bubunenko, 2007), which may explain why a deletion was not isolated by Baba (2006), leading to its misclassification as an essential gene.

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S18
Comments: Null

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S19
Comments: Null

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S20
Comments: Null

Function: Structural component; Ribosomal proteins - synthesis, modification
Description: 30S ribosomal subunit protein S21
Comments: rpsU has been shown to be an essential gene (Bubunenko, 2007). The rpsU mutants in the Keio collection have been shown to harbor an intact copy of rpsU in addition to the deletion alelle (Yamamoto, 2009). The tsaD-rpsUdnaGrpoD divergent operon promoter region binds ArcA and rpsU-dnaG-rpoD operon expression is activated by ArcA (Federowicz, 2014).

Function: Carrier; Transport of small molecules: Cations
Description: Ferritin, major cytoplasmic iron storage protein
Comments: FtnA helps re-assemble iron-sulfur clusters after oxidative damage (Bitoun, 2008).

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Pantothenate
Description: Pantothenate kinase
Comments: coaA is an essential gene (Vallari, 1987). The coaA mutants in the Keio collection have been shown to harbor an intact copy of coaA in addition to the deletion allele (Yamamoto, 2009).

Protein: component of RuvABC resolvasome, regulatory subunit
Description: Holliday junction recognition factor, recruits RuvB; works in conjunction with RuvB helicase to drive branch migration during recombination
Comments: Binds Holliday junction as two tetramers (an octamer) and each tetrameric half recruits one RuvB hexameric helicase. RuvAB may also directly convert replication forks into Holliday junctions. Required for replication forks reversal in certain replication mutants. LexA regulon. RuvA may be a sliding collar that protects Holliday junctions from unwinding while promoting branch migration

Protein: ATP-dependent DNA helicase, component of RuvABC resolvasome
Description: DNA helicase driving branch migration during recombination; hexameric ring
Comments: May directly convert replication forks into Holliday junctions. Required for replication forks reversal in certain replication mutants. ATP-dependent. LexA regulon.

Description: RuvC endonuclease, Holliday structure resolvase; not SOS regulated
Comments: Null

Description: Exodeoxyribonuclease I, exonuclease I, suppressor of recBC
Comments: The sbcB gene encodes exonuclease I (Kushner, 1971). The C-terminus of Ssb binds and stimulates Exonuclease I activity (Lu, 2008).

Description: DNA hairpin dsDNA 3'-exonuclease SbcCD, Mn(2+), ATP-dependent; ATP-independent 5' ssDNA endonuclease; required for recombinational repair of dsDNA breaks; cosuppressor with sbcB of recB recC mutations; heterodimeric
Comments: SbcCD can cleave dsDNA 5' ends sealed by a hairpin or by covalent linko a protein. SbcCD limits recombination between short inverted repeats, but is also reported to be required for palindrome-stimulated deletion. SbcCD protein forms a large 1.2 megadalton complex. Second amino acid was sequenced in protein as Gly, but in all DNA samples is a Lys codon. SbcC is a coiled coil protein.

Description: Peptide antibiotic transporter
Comments: SbmA is an inner membrane transporter that imports and confers sensitivity to microcin 25 (Salom√≥n, 1995). sbmA mutants are resistant to microcin B17 (Lavi√±a, 1986). sbmA mutants are resistant to the proline-rich antimicrobial peptide pyrrhocoricin (Narayanan, 2014). SbmA mediates the import of peptide nucleic acid (PNA) oligomers into the cytoplasm (Ghosal, 2013).

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Anions
Description: Sulfate-binding protein, periplasmic
Comments: Sbp is part of the CysAWUP-Sbp ABC transporter, also known as CysAWTP. CysP is the periplasmic binding protein for thiosulfate, but genetic evidence suggests that Sbp can partially compensate for a loss of CysP.

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Amino acids
Description: L-serine dehydratase 1; also known as serine deaminase; L-SD1
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: TCA cycle
Description: Succinate dehydrogenase (SQR) flavoprotein subunit; succinate:ubiquinone oxidoreductase (SQR); complex II of aerobic respiration
Comments: The crystal structure shows that His45 of SdhA is covalently modified with FAD to form tele-8alpha-FAD histidine (Yankovskaya, 2003). E. coli SdhE(YgfY, CbtB) can complement the growth defect associated with a Serratia ygfX sdhE double mutant; Serratia SdhE was shown to bind FAD and to facilitate the flavinylation of SdhA in vitro; an E. coli sdhE(cbtB) mutant has an inactive succinate dehydrogenase (McNeil, 2012). His45 was predicted to be the site of SdhA flavinylation with FAD by similarity to the sequenced histidine-modified bovine heart flavopeptide SHTVAAXGGIBLAAGBMDEBXWR (Kenney, 1972; Wood, 1984). In vitro flavinylation of SdhA using crude extracts was stimulated by citrate, isocitrate, succinate and fumarate (Brandsch, 1989). The sdhABCD operon is negatively regulated by ryhB RNA as part of indirect positive regulation by Fur. Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004).

Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: TCA cycle
Description: Succinate dehydrogenase (SQR) iron-sulfur protein; succinate:ubiquinone oxidoreductase (SQR); complex II of aerobic respiration
Comments: The sdhABCD operon is negatively regulated by ryhB RNA as part of indirect positive regulation by Fur.

Protein: succinate dehydrogenase, membrane subunit, binds cytochrome b556
Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: TCA cycle
Description: Succinate dehydrogenase (SQR) cytochrome b556; membrane anchor; succinate:ubiquinone oxidoreductase (SQR); complex II of aerobic respiration
Comments: The sdhABCD operon is negatively regulated by ryhB RNA as part of indirect positive regulation by Fur.

Protein: succinate dehydrogenase, membrane subunit, binds cytochrome b556
Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: TCA cycle
Description: Succinate dehydrogenase (SQR) hydrophobic subunit; succinate:ubiquinone oxidoreductase (SQR); complex II of aerobic respiration
Comments: The sdhABCD operon is negatively regulated by ryhB RNA as part of indirect positive regulation by Fur.

Description: Quorum-sensing ftsQAZ-P2, acrABCDE transcriptional activator; fluoroquinolone resistance; overproduction confers drug resistance by stimulating the acr genes; SdiA senses exogenous N-acyl homoserine lactones
Comments: Suppresses inhibitory effect of the MinC/MinD division inhibitor. N-acyl homoserine lactones act as folding switches for SdiA. LuxR family. SdiA has other global transcription targets such as uvrY, csrB, recN and nei. E. coli makes an unknown weak auto-inducer when grown in rich media. Most phenotypic effects require overproduction of SdiA. sdiA mutants are more sensitive to fluoroquinolones and have reduced AcrB protein, but are not defective in cell division. An sdiA rflP(ydiV) double mutant has twofold reduced cAMP levels than inhibits quorum sensing system 2 (Zhou, 2008).

Description: Preprotein translocase secAYEG receptor/ATPase subunit; autogenous translational repressor; ATP-dependent helicase activity on secMA mRNA; homodimeric/monomeric
Comments: SecA alone can mediate protein export, albeit at low efficiency, indicating the ability of SecA to from protein-conducting channels (Hsieh, 2011). SecA binds and targets preprotein-secB complexes to the secYEG membrane-imbedded translocon, and is the translocase ATPase subunit driving proteins through the inner membrane. SecA targets protein precursors to the SecYE core translocon for secretion. The SecA helicase activity is dispensable for both functions. Oligomerization induced by signal peptides. secA is regulated by the secretion competence of the SecM signal peptide. HT_Cmplx33_Cyt: AcpP+PurB+SecA. HT_Cmplx48_Mem: SecA+YdgA+YjiY.

Description: Protein export chaperone; SecB helps SecA deliver proteins to the SecYEG translocon; general protein chaperone
Comments: The penultimate Ser residue that is missing from the purified SecB protein could be a proteolytic artifact.

Description: SecDFyajC inner membrane secretion protein complex subunit; assists the SecYEG translocon to interact with SecA and export proteins
Comments: SecYEG complex interacts with SecDFyajC to form a hexameric holocomplex. SecD is degraded by FtsH (Arends, 2016).

Description: SecYEG inner membrane translocon core subunit; preprotein translocase secAYEG subunit; core translocon secYE subunit
Comments: SecYEG complex interacts with SecDFyajC to form a hexameric holocomplex. mbrC17 is a point mutation 23 nt before secE that increases secE and nusG expression, resulting in a suppression of camphor resistance by increasing cellular DNA content (Trun, 1991; Estevenon, 1997).

Description: SecDFyajC inner membrane secretion protein complex subunit; assists the SecYE core translocon to interact with SecA and export proteins
Comments: SecYEG complex interacts with SecDFyajC to form a hexameric holocomplex.

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Selenocysteine synthase; with SelD, converts serine residue to selenocysteine on tRNA; contains pyridoxal 5-phosphate
Comments: Null

Description: Elongation factor promoting selenocysteine incorporation; specific for selenocysteyl tRNA
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Selenophosphate synthase, ATP-dependent; reduced selenium donor for selenocysteic tRNA synthesis and for the modification of several tRNAs to contain 5-methylaminomethyl-2-selenouridine
Comments: Null

Description: D-3-Phosphoglycerate dehydrogenase
Comments: Null

Description: Phosphoserine phosphatase; HAD9
Comments: HAD superfamily.

Description: Phosphoserine aminotransferase
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Serine--tRNA ligase; serine hydroxamate resistance
Comments: 8/587 SerS peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is not removed (Maillet, 2007).

Protein: malate dehydrogenase, decarboxylating, NAD-requiring; malic enzyme
Description: Malic enzyme, NAD-dependent; NAD-ME
Comments: MaeA catalyzes four reactions: I, NAD-dependent L-malate decarboxylation; II, NAD-independent oxalacetate decarboxylation; III, oxalacetate reductase, NAD-dependent; !V, pyruvate reductase, NAD-dependent. Acetyl-CoA and ATP are allosteric inhibitors; aspartate is an allosteric activator. Reaction I proceeds by two steps: dehydrogenation, then decarboxylation. 6/208 peptide masses from MS analysis indicate that an upstream start codon is utilized, but the start nine codons upstream does not have a recognizable RBS, and the upstream sequences are not conserved (Maillet, 2007).

Function: Putative regulator; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: Sugar fermentation stimulation protein A; overexpression increases maltose utilization; stimulates MalQ
Comments: Null

Description: Soluble lytic murein transglycosylase Slt70, major autolysin, periplasmic
Comments: MltB is a soluble endolytic transglycosylase and an exolytic transglycosylase that can degrade both non-crosslinked and crosslinked murein chains (Lee, 2013). Slt cleaves the glycosidic bonds between the N-acetylmuramic acid and N-acetylglucosamine residues in murein. Slt has a C-terminal lysozyme-like domain.

Protein: SMP_2 family putative membrane-anchored periplasmic protein
Description: SMP_2 family predicted membrane-anchored periplasmic protein; function unknown
Comments: YtjB(smp) is a membrane bound protein (Neuwald, 1989). YtjB(Smp) is a member of the bacterial virulence factor haemolysin family (SMP_2; Pfam PF10144). YtjB has a predicted uncleavable signal anchor (residues 13-32) and probably is largely periplasmic; a predicted second transmembrane helix (residues 164-184) indicates that the C-terminal 29 residues of YtjB(Smp) may be in the cytoplasm. ytjB is transcribed divergently from serB from overlapping promoters. YtjB(smp) is homologous to ahpA of P. multocida, which induces anaerobic expression of the cryptic hemolysin HlyE(SheA) when cloned in E. coli

Protein: lipoprotein component of BamABCDE OM biogenesis complex
Description: Lipoprotein stabilizer of BamABCDE OM biogenesis complex
Comments: bamE(smpA) mutants are sensitive to rifampin, vancomycin, cholate, and SDS/EDTA, indicating an OM defect (Sklar, 2007). A bamE(smpA) bamB double mutant is non-viable (Sklar, 2007). SmpA is homologous to P. aeruginosa lipoprotein OmlA. The first 19 aa of BamE are predicted to be a type II signal peptide. A mutation of Cys20 severely reduces bamE complementation of vancomycin resistance (Knowles, 2011). Although a direct biochemical demonstration that E. coli BamE is a lipoprotein appears to be lacking, the supporting evidence is very strong.

Description: Superoxide dismutase, Mn
Comments: SoxRS regulon. Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004). sodA mutants are sensitive to plumbagin (Lin, 2010).

Description: Superoxide dismutase, Fe; response to oxidative stress; chromate resistance; negatively regulated by ryhB RNA as part of indirect positive regulation by Fur; acid-inducible
Comments: Null

Protein: antitoxin of the SohA(PrlF)-YhaV toxin-antitoxin system
Description: Antitoxin of the PrlF-YhaV toxin-antitoxin pair; extragenic suppressor of htrA; autoregulator
Comments: Null

Protein: inner membrane protein, S49 peptidase family protein
Description: Inner membrane S49 family predicted peptidase; multicopy suppressor of degP(htrA)
Comments: SohB has one central transmembrane seqment (residues 190-207), an N-terminal periplasmic domain (PF08496, and a C-terminal cytoplasmic domain (PF01343) (Daley, 2005). SohB is homologous to inner membrane protease IV, which digests cleaved signal peptides.

Protein: redox-sensitive transcriptional activator of soxS; autorepressor
Description: Redox-sensitive transcriptional activator for soxS; AraC family
Comments: SoxR responds to redox-cycling drugs directly rather than to superoxide (Gu, 2011). SoxR activates the SoxS global regulator in a regulatory cascade; SoxR is reduced by RseC and RsxABCDGE.

Protein: superoxide response regulon transcriptional activator; autoregulator
Description: Global transcription regulator for superoxide response; AraC family
Comments: Induces sox regulon when superoxide levels increase. Induced during biofilm formation. SoxS is unstable except in a lon ftsH double mutant. This unstability is suggested to play a role in the rapid return of the regulon's gene expression to preinduced levels.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Polyamine biosynthesis
Description: Biosynthetic decarboxylase
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Polyamine biosynthesis
Description: Agmatinase; agmatine ureohydrolase
Comments: HT_Cmplx35_Cyt: DapD+SpeB. 14/140 SpeB peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is removed (Maillet, 2007).

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Polyamine biosynthesis
Description: Ornithine decarboxylase
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Polyamine biosynthesis
Description: S-adenosylmethionine decarboxylase, spermidine biosynthesis; two subunits by cleavage: residues 1-111 are the beta chain and 112-264 are the alpha chain (153 aa)
Comments: Paraquat toxicity observed in cells deficient in spermidine. The N-terminus of the SpeD alpha chain, Ser112, is modified to pyrivic acid.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Polyamine biosynthesis
Description: Spermidine synthase
Comments: Paraquat toxicity observed in cells deficient in spermidine.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Polyamine biosynthesis
Description: Ornthine decarboxylase, inducible
Comments: Lack of cadBA opereon induction results in an increase in speF-potE operon expression.

Description: Guanylate kinase
Comments: 8/66 Gmk peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is removed (Maillet, 2007).

Description: ppGpp 3'-pyrophosphohydrolase and ppGpp synthase II; guanosine-3',5'-bis(diphosphate) 3'-pyrophosphohydrolase
Comments: ObgE(CgtA) binds SpoT and pre-50S ribosomes, ObgE(CgtA) increases ppGpp degradation by pre-50S ribosome-associated SpoT, and an obgE(cgtA) mutant has an elevated ppGpp level during growth, but not during the RelA-dependent stringent response (Jiang, 2007).

Description: tRNA mG18 2'-O-methyltransferase, SAM-dependent
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of proteins, peptides, glyco
Description: Protease IV, signal peptide peptidase
Comments: The role of SppA during cleaved signal peptide degradation in vivo is unknown; an sppA mutant was unaffected in Lpp signal peptide degradation in vivo; RseP and other unidentified proteases may be the real signal peptide peptidases (Saito, 2011). SppA is a perplasmic protease anchored to the inner membrane by an N-terminal transmembrane domain that digests spent signal peptides imbedded in the inner membrane in vitro (Wang, 2008).

Protein: glucitol/sorbitol-specific enzyme IIC component of PTS
Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: D-sorbitol-specific enzyme II of phosphotransferase system
Comments: Glucitol is a less common synonym for sorbitol.
