Protein: glucitol/sorbitol-specific enzyme IIA component of PTS
Function: Enzyme; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: D-sorbitol-specific enzyme III of the phosphotransferase system
Comments: Glucitol is a less common synonym for sorbitol.

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: Sorbitol-6-phosphate dehydrogenase
Comments: Glucitol is a less common synonym for sorbitol.

Function: Regulator; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: srl operon transcriptional activator, sorbitol-responsive
Comments: Glucitol is a less common synonym for sorbitol. gutM has been changed to srlM for consistency.

Description: D-arabinose 5-phosphate isomerase
Comments: SrlQ is homologous to KpsF and KdsD. A kdsD srlQ double mutant is a synthetic lethal. 9/76 SrlQ peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is removed (Maillet, 2007). Glucitol is a less common synonym for sorbitol. gutQ has been changed to srlQ for consistency.

Function: Regulator; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: srl operon transcriptional repressor, sorbitol-inducible
Comments: Glucitol is a less common synonym for sorbitol.

Function: Enzyme; RNA synthesis, modification, DNA transcription
Description: ATP-dependent RNA helicase, 50S ribosomal subunit biogenesis; suppresses 50S ribosome assembly defect of rplX(ts); required for effiicient ribosomal 50S subunit assembly; stabilizes exposed mRNA, possibly by protecting or destabilizing secondary structure
Comments: RNA-stimulated ATPase activity and ATP-dependent RNA helciase activities have been demonstrated in vitro for SrmB (Bizebard, 2004). SrmB binds RNaseE. srmB deletion mutant has slow growth phenotype at low temperature.

Description: Single-stranded DNA-binding protein; alkali-inducible; homotetramer
Comments: RarA(MgsA) co-purifies with SSB; the DNA-dependent ATPase activity of RarA(MgsA) is inhibited by SSB (Page, 2011). SSB binds to RecQ and stimulates DNA unwinding (Shereda, 2007). Secondary structure of DNA does not effect binding of SSB. SSB increases the binding of RecA in DNA with secondary structure. LexA regulon.

Protein: stringent starvation protein A, phage P1 late gene activator, RNAP-associated acid-resistance protein, inactive glutathione S-transferase homolog
Description: Stringent starvation protein A, phage P1 late gene activator; RNAP-associated acid-resistance protein; inactive glutathione S-transferase homolog
Comments: SspA is an RNAP-associated transcriptional activator of phage P1 late genes (Ishihama, 1979; Williams, 1991; Williams, 1994; Hansen, 2003). The SspA-mediated down-regulation of H-NS is needed for stationary phase-induced acid tolerance (Hansen, 2005). OtherPDB(Y.pestis):1YY7 (Hansen, 2005). SspA lacks GST activity and does not bind glutathione (Hansen, 2005).

Description: Specificity-enhancing factor for ClpXP protease, binds ssrA-tagged proteins; ribosome-associated stress response protein; homodimeric
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: TCA cycle
Description: 2-oxoglutarate dehydrogenase, E1 component; yields succinyl-CoA and CO(2); also known as alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
Comments: sucAB is a synthetic lethal with sucCD.

Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: TCA cycle
Description: 2-oxoglutarate dehydrogenase, E2 component; dihydrolipoamide succinyltransferase; acid-inducible; yields succinyl-CoA and CO(2); also known as alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
Comments: sucAB is a synthetic lethal with sucCD. Residues 104-153 is the E3(Lpd) component binding domain, called the peripheral subunit binding domain (PSBD). When the isolated 50 aa PSBD domain is produced as a protein it is called BBL, which is structured at low temperature and may be an example of a downhill protein folding (Packman, 1986; Garcia-Mira, 2002). This controversial topic, centered around experiments with a naphthyl-alanine derivative of BBL termed Naf-BBL, has a topic page with additional citations.

Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: TCA cycle
Description: Succinyl CoA synthase beta-subunit; acid-inducible
Comments: sucCD is a synthetic lethal with sucAB. Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004). HT_Cmplx6_Cyt: SucC+SucD.

Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: TCA cycle
Description: Succinyl CoA synthase alpha-subunit
Comments: sucCD is a synthetic lethal with sucAB. SucD is down 5X during growth at 4C (enabled by Oleispira antarctica Cpn10/60 transgene). Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004). HT_Cmplx6_Cyt: SucC+SucD.

Description: Inositol-1-monophosphatase; mutation suppresses TS growth phenotype of rpoH15, dnaB121, and secY24; suhB mutations confers CS growth
Comments: The N-terminal sequence was determined using protein made with a synthetic RBS, and thus is not a confirmation of the in vivo start site; the N-terminal Met was not clipped off the recombinant protein.

Description: Inhibits cell division and ftsZ ring formation; lexA regulon
Comments: Mutants of ssrA are sensitive to mitomycin C, suppressible by sulA mutations (Shanmughapriya, 2017).

Description: Periplasmic OM porin chaperone, has PPIase activity; required for stationary-phase survival
Comments: Parvulin (ppiC) family. SurA contains two PPIase domains. PPIase domain I is inactive; PPIase activity is not required for porin maturation (Behrens, 2001). An fkpA, surA, ppiB, ppiD quadruple mutant is viable (Justice, 2005).

Description: 3-methyladenine DNA glycosylase I, contains Zn(II)
Comments: Tag is constitutively expressed.

Description: Dipeptide chemoreceptor, methyl-accepting; MCP IV; flagellar regulon
Comments: Tap sense dipeptides indirectly through the periplasmic dipeptide binding protein DppA. Tap is a low-abundance chemoreceptor, 5- 10-fold lower than Tar and Tsr. Tap can function as a cold receptor during thermotaxis. Tap senses low pH as a repellent.

Description: Aspartate, maltose chemoreceptor, methyl-accepting; MCP II; also senses repellents cobalt and nickel; flagellar regulon
Comments: Tar senses maltose indirectly through periplasmic maltose binding protein. Tar can function as a warm receptor during thermotaxis.

Function: Regulator; Degradation of small molecules: Amino acids
Description: Transcriptional activator of tdc operon
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Amino acids
Description: L-threonine dehydratase, catabolic, PLP-dependent; also known as threonine deaminase
Comments: The structure of Salmonella typhimurium TcdB has been determined (Simanshu, 2006). otherPDB: 1GN0, 1GN1, 1GN2.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Serine/threonine:H+ symport permease
Comments: HAAAP family. Anaerobically inducible.

Function: Regulator; Degradation of small molecules: Amino acids
Description: Threonine dehydratase operon activator protein
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Amino acids
Description: Threonine dehydrogenase
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Salvage of nucleosides and nucleotides
Description: Deoxythymidine kinase
Comments: Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004). 5/88 Tdk peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is removed (Maillet, 2007).

Function: Enzyme; Fatty acid and phosphatidic acid biosynthesis
Description: Acyl-CoA thioesterase 2
Comments: TesB is a member of the HotDog superfamily of thioesterases and dehydratases (Pfam CL0050, PF02551; PDB 1CBU) (Li, 2000; Dillon, 2004).

Description: tRNA-guanine transglycosylase; queuosine biosynthesis; zinc metalloprotein
Comments: Tgt forms a transient covalent linkage with the tRNA substrate. Tgt can recognize a DNA substrate when 2'-deoxyuridines replace thymidines.

Description: GTPase required for 5-methylaminomethyl-2-thiouridine modification at tRNA U34
Comments: The GTPase activity of MnmE is essential for its modification function. MnmE is required or the cmnm(5) addition to tRNA-s(2)U34, forming (with subsequent or interdependent MnmG action) cmnm(5)s(2)U34-tRNA, an intermediate in mnm(5)s(2)U34-tRNA synthesis. Mutants are hypomodified for s(2)U34 in tRNA(Lys). The carboxymethylaminomethyl donor is unknown. The MnmE-modified base U34 in tRNA is the wobble base. mnmE has proposed to be epistatic to mnmG, preceding it in the pathway (Bregeon, 2001). Yim (2000) suggest that the MnmE and MnmG activities are interdependent, not sequential. MnmG(GidA) and MnmE form a heterotetrameric complex (Yim, 2006).

Description: Bifunctional aspartokinase/homoserine dehydrogenase 1; threonine-sensitive
Comments: L-serine is a competitive inhibitor of both ThrA activities and L-threonine is an allosteric effector (Wright, 1977; Costrejean, 1977; Broglie, 1983).

Description: Homoserine kinase
Comments: thrB is a multi-copy suppressor of a pdxB deletion (Kim, 2010).

Description: Threonine synthase
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Threonine--tRNA ligase, autogenously regulated; binds Zn(II)
Comments: 30/414 ThrS peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is removed; 24/414 ThrS peptide masses match the uncleaved ThrS (Maillet, 2007).

Description: Thymidylate synthase; aminopterin, trimethoprim resistance; homodimer
Comments: Thymidylate synthase (TS) catalytic mechanism order: TS + dUMP --> TS x dUMP + (6R)-5,10-CH2-H4folate --> TS x dUMP x (6R)-5,10-CH2H4folate --> TS x dTMP x H2folate --> TS x dTMP --> TS.

Description: Trigger factor, protein folding chaperone; also peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase; interacts with nascent polypeptide chains
Comments: dnaK and tig mutants are synthetic lethal at 30 degrees C, however, no lethal effects are observed at 23 degrees C. Overproduction of GroEL/GroES at 30 degrees C suppresses synthetic lethality.

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of proteins, peptides, glyco
Description: Protease II; oligopeptidase B
Comments: Cleaves after Arg and Lys.

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Amino acids
Description: Tryptophanase, also has cysteine desulfhydrase activity; interconverts tryptophan and indole; also called L-tryptophan indole-lyase
Comments: TnaA is required for growth on tryptophan as a carbon source and indole as a tryptophan source. TnaA is a key enzyme in L-cysteine degradation. Alkali-inducible. Downregulated during cold-shock and in early exponential phase. Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004). TnaA binds plasmid colE1 sRNA Rcd, which modulates TnaA activity to regulate growth inhibition by Rcd for plasmid stabilzation (Chant, 2007).

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Tryptophan:H+ symport permease, low affinity
Comments: HAAAP family. The AroP (general aromatic) and Mtr (Trp, high affinity) permeases can also transport tryptophan.

Protein: membrane anchored protein in TolA-TolQ-TolR complex
Description: Tolerance to group A colicins, single-stranded filamentous DNA phage; required for OM integrity; membrane protein; bacteriocin tolerant
Comments: Cell envelope integrity is stabilized by the Tol-Pal system linking inner and outer membranes. Mutants have elevated OM vesiculation (McBroom, 2006).

Description: Uptake of group A colicins, mutants are tolerant to colicins E1-3, A, and K
Comments: Mutants have elevated OM vesiculation (McBroom, 2006).

Syn: colE1-i, mtcB, mukA, refI, toc, weeA
Description: Outer membrane factor (OMF) of tripartite efflux pumps; channel-tunnel spanning the outer membrane and periplasm; trimeric; ColE1 tolerance
Comments: tolC mutants grow poorly on minimal medium and have aberrant cell shapes; a normal phenotype is restored by adding iron; iron-starved tolC cells accumulate periplasmic enterobactin responsible for the growth defect (Vega, 2013). A mutant lacking ygiB, ygiC, yjfM, yjfC, and tolC has an exacerbated growth defect in mimimal medium and has increased antibiotic sensitivities relative to tolC-alone mutants; the phenotypic defects of the five gene deletion strain are complemented by a tolC plasmid; both the ygiBC and yjfMC deletions are needed to exacerbate the tolA phenotype indicating that YgiBC and YjfMC may have redundant functions; it is not known if all four genes need to be deleted to observe the tolC mutant phenotype exacerbations; tolC-ygiBC constitute an operon; the tolC growth defect on minimal medium is caused by inner membrane stress, induces PspA, and is reversible by serine (Dhamdhere, 2010). TolC, MdtQ, MdtP and CusC are paralogs.

Protein: membrane spanning protein in TolA-TolQ-TolR complex
Description: Tolerance to group A colicins and ssDNA filamentous phage; cell envelope integrity; inner membrane protein
Comments: Null

Protein: membrane spanning protein in TolA-TolQ-TolR complex
Description: Colicin import; Tolerance to group A colicins, single-stranded DNA filamentous phage; cell envelope integrity; inner membrane protein;
Comments: TolR is anchored to the inner membrane by a single TM segment and extends into the periplasm. TolR is paralogous to ExbD.

Protein: membrane spanning protein in TonB-ExbB-ExbD transport complex
Function: Membrane; Transport of small molecules: Cations
Description: Uptake of chelated Fe(2+) and cyanocobalamin; works in conjunction with OM receptors; energy transducer; sensitivity to T1, phi80, and colicins; forms a complex with ExbB and ExbD
Comments: Periplasmic TonB is attached to the cytoplasmic membrane by a signal anchor and interacts with outer membrane proteins, thus TonB spans the periplasmic space. TonB contains 40 proline residues (17%).

Description: Topoisomerase I; omega protein
Comments: Type I topoisomerase TopA relaxes DNA supercoils by nicking.

Description: Topoisomerase III; mutR phenotype is decreased deletion formation between short repeats
Comments: Null

Description: Triosephosphate isomerase
Comments: Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004).

Description: Protamine-like protein, in tyrT primary transcript
Comments: Immunoblots of chromosomal SPA-tagged Tpr showed a band the size of the 8 kd SPA tag only, indicating that if tpr is a gene, it is poorly expressed and unstable under the conditions tested (Hemm, 2008). Possibly because of deleterious effects on the neighboring tyrosyl tRNA genes, the tpr mutants in the Keio collection have been shown to harbor an intact copy of tpr in addition to the deletion allele (Yamamoto, 2009).

Description: Trehalase, periplasmic
Comments: Glycoside hydrolase family 37.

Protein: methyl-accepting chemotaxis protein III, ribose and galactose sensor receptor
Description: Ribose, galactose chemoreceptor, methyl-accepting; MCP III; flagellar regulon
Comments: Trg senses ribose and galactose indirectly through their periplasmic binding proteins. Trg is a low-abundance chemoreceptor, 5- 10-fold lower than Tar and Tsr. Trg can function as a warm receptor during thermotaxis. Trg senses low pH as an attractant and phenol as a repellent.

Protein: NAD-binding component of TrK potassium transporter
Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Cations
Description: Major constitutive K+ uptake permeases TrkAG and TrkAH; high-rate, low-affinity transport; peripheral membrane protein bound to inner membrane protein TrkG or TrkH to form active permease; binds NAD+ and NADH
Comments: Although normally required for Trk activity, overproduction of TrkG or TrkH alone increases K+ transport in a trkA mutant strain (Buurman, 2004). TrkA has two complete TrkA(RCK) domains. SapD(TrkE) is required for TrkAH activity and stimulates TrkAG transport rate (Bossemeyer, 1989; Dosch, 1991; Harms, 2001). Trk-mediated transport is driven by proton motive force, but requires a high ATP concentration for maximal activity, presumably because ATP-binding is needed to activate SapD (Harms, 2001). Anaerobically, TrkAH is proposed to form a membrane supercomplex with the F0F1 ATPase and formate-hydrogen lyase (HycB-HycE-FdhF) responsible for hydrogen gas production and 2H+/K+ exchange; thiol groups are required for this activity (Trchounian, 2000). otherPDB(V.parahaemolyticus): 4J9U; 4J9V (Cao, 2013).

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Cations; Phage or Prophage Related
Description: Major constitutive K+ uptake permease TrkAG; high-rate, low-affinity transport; K+-translocating subunit; binds TrkA to inner membrane; Rac prophage
Comments: Although normally required for Trk activity, overproduction of TrkG or TrkH alone increases K+ transport in a trkA mutant strain (Buurman, 2004). SapD(TrkE) is required for TrkAH activity and stimulates TrkAG transport rate (Bossemeyer, 1989; Dosch, 1991; Harms, 2001). TrkAG may be inactive during anaerobic growth (Trchounian, 1994). Trk-mediated transport is driven by proton motive force, but requires a high ATP concentration for maximal activity, presumably because ATP-binding is needed to activate SapD (Harms, 2001).

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Cations
Description: Major constitutive K+ uptake permease TrkAH; high-rate, low-affinity transport; K+-translocating subunit; binds TrkA to inner membrane
Comments: Although normally required for Trk activity, overproduction of TrkG or TrkH alone increases K+ transport in a trkA mutant strain (Buurman, 2004). SapD(TrkE) is required for TrkAH activity and stimulates TrkAG transport rate (Bossemeyer, 1989; Dosch, 1991; Harms, 2001). Trk-mediated transport is driven by proton motive force, but requires a high ATP concentration for maximal activity, presumably because ATP-binding is needed to activate SapD (Harms, 2001). Anaerobically, TrkAH is proposed to form a membrane supercomplex with the F0F1 ATPase and formate-hydrogen lyase (HycB-HycE-FdhF) responsible for hydrogen gas production and 2H+/K+ exchange; thiol groups are required for this activity (Trchounian, 2000). otherPDB (V. parahaemolyticus): 3PJZ (Cao, 2011). otherPDB(V.parahaemolyticus): 4J9U; 4J9V (Cao, 2013).

Protein: tRNA m(5)U54 methyltransferase, SAM-dependent; tmRNA m(5)U341 methyltransferase
Description: tRNA m(5)U54 methyltransferase, SAM-dependent; tmRNA m(5)U341 methyltransferase; RUMT
Comments: TrmA(RUMT) is a dual-specificity methyltransferase responsible for m(5)U54 modification in all tRNAs and for m(5)U341 modification in tmRNA (Zamir, 1964; Goodman, 1968; Goodman, 1970; Bj√∂rk, 1970; Bj√∂rk, 1975; Ny, 1980; Greenberg, 1980; Sprinzl, 1987; Ny, 1988; Gustafsson, 1991; Feldon, 1998; Ranaei-Siadat, 2013). The modifed ribonucleotide 5-methyluridine, referred to as ribothymidylic acid, was found to be universally present in bulk E. coli tRNA (Zamir, 1965). The position of ribothymidine at position 54 was established when the first E. coli tRNA was sequenced (Goodman, 1968). Ribothymidine was shown to be uridine modified by a methyltransferase using tritiated methionine as the in vivo methyl donor for labeling 5-methyluridine in E. coli tyrosyl tRNA (Goodman, 1970). The trmA mutation was identified, named, mapped and predicted to be the structural gene for tRNA m(5)U methyltransferase (Bj√∂rk, 1970; Bj√∂rk, 1975). The trmA gene was cloned and restriction mapped (Ny, 1980). The tRNA m(5)U54 modification is found in all sequenced E. coli tRNAs (Sprinzl, 1985; Sprinzl, 1987). The TrmA enzyme was first purified based upon its tRNA m(5)U54 methyltransferase activity (Greenberg, 1980). TrmA with a high tRNA m(5)U54 methyltransferase specific actvity was purified, characterized, N-terminally sequenced and found to co-purify with a heterogenous RNA fraction (Ny, 1988). The trmA gene and promoter region were sequenced and trmA gene expression was shown to be growth rate regulated at the level of transcription (Gustafsson, 1991). The m(5)U341 modification in tmRNA was identified and TrmA was predicted to be the responsible tmRNA modification enzyme because m(5)U341 is the tmRNA base corresponding to m(5)U54 in tRNAs (Feldon, 1998). A trmA mutant lacks the m(5)U341 modification in tmRNA (Ranaei-Siadat, 2013).

Description: tRNA m(1)G37 methyltransferase, SAM-dependent
Comments: Null

Description: Tryptophan synthase, alpha subunit
Comments: otherPDB (S. typhimurium): 1BKS.

Description: Tryptophan synthase, beta subunit
Comments: otherPDB (S. typhimurium): 1BKS.

Description: Tryptophan synthesis, bifunctional: N-(5-phosphoribosyl)anthranilate isomerase and indole-3-glycerolphosphate synthase
Comments: The first of two methionine codons is now annotated as the start site since the N-terminal MMQTVLAK TrpC peptide was detected using shotgun proteomics (Krug, 2013). The N-terminal synthase is the TrpC domain and the C-terminal isomerase domain is the TrpF domain.

Protein: fused glutamine amidotransferase (component II) of anthranilate synthase/anthranilate phosphoribosyl transferase
Description: Anthranilate synthase component II, bifunctional; glutamine amidotransferase and phosphoribosyl anthranilate transferase; tryptophan biosynthesis
Comments: Null

Description: Anthranilate synthase component I
Comments: Induced during biofilm formation.

Description: Autogenously regulated tryptophan repressor protein; regulator of trp operon, aroH, and other members of the TrpR regulon; 5-Methyltryptophan resistance
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Tryptophan--tRNA ligase
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Thioredoxin, glutaredoxin, glutathione
Description: Thioredoxin 1; Trx; with TrxB, also has general chaperone activity; processivity factor for phage T7 gene 5 DNA polymerase
Comments: Null

Description: Thioredoxin reductase, NADP+, FAD-binding; with TrxA, also has general chaperone activity; dimeric
Comments: Null

Description: Translation elongation factor EF-Ts; exchanges GDP for GTP in EF-Tu-GDP complex; binds Zn(II); subunit of RNA phage Q beta replicase
Comments: Coliphage Q beta replicase is comprised of the phage-encoded beta subunit and three bacterial proteins: TufB, Tsf and RpsA (Kondo, 1970; Kamen, 1970; Blumenthal, 1972; Wahba, 1974). RpsA is dispensible for RNA synthesis by coliphage Q beta replicase and is not part of the core replicase (Kamen, 1972; Hori, 1974; Landers, 1974). Although TufB and Tsf in the Tomita lab Q beta replicase structures are derived from strain O157:H7, their sequences are identical to the K-12 alleles (Takeshita, 2010; Takeshita, 2012). Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004). HT_Cmplx23_Cyt: FusA+Tsf+TufA. HT_Cmplx4_Cyt: Tsf+TufA.

Protein: methyl-accepting chemotaxis protein I, serine sensor receptor
Description: Serine chemoreceptor, methyl-accepting; MCP I; also senses repellents; flagellar regulon
Comments: Tsr also senses energy levels and is involved in aerotaxis, redox taxis and glycerol repellent taxis. Tsr functions as a warm receptor during thermotaxis.

Protein: nucleoside channel, receptor of phage T6 and colicin K
Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Nucleosides, purines, pyrimidines
Description: Outer membrane channel for nucleosides; receptor for phage T6 and colicin K
Comments: The first 22 aa of Tsx are predicted to be a type I signal peptide. The antibiotic albicidin enters via the Tsx channel.

Description: Translation elongation factor EF-Tu 1; GTP-dependent binding of aa-tRNA to the A-site of ribosomes; has intrinsic GTPase activity when bound to kirromycin
Comments: EF-Tu is the most abundant protein in E. coli comprising 5-10% of total cellular protein, well in excess of translational requirements (Furano, 1975; Jacobson, 1976; Neidhardt, 1977; Miyajima, 1978; Pedersen, 1978; Young, 1981; van der Meide, 1983). The only amino acid difference between TufA and TufB is the last amino acid, G394 in TufA and S394 in TufB. EF-Tu lysines K38, K177, K249, K253, K295 and K314 can be modified to N6-succinyllysine (Zhang, 2011). EF-Tu lysines K177, K188, K209 and K314 can be modified to N6-acetyllysine (Yu, 2008; Zhang, 2009). HipA binds and was reported to phosphorylate EF-Tu residue Thr-383 in vitro (Schumacher, 2009). HipA is not EF-Tu kinase (Germain, 2013). The phage P1 toxin Doc phosphorylates EF-Tu in vitro at Thr383, blocking its ability to bind aminoacylated tRNAs (Castro-Roa, 2013). EF-Tu can be modified at K57 to either N6-monomethyllysine or N6,N6-dimethyllysine; the methyltransferases responsible for these modifications are unknown (L'Italien, 1979; G.F.-L. Ames, 1979). Methylation of EF-Tu at K57 impedes GTP hydrolysis in vitro (Van Noort, 1986). Nutrient starvation promotes the conversion of N6-monomethyllysine to N6,N6-dimethyllysine at K57 in E. coli B EF-Tu (Young, 1990; Young, 1991). tufA encodes an essential function, with duplicate gene tufB, such that tufA or tufB can be deleted, but the double mutant is inviable. Coliphage Q beta replicase is comprised of the phage-encoded beta subunit and three bacterial proteins: TufB, Tsf and RpsA (Kondo, 1970; Kamen, 1970; Blumenthal, 1972; Wahba, 1974). RpsA is dispensible for RNA synthesis by coliphage Q beta replicase and is not part of the core replicase (Kamen, 1972; Hori, 1974; Landers, 1974). 50-80% of EF-Tu can be located at the cytoplasmic membrane, possibly as a result of nutrient stress, and EF-Tu may have a ribosome-independent role since it is present in at least a four-fold molar excess over ribosomes; methylation status of K57 may be related to membrane localization (Jacobson, 1976; Young, 1991). Various mutants and growth conditions have demonstrated that EF-Tu, or a precursor form pTu, can be localized to the outer membrane (Dombou, 1981; Lifson, 1986; Sedgwick, 1986). EF-Tu can form filamentous structures in vitro and has been suggested to be an actin-like cytoskeletal protein (Minkoff, 1975; Minkoff, 1976; Rosenbusch, 1976; Jacobson, 1976; Minkoff, 1977; Beck, 1978; Wurtz, 1978; Beck, 1979; Cremers, 1981; Schilstra, 1986; Helms, 1995; Helms, 1996; Norris, 2007). Although early results indicated a lack of an in vivo EF-Tu cytoskeletal structure in E. coli, subsequent experiments identified a helically organized EF-Tu-containing intracellular protofilament near the inner face of the cytoplasmic membrane with polysomes attached; it was suggested that an EF-Tu-containing cytoskeletal web might be the original prokaryotic cytoskeleton and that MreB evolved later to build upon the EF-Tu cytoplasmic network and be a cell shape determinant (Schilstra, 1984; Mayer, 2003; Mayer, 2006). In B. subtilis, EF-Tu is found in a static helical structure at the inner face of the cytoplasmic membrane co-localized with MreB; MreB and EF-Tu interact in vivo and in vitro; reduction of intracellular EF-Tu affects cell shape but not translation efficiency; EF-Tu intracellular protofilaments may serve as tracks for dynamic MreB shape-determining filaments (Defeu, 2010). HT_Cmplx23_Cyt: FusA+Tsf+TufA.HT_Cmplx4_Cyt: Tsf+TufA.

Description: Translation elongation factor EF-Tu 2; GTP-dependent binding of aa-tRNA to the A-site of ribosomes; has intrinsic GTPase activity when bound to kirromycin; subunit of RNA phage Q beta replicase
Comments: EF-Tu is the most abundant protein in E. coli comprising 5-10% of total cellular protein, well in excess of translational requirements (Furano, 1975; Jacobson, 1976; Neidhardt, 1977; Miyajima, 1978; Pedersen, 1978; Young, 1981; van der Meide, 1983). The only amino acid difference between TufA and TufB is the last amino acid, G394 in TufA and S394 in TufB. EF-Tu lysines K38, K177, K249, K253, K295 and K314 can be modified to N6-succinyllysine (Zhang, 2011). EF-Tu lysines K177, K188, K209 and K314 can be modified to N6-acetyllysine (Yu, 2008; Zhang, 2009). HipA binds and was reported to phosphorylate EF-Tu residue Thr-383 in vitro (Schumacher, 2009). HipA is not EF-Tu kinase (Germain, 2013). The phage P1 toxin Doc phosphorylates EF-Tu in vitro at Thr383, blocking its ability to bind aminoacylated tRNAs (Castro-Roa, 2013). EF-Tu can be modified at K57 to either N6-monomethyllysine or N6,N6-dimethyllysine; the methyltransferases responsible for these modifications are unknown (L'Italien, 1979; G.F.-L. Ames, 1979). Methylation of EF-Tu at K57 impedes GTP hydrolysis in vitro (Van Noort, 1986). Nutrient starvation promotes the conversion of N6-monomethyllysine to N6,N6-dimethyllysine at K57 in E. coli B EF-Tu (Young, 1990; Young, 1991). tufA encodes an essential function, with duplicate gene tufB, such that tufA or tufB can be deleted, but the double mutant is inviable. Coliphage Q beta replicase is comprised of the phage-encoded beta subunit and three bacterial proteins: TufB, Tsf and RpsA (Kondo, 1970; Kamen, 1970; Blumenthal, 1972; Wahba, 1974). RpsA is dispensible for RNA synthesis by coliphage Q beta replicase and is not part of the core replicase (Kamen, 1972; Hori, 1974; Landers, 1974). 50-80% of EF-Tu can be located at the cytoplasmic membrane, possibly as a result of nutrient stress, and EF-Tu may have a ribosome-independent role since it is present in at least a four-fold molar excess over ribosomes; methylation status of K57 may be related to membrane localization (Jacobson, 1976; Young, 1991). Various mutants and growth conditions have demonstrated that EF-Tu, or a precursor form pTu, can be localized to the outer membrane (Dombou, 1981; Lifson, 1986; Sedgwick, 1986). EF-Tu can form filamentous structures in vitro and has been suggested to be an actin-like cytoskeletal protein (Minkoff, 1975; Minkoff, 1976; Rosenbusch, 1976; Jacobson, 1976; Minkoff, 1977; Beck, 1978; Wurtz, 1978; Beck, 1979; Cremers, 1981; Schilstra, 1986; Helms, 1995; Helms, 1996; Norris, 2007). Although early results indicated a lack of an in vivo EF-Tu cytoskeletal structure in E. coli, subsequent experiments identified a helically organized EF-Tu-containing intracellular protofilament near the inner face of the cytoplasmic membrane with polysomes attached; it was suggested that an EF-Tu-containing cytoskeletal web might be the original prokaryotic cytoskeleton and that MreB evolved later to build upon the EF-Tu cytoplasmic network and be a cell shape determinant (Schilstra, 1984; Mayer, 2003; Mayer, 2006). In B. subtilis, EF-Tu is found in a static helical structure at the inner face of the cytoplasmic membrane co-localized with MreB; MreB and EF-Tu interact in vivo and in vitro; reduction of intracellular EF-Tu affects cell shape but not translation efficiency; EF-Tu intracellular protofilaments may serve as tracks for dynamic MreB shape-determining filaments (Defeu, 2010).

Protein: inhibitor of replication at Ter, DNA-binding protein
Description: DNA contrahelicase, terminus utilization substance
Comments: Site-specific DNA binding protein Tus arrests the DnaB helicase at six chromosomal Ter sites (A-F), blocking replication forks.

Description: Tyrosine synthesis: chorismate mutase/prephenate dehydrogenase
Comments: Bifunctional protein, mutase is N-terminal domain. TyrR regulon. tyrA is in the PurR regulon (Marbach, 2012). N-terminal protein sequencing identified a faint band of uncleaved precursor, indicating that some TyrA protein is not processed (Hudson, 1984). 2/904 TyrA peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is removed; 1/904 peptide masses indicate that occasionally the initial Met is not removed (Maillet, 2007).

Description: Tyrosine aminotransferase; aromatic amino acid aminotransferase; phenylalanine aminotransferase; dicarboxylic amino acid aminotransferase; homodimeric
Comments: tyrB is in the TyrR regulon.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Tyrosine:H+ symport permease
Comments: HAAAP family. TyrR regulon.

Protein: aromatic amino acid biosynthesis and transport regulon transcriptional regulator; autorepressor; ATPase; phosphatase
Function: Regulator; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: TyrR regulon repressor or activator; regulates aroF, aroG, tyrA, and aromatic amino acid transport; autoregulation of tyrR not mediated by tyrosine; ATPase activity; zinc-stimulated phosphatase activity
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Tyrosine--tRNA ligase
Comments: Null

Description: 3-octaprenyl-4-hydroxybenzoate carboxylyase; UbiD isozyme
Comments: A small 56 codon non-translated ORF overlapping the end of ubiX is erroneously annotated as a CDS feature encoding protein in various E. coli genomes, e.g. the 47 aa c2854 CDS in strain CFT073.

Function: Enzyme; Salvage of nucleosides and nucleotides
Description: Uridine phosphorylase
Comments: Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004).

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: sn-Glycerol-3-phosphate ABC transporter permease
Comments: Pho regulon.

Protein: sn-glycerol-3-phosphate ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein
Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: sn-Glycerol-3-phosphate ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein
Comments: Pho regulon.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: sn-Glycerol-3-phosphate ABC transporter ATPase
Comments: Pho regulon.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: sn-Glycerol-3-phosphate ABC transporter permease
Comments: Pho regulon.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Pool, multipurpose conversions
Description: Glycerophosphodiester phosphodiesterase; cytosolic
Comments: Pho regulon. 5/36 UgpQ peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is removed (Maillet, 2007).

Protein: response regulator in two-component regulatory system wtih UhpB
Function: Regulator; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: Response regulator of two component system required for uhpT transcription
Comments: Null

Protein: sensory histidine kinase in two-component regulatory sytem with UhpA
Function: Enzyme; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: Membrane sensor kinase protein controlling UhpA activity
Comments: Probable false positive lipoprotein prediction, Cys not conserved, 10 CM TMs predicted.

Function: Regulator; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: Glc6P transporter; membrane sensor recognizing external glucose-6-phosphate (Glc6P) and, in concert with UhpB, inducing uhpT
Comments: UhpC transporter activity is not required for sensing. Major Facilitator Superfamily (MFS).

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: Hexose phosphate permease; fosfomycin sensitivity; monomeric
Comments: UhpT exhanges cytoplasmic phosphate for hexose phosphate. UhpT also catalyzes the neutral exchange of internal and external Pi. UhpT has 12 TM regions. Major Facilitator Superfamily (MFS).

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: Beta-d-glucuronidase
Comments: UidA has an Ig-like domain: pfam PF00703 aligns to residues 182-272. ebgA, uidA and lacZ are paralogs.

Protein: translesion error-prone DNA polymerase V subunit; DNA polymerase activity
Function: Putative enzyme; DNA - replication, repair, restriction/modification
Description: Translesion DNA polymerase V subunit, DNA polymerizing subunit; error-prone repair; induced mutagenesis protein; DNA damage checkpoint effector; intrinsic AP lyase activity
Comments: Error-prone translesion DNA polymerase V is UmuD'(2)C that can bypass DNA lesions blocking DNA pol III (Tang, 1999; Reuven, 1999; Tang, 2000; Maor-Shoshani, 2000). UmuC has weak DNA polymerase activity that is greatly stimulated by UmuD' and RecA (Reuven, 1999). Uncleaved UmuD(2)C is a DNA damage checkpoint effector that can delay replication restart until it is converted into Pol V (Opperman, 1999; Murli, 2000; Ferentz, 2001). Pol V has intrinsic AP lyase activity (Chen, 2005). Pol V is a RecA-ssDNA binding protein (Frank, 1993). The RecA-ssDNA complex, a nucleoprotein filament, is required for PolV translesion bypass synthesis (Reuven, 2001). The active form of PolV is UmuD'(2)C-RecA-ATP (Jiang, 2009). Because Pol V (UmuD'(2)C) is mutagenic it is regulated by UmuD autocleavage activation to UmuD' and by Lon and ClpXP-mediated regulated degradation of UmuC, UmuD, and UmuD'; UmuD' is targeted for ClpXP-mediated degradation by the UmuD protein in the UmuDD' dimer, leaving UmuD intact; UmuD and UmuC are degraded by Lon (Frank, 1996; Gonzalez, 1998; Gonzalez, 2000). LexA regulon.

Protein: translesion error-prone DNA polymerase V subunit; RecA-activated auto-protease
Function: Putative enzyme; DNA - replication, repair, restriction/modification
Description: Translesion DNA polymerase V subunit; error-prone repair; intrinsic AP lyase activity; induced mutagenesis protein; DNA damage checkpoint effector; RecA-activated auto-protease
Comments: Error-prone translesion DNA polymerase V is UmuD'(2)C that can bypass DNA lesions blocking DNA pol III (Tang, 1999; Reuven, 1999; Tang, 2000; Maor-Shoshani, 2000). Uncleaved UmuD(2)C is a DNA damage checkpoint effector that can delay replication restart until it is converted into Pol V (Opperman, 1999; Murli, 2000; Ferentz, 2001). Pol V has intrinsic AP lyase activity (Chen, 2005). Trans-autocleavage of an UmuD homodimer subunit by the other UmuD subunit, triggered by the UmuD dimer binding to a ssDNA-RecA complex, removes the first 24 amino acids to form UmuD' which is required for mutageneic translesion synthesis (TLS) (Shinagawa, 1988; Nohmi, 1988; Burckhardt, 1988; Shiba, 1990; Woodgate, 1991; Bailone, 1991; Lee, 1996; McDonald, 1998; Opperman, 1999; Sutton, 2001). UmuD and UmuD' are intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) that can nonetheless form stable dimers (Simon, 2008). Pol V is a RecA-ssDNA binding protein (Frank, 1993). The RecA-ssDNA complex, a nucleoprotein filament, is required for PolV translesion bypass synthesis (Reuven, 2001). The active form of PolV is UmuD'(2)C-RecA-ATP (Jiang, 2009). Because Pol V (UmuD'(2)C) is mutagenic it is regulated by UmuD autocleavage activation to UmuD' and by Lon and ClpXP-mediated regulated degradation of UmuC, UmuD, and UmuD'; UmuD' is targeted for ClpXP-mediated degradation by the UmuD protein in the UmuDD' dimer, leaving UmuD intact; UmuD and UmuC are degraded by Lon (Frank, 1996; Gonzalez, 1998; Gonzalez, 2000). LexA regulon.

Description: Uracil-DNA glycosylase; UDG excises uracil from DNA by base flipping mechanism; prefers ssDNA over dsDNA
Comments: UDG and Ndk form a complex (Goswami, 2006). UDG binds SSB C-terminus. CpxRA negatively regulates ung.

Description: Aspartate-semialdehyde dehydrogenase paralog, function unknown
Comments: HT_Cmplx38_Cyt: Usg+YbbN. HT_Cmplx50_Mem: Pgk+Usg.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Sugar-nucleotide biosynthesis, conversions
Description: UDP-glucose hydrolase, 5'-nucleotidase, CDP-alcohol hydrolase; also has dinucleoside-polyphosphate hydrolase activity; periplasmic and exported enzyme; monomeric
Comments: UshA has highly efficient CDP-alcohol hydrolase activity (Alves-Pereira, 2008).

Protein: ATPase and DNA damage recognition protein of nucleotide excision repair excinuclease UvrABC
Description: Excision nuclease subunit A; nucleotide excision repair of UV damage to DNA; LexA regulon; binds Zn(II)
Comments: Null

Protein: exision nuclease of nucleotide excision repair, DNA damage recognition component
Description: Excision nuclease subunit B, ATPase I and helicase II; repair of UV damage to DNA
Comments: Null

Description: Excision nuclease subunit C; repair of UV damage to DNA; multicopy causes mucoidy
Comments: Null

Syn: dar-2, dda, mutU, pdeB, rad, recL, srjC, uvr502, uvrE
Protein: DNA-dependent ATPase I and helicase II
Description: ATP-dependent 3'-5' DNA helicase II; unwinds forked DNA structures; dismantles the RecA nucleoprotein filament; increased rates of spontaneous mutagenesis; dimer
Comments: UvrD acts as a dimer in vivo (Maluf, 2003).

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: D-altronate oxidoreductase, NAD-dependent; galacturonate branch of hexuronate pathway
Comments: ExuR regulon. MtlD, UxaB, UxuB, YdfI and YeiQ are all COG0246/PF01232 members encoding mannitol/altrunate-related sugar oxidoreductases.

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: D-mannonate dehydratase (hydrolase); Fe(2)-requiring; glucuronate branch of hexuronate pathway
Comments: UxuR regulon.

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Valine--tRNA ligase
Comments: Null

Protein: DNA mismatch endonuclease of very short patch repair
Description: Mismatch nicking endonuclease, helps repair TG mismatches
Comments: Mismatch repair minimizes the effects of C methylation.

Description: Tyrosine recombinase XerCD, resolves chromosome dimers; site-specific
Comments: XerCD acts at the Dif site.

Description: Disulfide bond isomerase, periplasmic; chaperone; activated by DsbD; homodimeric
Comments: DsbC rearranges incorrect disulfide bonds during oxidative protein folding.

Description: Tyrosine recombinase XerCD, resolves chromosome dimers; site-specific
Comments: XerCD acts at the Dif site.

Description: Exonuclease VII, large subunit
Comments: Null

Description: Exodeoxyribonuclease III and AP endodeoxyribonuclease VI; RNase H activity; DNA repair
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: D-xylose isomerase
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: D-xylulose kinase
Comments: Null

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Carbohydrates, organic acids, alcohols
Description: Xylose/H+ symporter
Comments: Major Facilitator Superfamily (MFS).

Function: Regulator; Transport of small molecules: Cations
Description: Positive regulator of nhaA, Na(+)-dependent
Comments: nhaR lacks an obvious promoter and may be expressed via nhaA readthrough. LysR family.

Description: Riboflavin kinase and FAD synthase
Comments: RibF is a bifunctional enzyme: the riboflavin kinase is the N-terminal domain; the FAD synthase is the C-terminal domain. RibF is homologous to and can substitute for the essential B. subtilis RibC. RibF is also known as protein X. The biochemical characterization of RibF described in Kitatsuji, K., S. Ishino, S. Teshiba, and M. Arimoto, 1993, Process for producing flavine nucleotides, European patent application: 0 542 240 A2. Although ribF is classified as an essential gene because a kan cassette replacement deletion could not be recombineered as part of the Keio collection, using pKO-mediated knockout technology a deletion was reportedly obtained (Arigoni, 1998). Perhaps a Keio collection kan replacement mutation could not be constructed in ribF due to polarity on the downstream essential genes ileS and lsp.

Function: Putative enzyme; Proteins - translation and modification
Description: FKBP-type peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase
Comments: Null

Description: 4-hydroxy-3-methylbut-2-enyl diphosphate reductase; last, branched, step of isopentenyl diphosphate (IPP) and dimethylallyl diphosphate (DMAPP) synthesis from 1-hydroxy-2-methyl-2-(E)-butenyl 4-diphosphate; alternative nonmevalonate (DXP) pathway for terp
Comments: The ispH gene is essential. IspH contains a [4Fe-4S] cluster. IspH affects penicillin tolerance and the stringent response. 2/42 IspH(LytB) peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is not removed (Maillet, 2007).

Description: Ribonucleoside hydrolase
Comments: Purified homodimeric RihC has the highest activity with substrates uridine, xanthosine, and inosine (Arivett, 2014).

Protein: RNA polymerase remodeling/recycling factor ATPase; RNA polymerase-associated, ATP-dependent RNA translocase
Function: Putative enzyme; RNA synthesis, modification, DNA transcription
Description: RNA polymerase-associated, ATP-dependent RNA translocase; RNA polymerase PTC complex remodeling/recycling factor ATPase
Comments: RapA stimulates RNAP recycling and PcnB-dependent RNA polyadenylation with an ATPase-dependent RNA remodeling and release from post-termination immobilized ternary RNAP-DNA-RNA complexes (PTCs) (Sukhodolets, 2001; McKinley, 2007; Shaw, 2008; Yawn, 2009; Richmond, 2011; Jin, 2011). RapA(HepA) has sequence similarity to SWI2/SNF2 helicases and binds nucleic acids, but RapA does not display RNA or DNA helicase activity in vitro (Sukhodolets, 1998). RapA has RNAP-dependent ATPase activity (Sukhodolets, 2000). rapA is downstream of polB, but is not under lexA control. The mutant phentypes may be indirect since other genes, e.g. yeeZ and aaeA(yhcQ), are downregulated in rapA(hepA) mutants (Lynch, 2007). rapA(hepA) mutant biofilms have less polysaccharide and are antibiotic sensitive (Lynch, 2007). rapA(hepA) mutants are UV sensitive.

Description: DNA-binding transcriptional repressor
Comments: MraZ is a transcriptional repressor for the mraZ promoter of the dcw gene cluster and and RNA-Seq indicates regulation of 100 genes by MraZ, including mioC for which operator binding was confirmed (Eraso, 2014).

Description: 16S rRNA m(4)C1402 methyltransferase, SAM-dependent; membrane-associated. expressed gene in dcw gene cluster; non-essential
Comments: RsmH and RsmI are responsible for the N(4), 2'-O-dimethylcytidine (m(4)Cm) modifications at position 1402 of the Escherichia coli 16S rRNA (Kimura, 2009). RsmH(MraW) was reported to also methylate membrane proteins (Carrion, 1999). At least four groups have deleted rsmH(mraW,yabC): Carrion(1999) found it to be essential for growth; Arigoni(1998) found a reduced growth rate; Dassain(1999) and Merlin(2002) found that the deletion strain grew normally. A possible explanation is that the Carrion et al. mutation might be polar on a downstream essential gene. But this defect would have to be suppressible by RsmH(MraW) overexpression. Carrion(1999) found some protein starting with the second Met which might represent an alternative initiation site. Limiting MAP, when RsmH(MraW) is overproduced, is probably not the explanation since MM- is not a MAP substrate.

Protein: membrane bound cell division leucine zipper septum protein
Description: Cell division and growth, membrane protein
Comments: The ftsL gene is essential. FtsL forms a complex with FtsB prior to mid-cell localization; this complex formation requires FtsQ, but not FtsK. Divisome.

Description: Secretion monitor controlling secA expression
Comments: Translation and secretion of SecM regulates downstream secA gene expression. The first 37 aa of SecM are predicted to be a signal peptide. The arrest sequence is 150-FXXXXWIXXXXGIRAGP-166. The arrested peptide ends with G165: P-166 encodes an arrest requirement for free Pro166-tRNA in the ribosomal peptidyl transferase A site (Muto 2006).

Function: Regulator; Energy metabolism, carbon: Pyruvate dehydrogenase
Description: Pyruvate dehydrogenase operon (pdhR-aceEF-lpd) repressor; autoregulatory; pyruvate relieves repression; monomeric
Comments: The N-terminus of overexpressed PdhR has been determined (Quail and Guest, 1995), indicating that the initial Met is removed. however, the native pdhR RBS was not used, so PdhR is not in the Verified Set, although this is probably the correct start. PdhR is a GntR-type DNA-binding transcriptional regulator.

Description: Expressed protein, function unknown, PulS_OutS family
Comments: YacC is expressed as part of the speDE operon. The first 22 aa of YacC are predicted to be a Type I signal peptide.

Description: 5'-Methylthioadenosine nucleosidase; S-adenosylhomocysteine and 5'-deoxyadenosine are also substrates
Comments: Mutants accumulate 5'-deoxyadenosine and have impaired biotin synthase activity. Required for AI-2 autoinducer synthesis in Salmonella and P. gingivalis.

Protein: fermentation-respiration switch protein; PTS Enzyme IIA(Glc)-binding protein; pNP-butyrate esterase activity
Description: Fermentation-respiration switch protein; PTS Enzyme IIAGlc-binding protein, binds unphosphorylated form; has pNP-butyrate esterase activity in vitro
Comments: An frsA mutant has increased cellular respiration on glucose; FrsA overexpression has increased fermentation rate on glucose. The FrsA N-terminus has been verified by MS, fMet is clipped (Koo, 2004). 8/228 FrsA(YafA) peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is removed (Maillet, 2007). FrsA peptide masses from MS/MS analysis indicate this is the correct start site and that the initial Met is removed (Guo, 2014).

Protein: pseudogene, sigma factor-binding protein, RNA polymerase holoenzyme formation stimulator
Description: Pseudogene, sigma factor-binding protein; stimulates RNAP holoenzyme formation; stimulates RpoS activity during stationary phase; mutants display rpoS mutant phenocopy; mutant does not have reduced amount of RpoS protein
Comments: RpoD, RpoS and RpoH sigma factor-containing holoenzyme assembly is stimulated by Crl (Gaal, 2006). Accumulation of Crl during stationary phase at 30C, but not 37C, suggests it is a thermosensor controlling sigma(S) activity. Initially identified due to reduction of RpoS-dependent curlin (csgAB) expression. The crl IS1I insertion after codon 33 creating a pseudogene in MG1655(Seq) (ATCC 700926; CGSC 7740) is a lab mutation acquired during the genome sequencing process; the parental MG1655 strain (ATCC 47076; CGSC 6300) has an intact crl gene (Freddolino, 2012).

Description: OxyR-regulated protein
Comments: Although there are no Pfam hits for YaiA there are homologs in closely related bacteria.

Description: DNA hairpin dsDNA 3'-exonuclease SbcCD, Mn(2+), ATP-dependent; ATP-independent 5' ssDNA endonuclease; cosuppressor with sbcB of recB recC mutations; heterodimeric
Comments: SbcCD can cleave dsDNA 5' ends sealed by a hairpin or by covalent linkage to a protein. SbcCD limits recombination between short inverted repeats, but is also reported to be required for palindrome-stimulated deletion. SbcCD protein forms a large 1.2 megadalton complex.

Protein: acyl carrier protein (ACP) phosphodiesterase; ACP hydrolyase
Description: Acyl carrier protein (ACP) phosphodiesterase; ACP hydrolyase
Comments: AcpH is required for turnover of the acyl carrier protein (ACP) prosthetic group 4'-phosphopanthetheine at Ser36 in vivo. Structural modeling and site-directed mutagenesis experiments indicate that the AcpH/DUF479/COG3124 family are members of the HD superfamily of metal-dependent phosphohydrolases, although lacking a usually conserved His residue (Thomas, 2006).

Description: SecDFyajC membrane secretion complex subunit; assists the SecYE translocon to interact with SecA and export proteins
Comments: YajC is found in the heterotrimeric complex SecDFYajC and in the heterotetrameric complex secDFYajC-YidC which can bind to SecYEG, and is also found as an abundant ~56 kDa homoligomeric complex (Nouwen, 2002; Stenberg, 2005).

Description: HNH nuclease family protein
Comments: Null

Description: Exonuclease VII, small subunit
Comments: The XseA start site has been confirmed by N-terminal protein sequencing and the initial Met is removed: Diaz, DL, Williams, KR, and Chase, JW, (1995) personal commnication cited in SwissProt P0A8G9.

Description: DUF1428 family protein
Comments: Null

Description: DNA-binding protein, probable nucleoid-associated protein; cloned membrane protein overexpression enhancer; homodimer
Comments: E. coli YbaB is a DNA-binding protein (Cooley, 2009). B. burgdorferi YbaB is a novel nucleoid-binding protein and global regulator of gene expression that can bend DNA and is highly expressed in rapidly growing cells but is not expressed in stationary phase (Jutras, 2012). YbaB co-expression increases the overproduction of cloned membrane proteins, especially human GPCRs (Skretas, 2010). YbaB is in the RpoE regulon (Rezuchova, 2003). YbaB can be modified by lysine acetylation in vitro using purified E. coli Pka(YfiQ) (Thao, 2010). otherPDB (H. influenzae): 1J8B.

Description: Short acyl chain and triacetyl glycerol esterase; affects maltose gene expression
Comments: S9 peptidase family.

Function: Enzyme; Salvage of nucleosides and nucleotides
Description: Inosine-guanosine kinase
Comments: Null

Description: Orphan two-component system response regulator protein; predicted DNA-binding transcriptional regulator; putative sfm operon positive regulator
Comments: Salmonella FimZ is a positve regulator of Salmonella fim operon expression (Yeh, 1995). The sfmACDHF-sfmZ genes in centisome 12 are a remnant of a region that is orthologous to the Salmonella enterica fimA[I]CDHF-fim[WY]Z convergent operons also in centisome 12; both are adjacent to the argU tRNA gene; an ancestral sfmWYZ operon was apparently disrupted by the insertion of the DLP prophage, resulting in the loss of the sfmWY genes; fimI (like E. coli fimI) and STM05551 (between fimW and fimY) are specific to Salmonella. The cognate sensor histidine kinase for SfmZ(FimZ) and the orphan response regulator FimZ in Salmonella is unknown, but evidence suggests it should exist elsewhere where on the Salmonella chromosome, and by analogy also SfmZ might have a cognate sensor elsewhere; both fimY and fimZ are needed for fim expression in Salmonella; FimW is a FimZ-interacting proteni that does not bind DNA although it appears to be distantly related to the DNA-binding response regulators (Zeiner, 2013). SfmZ(FimZ) has an N-terminal response regulator receiver domain (PF00072) and a C-terminal LuxR-type DNA-binding HTH transcriptional regulator output domain (PF00196).

Description: Enterobactin exporter, iron-regulated
Comments: EntS(YbdA) overexpression reduces intracellular arabinose, but not xylose, concentration; other compounds were not tested (Koita, 2012). Major Facilitator Superfamily (MFS). Mutations in entS have a hyperlethality phenotype when cells are stressed; EntS is a protein that reduces the lethal effects of stress (Han, 2010). In addition to its role in iron acquisition, enterobactin plays a role in oxidative stress protection and is required to form colonies on M9 minimal media aerobically (Adler, 2014).

Description: Enterobactin synthesis proofreading thioesterase
Comments: EntH corrects misacylation of the aryl carrier protein domain of EntB (Guo, 2009; Chen, 2009). EntH is a member of the HotDog superfamily of thioesterases and dehydratases (Pfam CL0050, PF03061; PDB 1VH9) (Dillon, 2004; Badger, 2005). EntH has acyl-CoA esterase activity in vitro (Kuznetsova, 2005). EntH has low level DHNA-CoA thioesterase activity but entH still mutants synthesize enterobactin (Chen, 2013). In addition to its role in iron acquisition, enterobactin plays a role in oxidative stress protection and is required to form colonies on M9 minimal media aerobically (Adler, 2014).

Description: DUF466 family protein
Comments: Paralogs cstA and yjiY are both in operons with paralogous small proteins of unknown function, ybdD and yjiX, respectively.

Description: DUF1722 family protein
Comments: Null

Protein: transcriptional repressor for the mannosyl-D-glycerate catabolic operon
Function: Regulator; Energy metabolism, carbon: TCA cycle
Description: mngAB operon repressor, mannosyl-D-glycerate utilization
Comments: MngR was originally identifed as the fatty acyl-responsive regulator FarR based on in vitro experiments; this conclusion is now in doubt based on microarray experiments (Sampaio, 2004).

Function: Enzyme; Fatty acid and phosphatidic acid biosynthesis
Description: Acyl-CoA thioesterase; possibly involved in phospholipid metabolism; binds ACP; acyl-ACP could be native substrate
Comments: YbgC-ACP forms an inner membrane complex with PssA and PlsB and is therefore presumed to be involved in phospholipid biosynthesis, possibly in the release of lipids from ACP or in the regulation of the stability or activity of the phospholipid synthetic enzymes PssA and PlsB, however a ybgC mutant did not exhibit qualitative differences in phospholipid composition (Gully, 2006). A ybgC insertion mutation has no obvious phenotype and is not polar on tolQ (Sun, 1987). It was suggested that YbgC might be DHNA-CoA thioesterase since the YbgC homolog Slr0204 of Synechocystis catalyzes DHNA-CoA hydrolysis, but it was subsequently shown that YbgC has no DHNA-CoA thioesterase activity and the real DHNA-CoA thioesterase is MenI(YdiI) (Jiang, 2010; Chen, 2013). ybgC is the first gene in the ybgC-tolQRA operon (Vianney, 1996; Muller, 1997). YbgC is not part of the Tol-Pal complex. YbgC is a low abundance protein (Fountoulakis, 1999). YbgC is a member of the hotdog superfamily of thioesterases and dehydratases (Pfam CL0050, PF03061; PDB 1S5U) (Dillon, 2004; Kim Y., Joachimiak A., Skarina T., Savchenko A., Edwards A., unpublished).

Protein: inhibitor of DNA replication, cold shock protein homolog
Description: Inhibitor of DNA replication; cold shock protein homolog, not cold shock inducible; stationary phase and starvation inducible; lethal when overproduced; persistance gene
Comments: The toxic protein CspD is regulated by the toxin-antitoxin pair MqsRA and affects the formation of persister cells (Kim, 2010).

Function: Enzyme; Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases, tRNA modification
Description: Leucyl, phenylalanyl-tRNA-protein transferase; L/F-transferase; transfers Leu or Phe to N-terminal Arg or Lys residues; required for the N-end rule degradation by ClpAP protease
Comments: Null

Protein: Modulator of FtsH protease, inner membrane protein
Description: Modulator of FtsH protease, inner membrane protein; mutant YccA stabilizes SecY(Ts), suppression requires HflKC; BAX Inhibitor-1 family protein
Comments: YccA is a native substrate for the FtsH(HflB) protease and modulates its activity for other substrates (Kihara, 1998; van Stelten, 2009). The BAX Inhibitor-1 (BI-1) family (previously called the TEGT or UPF0005 family) proteins are widely conserved; BI-1 has an anti-apoptotic function and forms a Ca(2+)-permeable channel; E. coli has three BI-1 family proteins: YccA, YbhM and YbhL (H√ºckelhoven, 2004; Bultynck, 2011).

Description: Probable subunit of cytochrome bd-II oxidase
Comments: CbdX(AppX,YccB) is a probable subunit of the cytochrome bd-II oxidase CbdAB(AppCB); CydX(YbgT) binds to CydAB and is required for full cytochrome bd-1 activity in cells; overproduced CbdX can substitute for CydX in vivo (Vanorsdel; 2013). cbdX(appX) and cydX(ybgT) are homologs.

Description: Putative rhodanese
Comments: glpE, yceA and yibN are paralogs.

Description: DUF1439 family verified lipoprotein
Comments: First 18 aa are a type II signal peptide.

Description: 23S rRNA pseudouridine(955,2504,2580) synthase
Comments: RluC is a ribosome-associated protein (Jiang, 2007).

Description: DUF177 family protein
Comments: One of the yceD mRNA starts is leaderless but can bind ribosomes (Tanaka, 1989; Brock, 2010).

Protein: e14 prophage; putative tail fiber assembly protein
Description: Predicted tail fiber assembly gene, e14 prophage
Comments: tfaE is expectd to be transcriptionally silenced in the P-element P(+) orientation (as shown) and non-functional also because its cognate stfE' gene is truncated in the P(-) orientation (Plasterk, 1984; Mehta, 2004).

Description: Acyl-CoA esterase
Comments: YciA is a member of the HotDog superfamily of thioesterases and dehydratases (Pfam CL0050, PF03061) (Dillon, 2004). YciA peptide masses from MS/MS analysis indicate this is the correct start site and that the initial Met is removed (Guo, 2014).

Description: IspA family inner membrane protein; biofilm-related protein; reduced OM production
Comments: An outcrossed yciB deletion from the Keio collection conferred reduced biofilm formation; a yciB mutant has reduced levels of outer membrane proteins OmpA, OmpC, OmpF, and LamB; a yciB rodZ(yfgA) double mutant could not be constructed indicating that this is a synthetically lethal combination (Niba, 2007). A yciB ortholog is involved in intracellular septation in Shigella and named as ispA (Hong, 1998). YciB is an intracellular septation protein A (IspA)-like protein (Pfam PF04279). The ompW-yciCB divergent operon promoter region binds FNR (Federowicz, 2014).

Description: UPF0259 family protein
Comments: The ompW-yciCB divergent operon promoter region binds FNR (Federowicz, 2014).

Description: Outer membrane protein W; colicin S4 receptor
Comments: OmpW is the colicin S4 receptor (Pilsl, 1999). OmpW is localized to the cell poles (Lai, 2004). OmpW expression is elevated by exposure to tetracycline or ampicillin (Xu, 2006). The expression of ompW is down-regulated by the RpoE-activated RybB sRNA (Johansen, 2006). FrdAB and OmpW form a complex (Huang, 2006). The ompW-yciCB divergent operon promoter region binds FNR (Federowicz, 2014).

Description: Rubrerythrin/ferritin-like putative metal-binding protein
Comments: yciGFE is transcribed using RpoS and is silenced by HNS and the H-NS silencing is reversed by transcription factor McbR(YncC) (Beraud, 2010). yciF and yciE are paralogs.

Description: Rubrerythrin/ferritin-like putative metal-binding protein; H-NS repressed; dimeric
Comments: yciGFE is transcribed using RpoS and is silenced by H-NS and the HNS silencing is reversed by transcription factor McbR(YncC) (Beraud, 2010). Protein sequencing reveals ATG at codon 3 is also utilized as a start. YciF homolog from X. axonopodis pv. passiflorae is upregulated by host plant leaf extract. Salmonella ortholog regulated by RpoS. yciF and yciE are paralogs.

Description: KGG family protein; required for swarming phenotype
Comments: ymdF and yciG are paralogs. YciG and YmdF may be related to small stress proteins (KGG family, PF10685) and appears to be regulated by RpoS. yciGFE is transcribed using RpoS and is silenced by HNS and the H-NS silencing is reversed by transcription factor McbR(YncC) (Beraud, 2010).

Protein: initiation factor function partial mimic, SUI1 family
Description: Alternative translation initiation factor; binds 30S subunit; eIF1 homolog
Comments: YciH is homologous to eukaryotic translation initiation factor eIF-1 (Cort, 1999). YciH binds 30S weakly and does not promote disassociation of subunits. YciH has some tRNA discriminatory activity in vitro. YciH also mimics some eIF1 activities in vitro.

Description: Function unknown, Qin prophage; downstream of relF gene
Comments: Null

Description: Small toxic membrane polypeptide, Qin prophage; homologous to plasmid-encoded plasmid stabilization toxins regulated by antisense RNA; functional relevance of chromosomal homologs is unknown
Comments: hokD regulatory elements are apparently deleted in K-12 and hokD is fused to relBE transcript.

Protein: Qin prophage; toxin of the RelE-RelB toxin-antitoxin system
Description: Sequence-specific mRNA endoribonuclease, Qin prophage; toxin-antitoxin (TA) pair RelEB, RelE inhibitor of translation cleaves mRNA in A site; binds to its antitoxin RelB and to ribosomes; co-repressor of relB operon transcription; stress-induced
Comments: Overproduction of RelE has been shown to increase persistence. Overexpression causes filamentous biofilm formation. Overexpression also reported to inhibit growth (Brown, 2003). Degraded by Lon protease.

Protein: PEP synthase kinase and PEP synthase pyrophosphorylase
Function: Regulatory enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Gluconeogenesis
Description: PEP synthase regulatory protein PSRP; bifunctional PEP synthase kinase, ADP-dependent, and PEP synthase pyrophosphorylase, Pi-dependent; tetrameric; DUF299 family
Comments: PEP synthase is inactivated by an ADP-dependent (additional) phosphorylation of the phosphorylated active site His421 residue, a reaction mediated by PSRP(YdiA); PEP synthase is activated by a Pi-dependent pyrophosphorylase reaction also mediated by PSRP(YdiA) (Burnell, 2010).

Description: Predicted peptidase, C40 clan, lipoprotein; putative PG hydrolase
Comments: The first 15 aa of NlpC are a type II signal peptide. Spr, NlpC, YafL and MepH(YdhO) are paralogous members of the NlpC/P60 peptidase superfamily (Pfam entry: PF00877).

Description: Predicted nitroreductase, function unknown, binds FMN; low abundance protein
Comments: Binds TrxA (Kumar, 2004). nfsA, nfsB, rutE, and ydjA are paralogs. 13/132 YdjA peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is not removed (Maillet, 2007).

Description: Pyrazinamidase/nicotinamidase
Comments: Null

Description: DUF830 family protein, function unknown
Comments: A small peptide corresponding to the translation of an antisense ORF of yebB was detected in a shotgun MS experiment (Krug, 2013). YebB, YaeF, YiiX are paralogs that are members of the NlpC superfamily (Anantharaman, 2003).

Description: Function unknown, expressed protein, UPF0082 family
Comments: A yebC mutation is one of many selected in a strain evolved for resistance to high levels of ionizing radiation; a single yebC deletion mutant has a 2-3 orders of magnitude drop in survival after radiation exposure as compared to a yebC + strain (Byrne, 2014). yeeN and yebC are paralogs. UPF0082.

Description: Dihydroneopterin triphosphate pyrophosphohydrolase; early step in folate synthesis
Comments: A nudB mutant has reduced folate synthesis (Gabelli, 2007). NudB also hydrolyzes dATP, 8-hydroxy-2'-deoxyadenosine 5'-triphosphate and 8-hydroxy-2'-deoxyadenosine 5'-diphosphate.

Description: UPF0149 family protein
Comments: YecA and YgfB are both members of the UPF0149 family of unknown function.

Protein: response regulator in two-component regulatory system with BarA
Description: Response regulator, pleiotropic; controls the expression of csrB/C sRNAs; hydrogen peroxide resistance; cognate sensor kinase is BarA
Comments: Salmonella ortholog regulates virulence gene expression. 4/29 UvrY peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is not removed (Maillet, 2007).

Protein: amino acid exporter for phenylalanine, threonine
Description: Amino acid exporter for phenylalanine, threonine
Comments: YedA overproduction enhances phenyalanine and threonine export (Livshits et al., US Patent No. 10302983, filed on 11/25/2002). YedA belongs to the EamA/RhaT transporter family, DMT superfamily.

Protein: DUF2138 family protein, putative host defense protein
Description: DUF2138 family protein, function unknown; predicted host defense protein
Comments: yfaA is in the yfaATSQP operon encoding the variant bacterial alpha2-macroglobulin family protein YfaS, leading to a prediction that YfaT is also involved in host defenses, possibly in the extracellular environment (Budd, 2004). The first 19 aa of YfaA are predicted to be a type I signal peptide.

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Menaquinone, ubiquinone
Description: SAM:OMHMB methyltransferase; Reactions: 2-octaprenyl-6-hydroxylphenol to 2-octaprenyl-6-methoxyphenol; 2-octaprenyl-3-methyl-5-hydroxy-6-methoxy-1,4-benzoquinone to ubiquinone 8
Comments: Null

Description: TauE/TSUP family inner membrane protein; function unknown
Comments: Although a wildtype strain was unaffected, a yfcA deletion mutant exhibited 40% survival after 100 minutes at 56C (Kri Ko, 2014). YfcA is a member of the sulfite exporter TauE/SafE family (PF01925) formerly known the UPF0721 family. YfcA is a member of the 4-Toluene Sulfonate Uptake Permease (TSUP) family, which is thought to contain diverse transporters and other membrane proteins; it is suggested that YfcA may be a glycerate uptake porter (Shlykov, 2012). E. coli can utilize glycerate but a transporter gene has not been identified (Umbarger, 1963).

Description: Predicted cyclic-di-GMP phosphodiesterase; dual domain protein; defective cyclase domain; predicted membrane sensor protein
Comments: YfeA has an N-terminal MASE1 transmembrane signaling domain, a defective diguanylate cyclase domain, then a C-terminal cyclic-di-GMP phosphodiesterase domain; the PDE domain has EIL instead of EAL but so does YfgF which does have c-di-GMP PDE activity.

Function: Regulator; Central intermediary metabolism: Nucleotide interconversions
Description: Regulatory gene for xapAB
Comments: LysR family.

Description: Predicted reductase, function unknown, ArsC family; low abundance protein
Comments: First gene in dapE operon

Protein: transcriptional repressor, regulatory protein accessory to GcvA
Function: Regulator; Central intermediary metabolism: Pool, multipurpose conversions
Description: Required for repression of gcv operon by GcvA; GcvA-GcvR repressor complex disrupted by glycine binding to GcvR
Comments: The structure of GcvR of Vibrio cholerae has been determined (Kumaran, D. and Swaminathan, S., unpublished). otherPDB: 1U8S. ACT-like domain (Grant, 2006).

Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: Anaerobic respiration
Description: Hydrogenase 4 component A, ferrodexin-like
Comments: Null

Protein: cold shock protein associated with 30S ribosomal subunit
Description: Protein Y, associated with 30S ribosomal subunit; inhibits 70S dimer formation; stabilizes the ribosomal 70S complex against dissociation at low magnesium ion concentrations; counteracts miscoding under stress conditions
Comments: RaiA is a ribosome-associated factor that is induced in stationary phase. The paralogous protein Hpf has opposite effect on 70S dimers.

Protein: OM lipoprotein putative positive effector of YfiN activity
Description: Putative positive effector of DgcN(YfiN) activity, OM lipoprotein
Comments: The first 18 aa of YfiB are a type II signal peptide. The P. aeruginosa yfiB ortholog encodes an outer membrane lipoprotein that counteracts the inhibitory effect of YfiR on DgcN(YfiN) diguanylate cyclase activity (Malone, 2010).

Description: Ribosome maturation factor; 30S subunit maturation factor; S19 binding protein
Comments: RimM promotes the assembly of some 3'-domain 30S proteins and stabilizes rRNA tertiary structure (Guo, 2013). rimM mutants accumulate 17S rRNA precursors but RimM is not directly involved in 16s rRNA processing (Bylund, 1997; Lovgren, 2004). other PDB (T. thermophilus): 2DOG. otherPDB (P. aeruginosa): 2F1L.

Description: Predicted prepilin peptidase-dependent DUF3728 family protein; required for swarming
Comments: The N-terminus of PpdC contains an N-terminal cleavage/methylation motif G-FXXXE (PF13544); the first 10 residues of PpdC may be cleaved by prepilin peptidase, making an N-terminal N-methylphenylalanine in the process. PpdC is the prototype for the DUF3728 family of predicted prepilin peptidase-modified proteins of unknown function (PF12528). PpdC is required for swarming motility (Inoue, 2006).

Description: DUF2509 family protein
Comments: Possible signal anchor.

Description: Predicted prepilin peptidase-dependent protein, FliA-regulated
Comments: The N-terminus of PpdB contains an N-terminal cleavage/methylation motif G-FXXXE (PF13544); the first 7 residues of PpdB may be cleaved by prepilin peptidase, making an N-terminal N-methylphenylalanine in the process. ppdB is in the flagella and motility regulon and is both FliA- and FlhDC-regulated; overexpression or deletion of ppdB does not affect motlity or chemotaxis (Park, 2001).

Description: Function unknown, Asp/Glu_racemase family
Comments: Null

Description: 5-formyltetrahydrofolate cycloligase, folinic acid catabolism; also known as 5,10-methenyltetrahydrofolate synthase (MTHFS)
Comments: Although enzyme activity has not been measured directly in E. coli, the accumulation of 5-CHO-THF (folinic acid ) in the fau(ygfA) mutant is diagnostic for 5-formyltetrahydrofolate cycloligase activity (Jeanguenin, 2010). A deletion of fau(ygfA) is sensitive to sulfonamide antifolate drugs (Ogwang, 2011). fau(ygfA) is induced during biofilm formation.

Description: Arginine exporter
Comments: LysE family. Integral membane protein. ArgP regulon.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Other
Description: Mechanosensitive channel protein, intermediate conductance; heptameric
Comments: HT_Cmplx47_Mem: MscS+YiaF. mscS, mscK(kefA), mscM(yjeP), ybiO, ybdG and ynaI are paralogs of the MscS family.

Description: Predicted PanK family P-loop kinase, function unknown
Comments: YggC and CoaA(PanK) are paralogs.

Protein: Fumarase E; MtlR family putative transcriptional repressor
Description: Fumarase E, putative transcriptional regulator
Comments: Although fumerase activiy has been demonstrated in vitro, FumE(YggD) is still predicted to be an MtlR family putative transcriptional repressor, indicating this functional assignment may be problematic (S√©vin, 2017). The FumE(YggD) crystal structure from E. coli strain S.flexneri(PDB:3C8G) has 5 mismatches to the K-12 FumE(YggD); MtlR and FumE(YggD) are paralogs (Tan, 2009).

Description: DUF1190 family protein, function unknown; helps mitigate tolC mutant defects; tolC operon
Comments: A mutant lacking ygiB, ygiC, yjfM, yjfC, and tolC has an exacerbated growth defect in mimimal medium and has increased antibiotic sensitivities relative to tolC-alone mutants; the phenotypic defects of the five gene deletion strain are complemented by a tolC plasmid; both the ygiBC and yjfMC deletions are needed to exacerbate the tolA phenotype indicating that YgiBC and YjfMC may have redundant functions; it is not known if all four genes need to be deleted to observe the tolC mutant phenotype exacerbations; tolC-ygiBC constitute an operon (Dhamdhere, 2010). YgiB was previously predicted to have a 35 aa type II signal peptide, however this prediction does not hold for the DUF1190 family; a reevaluation indicates YgiB might have either a signal anchor or a signal peptide (Gonnet, 2004).

Description: ATP-Grasp family ATPase, function unknown; helps mitigate tolC mutant defects; tolC operon
Comments: Gss, YgiC and YjfC are ATP-Grasp family proteins with ATPase activities, but only Gss has glutathionylspermidine synthase activity (Sui, 2012). YgiC and YjfC do not contain the CHAP amidase domain present in Gss. A mutant lacking ygiB, ygiC, yjfM, yjfC, and tolC has an exacerbated growth defect in mimimal medium and has increased antibiotic sensitivities relative to tolC-alone mutants; the phenotypic defects of the five gene deletion strain are complemented by a tolC plasmid; both the ygiBC and yjfMC deletions are needed to exacerbate the tolA phenotype indicating that YgiBC and YjfMC may have redundant functions; it is not known if all four genes need to be deleted to observe the tolC mutant phenotype exacerbations; tolC-ygiBC constitute an operon (Dhamdhere, 2010).

Description: 4,5- DOPA-extradiol-dioxygenase
Comments: YgiD is a monomeric 4,5- DOPA-extradiol-dioxygenase that converts L-DOPA to betalamic acid and muscaflavin but its native substrates are unknown (Gand√≠a-Herrero, 2013). YhaJ binds and activates promoters for yqjF, ybiJ, yhaK, ygiD, yhhW, as well as (bssS)yceP to a lesser degree; these YhaJ-regulated genes are proposed to constitute a novel quinol-like compound degradation regulon (Palevsky, 2016).

Description: Zinc and other divalent cation uptake transporter
Comments: The zupT synonym ygiE was mistakenly used to refer to ygjE in the abstract of Oshima, 2006 (see the ygjE bibliography).

Description: L-tartrate dehydratase alpha subunit
Comments: Null

Description: L-tartrate dehydratase beta subunit
Comments: Null

Protein: tRNA(ANN) t(6)A37 threonylcarbamoyladenosine modification protein; glycation binding protein
Description: tRNA(NNU) t(6)A37 threonylcarbamoyladenosine modification; glycation binding protein
Comments: The modified tRNA nucleotide t(6)A37 is derived from the labile cyclized ct(6)A37 during extraction; the tRNA threonylcarbamoyladenosine dehydratase TcdA catalyzes the cyclization reaction (Miyauchi, 2013). TsaBCDE are necessary and sufficient for tRNA(NNU) t(6)A37 threonylcarbamoyladenosine modification in vitro (Deutsch, 2012). TsaD(YgjD) was proposed to be a threonine-bicarbonate ligase producing N-carbamoylthreonine which was proposed to then be transferred to the N(6) group of tRNA(NNU) A37 by TsaC(YrdC); TsaB(YeaZ) is required for the essential function of TsaD(YjgD) (El Yacoubi, 2011). Depletion of TsaD(YgjD) prevents tRNA(NNU) t(6)A37 threonylcarbamoyladenosine modification (Srinivasan, 2010). tsaD(ygjD) mutants accumulate toxic glycated proteins (Amadori-modified proteins); the accumulation of glycated FtsZ in TsaD(YgjD)-depleted cells may explain the genome maintenance phenotype and the unusual cell shapes of tsaD(ygjD) mutants (Katz, 2010). S. cerevisiae Qri7, involved in genome maintenance, complements a tsaD(ygjD) mutant growth defect in E. coli (Oberto, 2009). Loss of TsaD(YgjD) in E. coli causes small cell size and nucleoid loss (Obero, 2009). Depletion of TsaD(YgjD) causes a proportion of cells to be enlarged, with a peripheral distribution of DNA; the TsaD(YgjD) depletion phenotype is suppressed by multicopy clones of rstA (Handford, 2009). TsaD(YgjD) family proteins have been termed UGMPs (Universal Genome Maintenance Proteins) but this may be a pleiotropic phenotype primarily due to a defect in tRNA(NNU) t(6)A37 modification (Oberto, 2009). (TsaB)YeaZ interacts with TsaE(YjeE) and TsaD(YgjD), preferring TsaD(YgjD); TsB(YeaZ) can proteolyze TsaD(YgjD) in vitro (Handford, 2009). TsaD(YgjD) is a homolog of a reported glycoprotease named Gcp, but TsaD(YgjD) does not have glycoprotease activity against glycophorin A and multicopy Gcp (M.h.) expression does not complement an E. coli TsaD(YgjD) deficiency, indicating that M. hemolytica Gcp and E. coli YgjD are not isofunctional orthologs; Gcp (M.h.) may not partner properly with the E. coli TsaB(YeaZ) protein (Handford, 2009). The identification of M. hemolytica Gcp as a glycoprotease was probably incorrect (Srinivasan, 2010). Since TsaD(YgjD) does not have glycoprotese activity and the homologous M. hemolytica Gcp is also probably not a glycoprotease, gcp was retired as the primary gene name for tsaD(ygjD). The tsaD-rpsUdnaGrpoD divergent operon promoter region binds ArcA (Federowicz, 2014).

Description: Propionate kinase, anaerobic; non-essential gene
Comments: otherPDB (S. typhimurium): 1X3M, 1X3N.

Description: Function unknown
Comments: Null

Description: Pentapetide repeats-related protein, function unknown
Comments: YhaC is distantly related to the pentapeptide repeats protein family (NCBI COG1357) and has four pentapeptide repeats (residues 151-170) that are similar to a reported consensus (Vetting, 2006). Like the pentapeptide repeats protein gene yjcF, yhaC is in one of the regions of extreme structure (RES12), perhaps correlated to the DNA mimic role proposed for pentapeptide repeats proteins. YhaC is 43% similar across 214 residues to the pseudogene-encoded pentapeptide repeats protein YjbI'.

Description: Glycerate 2-kinase, glycolate-, glycerate- or glucarate-inducible; GKI; produces 2-phospho-glycerate
Comments: Null

Description: Tartronate semialdehyde reductase, glycerate- or galactarate-inducible
Comments: Null

Protein: tRNA pseudouridine synthase B: tRNA pseudouridine(55) synthase and putative tmRNA pseudouridine(342) synthase
Description: tRNA pseudouridine(55) synthase; tRNA pseudouridine synthase B; putative tmRNA pseudouridine(342) synthase
Comments: TruB is probably a dual specificity enzyme responsible for the formation of pseudouridine at position U342 in tmRNA in addition to tRNA U55 pseudouridinylation (Nurse, 1995; Feldon, 1998). truB mutants are sensitive to extreme heat shock.
