Description: Antitoxin for RnlA, CP4-57 putative defective prophage
Comments: RnlB is the antitoxin for the RnlA RNase LS (Koga, 2010).

Protein: CP4-57 prophage; 50S ribosome-binding GTPase family protein
Description: Required for swarming phenotype, function unknown; putative GTP-binding protein, in CP4-57 putative defective prophage
Comments: Paralogous to yeeP and ykfA.

Description: Function unknown, CP4-57 putative defective prophage
Comments: Null

Protein: CP4-57 prophage; putative DNA-binding transcriptional regulator
Description: Function unknown, CP4-57 putative defective prophage; predicted transcriptional regulator
Comments: The YjfR family contains a predicted HTH domain.

Description: Inner membrane lipoprotein, function unknown, CP4-57; putative defective prophage
Comments: yfjS and yafY are homologs. The first 20 aa of YfjS are a type II signal peptide (Matsuyama, unpublished, cited in Miyadai, 2004). Although overproduction of YafY induces degP expression, YjfS does not; chimeric protein experiments demonstrate that the N- and C- termini of YafY have the degP stimulatory determinants (Miyadai, 2004).

Description: Predicted periplasmic protein, function unknown, CP4-57; putative defective prophage
Comments: Overexpression of YfjT causes abnormal biofilm architecture. The first 23 aa of YfjT are predicted to be a type I signal peptide.

Description: Pseudogene, CP4-57 putative defective prophage
Comments: Null

Description: Pseudogene reconstruction, arsB-like C-terminal fragment; CP4-57 putative defective prophage
Comments: An apparent frameshift at codon 39 was hypothetically reconstructed. Stop codon 116 is reconstructed as an X.

Protein: CP4-57 prophage; putative inner membrane protein
Description: Predicted inner membrane protein, function unknown, CP4-57 putative prophage remnant
Comments: Null

Description: Function unknown, CP4-57 putative prophage remnant
Comments: Null

Protein: CP4-57 prophage; putative DNA repair protein
Description: Function unknown, CP4-57 putative prophage remnant
Comments: Null

Protein: CP4-57 prophage; antitoxin of the YpjF-YfjZ toxin-antitoxin system
Description: Antitoxin component of putative toxin-antitoxin YpjF-YfjZ; CP4-57 putative defective prophage
Comments: YfjZ mutant slightly NO sensitive.

Description: OM autotransporter homolog; overexpression increases adhesion
Comments: Mutants have reduced OM vesiculation (McBroom, 2006). First 29 aa are predicted to be a type I signal peptide.

Description: Function unknown
Comments: Null

Protein: thiamine pyrimidine pyrophosphate hydrolase; HMP-PP phosphatase
Description: HMP-PP phosphatase; catalyzes hydrolysis of 4-amino-2-methyl-5-hydroxymethylpyrimidine pyrophosphate (HMP-PP); MeO-HMP-PP and CF3-HMP-PP also serve as substrates for Cof; HAD18
Comments: Cloned cof complements fur deletion mutant for growth on succinate: this gene name and function have only been reported as an annotation in EMBL entry Z54355, Patzer, S.I. and Hantke, K., 1995. HAD superfamily. Additional substrates include: pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), FMN, 2-deoxyglucose-6-P; in vitro activities demonstrated by Kuznetsova et al. (2005, 2006).

Protein: putative ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein
Description: Putative ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein
Comments: Null

Description: Lrp family predicted transcriptional regulator
Comments: Rob regulon.

Function: Enzyme; Energy metabolism, carbon: Pyruvate dehydrogenase
Description: Lysine decarboxylase, constitutive
Comments: E. coli K-12 has two lysine decarboxylases. CadA(LdcI) is inducible and LdcC is constitutively expressed.

Description: tRNA(Ile) lysidine (L34) synthase, ATP-dependent; solely responsible for tRNA(Ile) lysidine 34 (L34) formation
Comments: TilS(YaeN) is mistakenly labeled as a cell cycle gene in many databases; the confusion arose from the misinterpretation of Genbank Z50870; the real "minE suppressor" is the small rof gene next to tilS, labeled as orf4 in Z50870. PDB: 1NI5. Gu M., Burling T., Lima C.D., Structure of the MesJ PP-ATPase from Escherichia coli, unpublished.

Description: anti-Rho (termination factor); pleiotropic multicopy suppressor of Ts mutations; ribosome-associated; growth-rate regulated
Comments: This is the real "mesJ" minE suppressor, not yaeN.

Description: UPF0253 family protein, function unknown
Comments: Null

Description: PDDEXK superfamily protein, function unknown
Comments: Although Salmonella yaeQ was reported to be a multi-copy suppressor of the E. coli mutant rfaH anti-termination defect responsible for reduced hlyCABD expression, E. coli YaeQ is not an anti-terminator protein (Wong, 1998; Vicari, 2004). YaeQ is the prototype of a family of proteins of unknown function (Pfam PF07152) in the PDDEXK superfamily (Pfam CL0236) of nuclease and other nucleic acid binding enzymes.

Description: Function unknown
Comments: Null

Protein: DNA translocase at septal ring sorting daughter chromsomes
Description: DNA translocase at septal ring sorting daughter chromsomes
Comments: FtsK is required for resolution of chromosome dimers at dif by XerCD. FtsK helps keep the nucleoids properly localized, recognizing opposing replichores by using FtsK orienting polar sequences (KOPS). The N-terminal domain is membrane-anchored, localizes to the division septum and is required for cell division. The C-terminal domain has the non-essential translocase activity, which becomes essential for replicating the asymmetric replichores produced by chromosome inversion (Lesterlin, 2008). LexA regulon. Homologous to B. subtilis SpoIIIE protein. The ftsK gene is essential. The filamentous growth of mutants is suppressed by dacA deletions. ftsK44(ts) can be suppressed by an ftsA R286W mutation or by an ftsQAZ plasmid. Divisome.

Protein: transcriptional repressor for the molybdenum transport operon modABC
Function: Regulator; Transport of small molecules: Anions
Description: Repressor of the modABC operon for molybdenum transport; secondary activator of hyc and nar operons; dimeric
Comments: ModE mutants are unable to reduce selenate.

Description: L-Ala-D/L-Glu epimerase; also epimerizes some other Ala-X dipeptides
Comments: YcjG has a role in the recycling of the murein peptide (Schmidt, 2001; Park, 2008).

Description: Putative LysR-family transcriptional regulator, function unknown
Comments: Null

Description: 6-phosphogluconolactonase, pentose phosphate shunt
Comments: Overexpression causes filamentous biofilm formation.

Description: Cold shock gene, function unknown; mistakenly thought to be sfa, which is the adjacent gene, now called gnsA
Comments: ymcE is transiently induced after a cold shock, dependent on the presence of PNPase. ymcE was misidentified as sfa in the Polissi et al. cold shock paper.

Description: Multicopy suppressor of null secG(Cs) and fabA6(Ts); overexpression increases unsaturated fatty acid content of phospholipids; gnsB paralog
Comments: This is the real sfa allele mistakenly assigned to the adjacent gene, which has now been assigned the ygene name ymcE

Description: Putative polyferredoxin
Comments: napH and yccM are paralogs.

Protein: fused 2-O-a-mannosyl-D-glycerate specific PTS enzymes: IIA component/IIB component/IIC component
Description: 2-O-alpha-mannosyl-D-glycerate transport, EIIABC component; PTS system; overproduction suppresses the defective ompC thermoresponse of a micF mutant
Comments: Null

Description: Alpha-mannosidase, 2-O-alpha-mannosyl-D-glycerate catabolism
Comments: Null

Description: DNA glycosylase/apurinic lyase, deoxyinosine-specific; endonuclease VIII
Comments: There is some evidence from high-throughput studies that YbgIJK-Nei might be a protein complex.

Protein: cobinamide kinase and cobinamide phosphate guanylyltransferase
Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Cobalamin
Description: Partial cobalamin biosynthesis pathway present in E. coli
Comments: Null

Description: Pseudogene, internal fragment
Comments: Defective remnant in ISW.

Function: Putative regulator; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Cobalamin
Description: Probable alpha-ribazole-5'-phosphate phosphatase; potential partial cobalamin biosynthesis pathway
Comments: Primarily characterized in Salmonella.

Description: Nicotinate mononucleotide adenylyltransferase, NAD(P) biosynthesis
Comments: Null

Description: DUF2766 family protein
Comments: Null

Description: Latent secreted hemolysin E; regulated by SlyA, FNR and HN-S
Comments: HylE is secreted but has no signal peptide.

Description: TraB family protein
Comments: The N-terminal domain of YbaP has similarity to the molybdopterin-binding domain of MopB family proteins.

Description: Predicted transcriptional regulator, function unknown
Comments: PF01381 family.

Description: Copper and silver-translocating P-type ATPase efflux pump; CopA(Z) metallochaperone; involved in copper resistance; copper- and silver-inducible; regulated by copper-responsive CueR activator
Comments: CopA produces a 70 aa metallochaperone named CopA(Z) from its first 69 residues plus a C-terminal glycine added after a programmed frameshift (Meydan, 2017; Drees, 2017). CopA contains a putative phosphatase HAD domain: residues 516-740. CusF is a periplasmic copper-, silver-binding protein that may work with CopA. Alternatively, YobA may be a CopC-like periplasmic copper-binding protein that works with CopA. copA is upregulated by GSNO in defined medium (anaerobic). HAD superfamily.

Description: Glutaminase 1, GlsA1
Comments: GlsA and GadC form an acid resistance system sufficient to protect E. coli from acid stress in the pressence of glutamine (Lu, 2013). Early experiments suggesed that GlsA(YbaS) might contribute to acid resistance, as was later demonstrated (Brown, 2008). glsA(ybaS) is in the CueR regulon (Marbach, 2012). glsA(ybaS) may be in the GadE regulon; weak support (Marbach, 2012). Two glutaminases have been purified and biochemically characterized from E. coli B.

Description: Predicted amino acid transporter
Comments: The glsA-ybaT operon organisation and the PF13520 AA_permease_2 motif suggest that YbaT may be a glutamine or general amino acid transporter. A mini-Tn10 insertion in ybaT inhibits the reduction of selenate without altering the growth rate. ybaT is in the CueR regulon and adjacent to cueR (Marbach, 2012).

Protein: periplasmic folding chaperone, has an inactive PPIase domain
Description: Periplasmic folding chaperone, has an inactive PPIase domain
Comments: Contrary to previously reported results, PpiD does not have PPIase enzymatic activity, although it retains its PPIase substrate binding function (Weninger, 2009). PpiD has an N-terminal membrane anchor. A native membrane complex of YfgM and PpiD has been detected (Maddalo, 2011). An fkpA, surA, ppiB, ppiD quadruple mutant is viable (Justice, 2005). Heat-inducible.

Protein: putative competence-suppressing periplasmic helix-hairpin-helix DNA-binding protein
Description: Putative competence-suppressing DNA-binding periplasmic protein; function unknown
Comments: YbaV is a predicted periplasmic protein required for cell-to-cell plasmid transfer that has a C-terminal ComEA-like tandem helix-hairpin-helix putative DNA-binding domain and may sequester incoming DNA in the periplasm, suppressing transformation efficiency (Matsuda, 2012). ybaV is predicted to have a CRP-S promoter co-regulated by both Crp and Sxy (Cameron, 2006). YbaV is predicted to have a 25 aa type I signal peptide.

Description: Long-chain acyl-CoA thioesterase III
Comments: 3,5-tetradecadienoyl-CoA is the preferred substrate for thioesterase III, which is induced by fatty acids, suggesting a role in beta-oxidation of fatty acids (Nie, 2008). fadM(ybaW) is part of the FadR regulon (Feng, 2009). FadM is a member of the HotDog superfamily of thioesterases and dehydratases (Pfam CL0050, PF03061; PDB 1NJK) (Dillon, 2004).

Description: 7-cyano-7-deazaguanine (preQ0) synthase; queuosine biosynthesis
Comments: An E. coli queC mutant is deficient in converting preQ0 to preQ1 (Gaur, 2005). An E. coli queC mutant lacks quenosine and epoxyqueuosine (Miles, 2011). The orthologous B. subtilis QueC enzyme activity has been characterized in vitro (McCarty, 2009). Asn, Asp, Tyr, and His tRNA anticodons are modified by queuosine. A. viscosus ortholog ALU1 confers aluminum tolerance when cloned in E. coli (Jo, 1997). COG0603 predicts ATPase activity. tgt mutants lack queuosine and are have reduced survival in stationary phase. (Noguchi, 1982).

Description: Novel verified lipoprotein, function unknown
Comments: The first 18 aa of YbaY are a type II signal peptide. ybaY is repressed by OxyS overexpression (Tjaden, 2006).

Protein: excision repair protein, alkyltransferase-like protein ATL
Description: Excision repair protein; alkyltransferase-like protein ATL; binds and enhances nucleotide excision repair of O(6)-alkylguanine; DNA-binding protein; degenerate Ada/Ogt cysteine methyltransferase paralog
Comments: YbaZ is homologous to methylated-DNA--protein-cysteine methyltransferases Ada and Ogt, but lacks the active site cysteine. YbaZ binds O(6)-alkylguanine residues in DNA and blocks alkyltransferase action; YbaZ does not remove methyl groups from O(6)-methylguanine-containing DNA nor does it have glycosylase or endonuclease activity (Margison, 2007). YbaZ preferentially binds DNA with an abasic site, has base-flipping activity, and binds HelD (Chen, 2008). YbaZ strongly enhances nucleotide excision repair of the large O(6)-alkylguanine adducts that are not good substrates for paralogs Ogt and Ada to remove (Mazon, 2009).

Description: Activator of copper-responsive regulon genes cueO and copA; MerR homolog
Comments: Although CueR is a soluble copper-binding protein, it was not detected using Cu(I)-MIRAGE, probably because it selectively binds Cu(I), most of which is oxidized to Cu(II) by CueO, and thus the amount of CueR bound to Cu(I) probably lies below the detection limit (Sevcenco, 2009; Sevcenco, 2012).

Protein: inner membrane protein; stimulator of the QmcA suppressor of ftsH-htpX
Description: Inner membrane protein; stimulates the ftsH htpX mutant suppressor activity of QmcA
Comments: qmcA and ybbJ constitute an operon. YbbJ is a NfeD/STOPP family protein, often operonic with PHB proteins.

Description: Multicopy suppressor of ftsH htpX double mutant; membrane-anchored predicted protease with C-terminal cytoplasmic PHB domain
Comments: Prohibitin homology (PHB) domain. The PHB domain is also called the SPFH domain, named after the proteins Stomatin, Prohibitin, Flotillin and HflK/C (Tavernarakis, 1999; Morrow, 2005; Rivera-Milla, 2006; Browman, 2007). QmcA belongs to subfamily SPFH1a (Hinderhofer, 2009). QmcA is oligomeric and interacts with ftsH. QmcA suppressor activity, but not protein synthesis, is stimulated by downstream NfeD/STOPP family gene ybbJ. QmcA expression from the chromosome is detected, but must be insufficient for suppression. QmcA is not stably complexed with FtsH, but they do physically interact.

Protein: iron export ABC transporter ATPase; peroxide resistance protein
Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Cations
Description: Iron export ABC transporter ATPase; peroxide resistance protein
Comments: FetAB confers peroxide resistance and exports excess iron; overexpression of FetAB increases peroxide resistance and fetA or fetB mutants are sensitive to peroxide stress (Nicolaou, 2013).

Protein: iron export ABC transporter permease; peroxide resistance protein
Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Cations
Description: Iron export ABC transporter permease; peroxide resistance protein
Comments: FetAB confers peroxide resistance and exports excess iron; overexpression of FetAB increases peroxide resistance and fetA or fetB mutants are sensitive to peroxide stress (Nicolaou, 2013). FetA is an integral mebrane protein with the C-terminus inside the cytoplasm (Daley, 2005; Nicolaou, 2013).

Description: DnaK co-chaperone, thioredoxin-like protein; probable DNA replicase folding chaperone; has SXXC not CXXC motif
Comments: YbbN is a co-chaperone for both DnaJKGrpE and GroESL(Lin, 2011). YbbN assists in refolding of DnaN, and ybbN mutants produce anucleated cells and have DNA replication defects (Le, 2011). YbbN has two tandem C-terminal TPR-like repeat domains. The function of YbbN as both an thiol-disulfide oxidoreductase and as a chaperone is controversial (Vlamis-Gardikas, 2008): YbbN has been reported to oxidize cysteines of RNase A and to have chaperone activity (Caldas, 2006), but this is partially contradicted by a report that YbbN cannot reduce oxidized insulin and has no chaperone activity on citrate synthase (Pan, 2006). This contradiction is substantially resolved by a followup to the Caldas (2006) study which found no evidence for YbbN oxidoreductase activity in vivo and and agree with Pan (2006) that there is no significant in vitro chaperone activity of YbbN alone on citrate syntase, but there is a strong stimulation of DnaK chaperone activity on citrate syntase, thus YbbN is a DnaK co-chaperone (Kthiri, 2008). YbbN binds DnaK and GroEL; ybbN mutants are sensitive to heat stress but not oxidative stress (Kthiri, 2008). HT_Cmplx38_Cyt: Usg+YbbN. otherPDB (S.typhimurium): 3QDN.

Description: COG1028 oxidoreductase family protein
Comments: Null

Description: Putative ABC transporter permease
Comments: Null

Description: Tartronate semialdehyde reductase, glyoxylate-inducible, NADH-dependent
Comments: Null

Description: Transcriptional activator for the allD operon
Comments: Null

Description: Probable fosmidomycin exporter, membrane protein; overexpression confers fosmidomycin resistance
Comments: Major Facilitator Superfamily (MFS).

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Other
Description: Aquaporin Z, glycerol and water channel; RpoS regulon
Comments: AqpZ-dependent water permeability increases as cells enter stationary phase. The aqpZ-ybjD divergent operon promoter region binds FNR (Federowicz, 2014).

Description: 2-dehydropantoate 2-reductase, NADPH-dependent; also known as ketopantoate reductase (KPR)
Comments: PanE is also indirectly involved in the alternative pathway for pyrimidine biosynthesis. Sequence verified by mass spectrometry (obs=33870), Met is not clipped. False positive lipoprotein prediction, unprocessed, verified by mass spectrometry.

Description: Guanine deglycase, guanine glycation repair system; covalent chaperone for sulfenylated thiol proteins; confers resistance to oxidative stress, chaperone activity; mutant accumulates protein aggregates
Comments: YhbO, YajL and HchA are three guanine deglycases that constitute a guanine glycation repair system, removing glyoxal and methylglyoxal adducts from free quanine nucleotides and from modified quanine in nucleic acids (Richarme, 2017). The YajL chaperone forms mixed disulfides with target proteins, preferentially at sulfenylated cysteines (Le, 2012; Gautier, 2012). YajL stimulates refolding of citrate cynthase in vitro, and a yajL mutant has increased protein aggregation during aerobiosis, is sensitive to oxidative stress, and has reduced mRNA levels for the aggregated proteins (Kthiri, 2010). YajL has been mistakenly described as ThiJ, involved in thiamine metabolism. This phenotype is now attributed to the adjacent thiI gene (T. Begley, personal communication cited in Mueller et al., NAR 26:2606-10 (1998). C56 peptidase family; DJ-1/PARK7 superfamily; PfpI/HchA protease/chaperone family.

Description: tRNA s(4)U8 sulfurtransferase, activated by IscS; ThiS-thiocarboxylate (ThiS-COSH) synthesis; mutant is near-UV resistant
Comments: The 4-thiouridine modification of tRNA acts as a near UV sensor because it makes tRNA near-UV labile, blocking translation, inducing the stringent response and stopping growth. The synonym nuvA is assigned to thiI: a nuvA mutant is near-UV resistant and maps to 9.3' (Mueller, 1998). ThiI has rhodanase and THUMP domains. Two reports of thiI complementation of nuvC were noted in Taylor (1998): footnote 3 cites (Mueller, 1998), but that complemented "nuvC" allele was not the original nuvC allele but a thiI mutant with the same phenotype isolated using the same procedure; footnote 2 attributes the complementation to C. Kinsland and T. P. Begley, unpublished results, and these results ars still unpublished. ThiI probably transfers sulfur to adenylated substrates. Two components Factor A (NuvA, 9.3) and Factor B (NuvB, ~45') were originally shown to be required for tRNA s(4)U8 modification with NuvC being the pyridoxal phosphate requiring factor; despite the mapping discrepancy it seems likely that IscS (57.3') is Factor C (NuvC) and ThiI (9.3') is Factor A (NuvA) (Kambampati, 2000).

Description: Part of T3SS PAI ETT2 remnant, function unknown
Comments: This gene is a remnant of the type three secretion system (T3SS) pathogenicity island ETT2. 18 kb of ETT2 has been deleted from K-12, leaving 10 kb of the presumably non-functional T3SS ETT2 remaining.

Description: Nucleoside triphosphatase, pyrimidine dNTPs preferred
Comments: Null

Protein: trimethylamine N-oxide reductase system III, catalytic subunit
Description: Periplasmic trimethylamine oxide (TMAO) reductase; also has biotin sulfoxide and DMSO reductase activities; respiratory system
Comments: Verified Tat substrate: TorZ has a Tat/Sec (Class II) 31 aa signal peptide (Tullman-Ercek, 2007). Signal peptide is a TatC-dependent export substrate (Gon, 2000).

Protein: TMAO reductase III (TorYZ), cytochrome c-type subunit
Description: Cytochrome c homolog required for periplasmic reduction of TMAO by TorZ; respiratory system
Comments: Null

Description: DUF159 family protein, function unknown
Comments: Null

Description: GNAT family putative N-acetyltransferase
Comments: Null

Description: Pseudogene reconstruction, IpaH/YopM family
Comments: An intact allele is Z3023 of E. coli OH157:H7 (UniProtKB: Q8X520). Frameshifts at codons 104 and 331 were hypothetically reconstructed. Stop codon 268 is translated as X in the reconstruction.

Protein: multidrug resistance efflux pump membrane fusion protein
Description: EmrKY-TolC multidrug resistance efflux pump, membrane fusion protein; overexpression resistance to deoxycholate; signal anchored membrane protein
Comments: Mutations in emrK have a hyperlethality phenotype when cells are stressed; EmrK is a protein that reduces the lethal effects of stress (Han, 2010). EvgAS regulon.

Description: EmrKY-TolC multidrug resistance efflux pump; overexpression resistance to deoxycholate
Comments: Mutations in emrY have a hyperlethality phenotype when cells are stressed; EmrY is a protein that reduces the lethal effects of stress (Han, 2010). EvgAS regulon. Major Facilitator Superfamily (MFS).

Description: Acetyl-CoA:oxalate CoA-transferase
Comments: EvgAS regulon. The frc-oxc-yfdVE operon is adjacent and convergent on evgAS. Frc paralog.

Protein: putative membrane-anchored DUF883 family ribosome-binding protein
Description: Ribosome-binding protein, function unknown; probably membrane-anchored; DUF883 family
Comments: YgaM binds ribosomes and is expressed mainly in stationary phase (Yoshida, 2012). DUF883 family. YgaM, ElaB and YqjD are paralogs predicted to have C-terminal inner membrane anchors (Luirink, 2011).

Protein: hydrogen donor for NrdEF electron transport system; glutaredoxin-like protein
Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Thioredoxin, glutaredoxin, glutathione
Description: NrdH-redoxin reducing oxidized NrdEF
Comments: NrdH-redoxin has a glutaredoxin-like protein sequence but is reduced by thioredoxin reductase in vivo, consistent with its lack of a GSH binding site motif (Stehr, 2001; Gon, 2006) In the absence of thioredoxin reductase and NrdH-redoxin, glutaredoxin 1 can partially replace NrdH-redoxin (Gon, 2006). Purified NrdH-redoxin was N-terminally sequenced to show the initial Met is not clipped, but this is not counted as verification of the ATG since the purified protein was made with a foreign RBS. Upregulated by GSNO in defined medium (anaerobic). Fur regulon.

Function: Enzyme; Biosynthesis of cofactors, carriers: Thioredoxin, glutaredoxin, glutathione
Description: Flavodoxin required for NrdEF cluster assembly
Comments: NrdI binds NrdF and is involved in NrdEF Mn(+3) dimetallocofactor asssembly, helping to disciminate against Fe(+2) insertion (Cotruvo, 2010).

Description: DUF2892 family inner membrane rhodanese; tributyltin-inducible via YgaU
Comments: YgaP has a rhodanese domain and sulfur transferase (rhodanese) activity in vitro, F. Ahmed, Ph.D. thesis, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA (2003), cited in Gueune (2008).

Description: Function unknown, low abundance protein; homologous to P. aeruginosa AlgH regulatory protein
Comments: Null

Description: Putative anti-termination factor for Rho-dependent terminators
Comments: A yqgF-Ts mutant is sensitive to Rho and NusA overproduction and has reduced transcription of genes following Rho terminators; the reduced transcription is increased in the presence of the Rho inhibitor bicylomycin (Iwamoto, 2012). YqgF is an essential gene. YqgF has an RNase H-like fold and is related to the Holliday junction resolvases RuvC and RusA.

Function: Enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Pool, multipurpose conversions
Description: Glycolate oxidase 4Fe-4S iron-sulfur cluster subunit
Comments: The GlcF subunit of glycolate oxidase has an N-terminal 4Fe-4S dicluster domain (pfam PF12838) with 8 conserved Cys residues; GlcF also has two C-terminal cysteine-rich domains (Pfam PF02754) each with invariant CCG motifs and two conserved single Cys residues. glcF and glpC are homologous horizontal transfer (HT) genes.

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: 4-Hydroxy-2-oxovalerate aldolase; utilizes MHP
Comments: Null

Description: 3-hydroxyphenylpropionic acid transporter
Comments: MhpT overexpression reduces intracellular arabinose, but not xylose, concentration; other compounds were not tested (Koita, 2012). Major Facilitator Superfamily (MFS).

Description: DUF2058 family protein, function unknown
Comments: Null

Description: S-formylglutathione hydrolase, formaldehyde degradation
Comments: FrmB also has p-nitrophenyl C2-C6 fatty acid ester and a-naphthyl acetate carboxylesterase activities in vitro. The frmRAB operon is negatively regulated by frmR, is induced by formaldehyde, and probably degrades formaldehyde. FrmB is 50% identical to P. denitrificans S-formylglutathione hydrolase. FrmB and YeiG are 50% identical paralogs; double mutant is formaldehyde sensitive; this may explain why an frmB single mutant did not have a formadehyde phenotype when tested on Biolog plates (Herring, 2004). The amino terminal half of FrmB is homologus to the C-terminal half of YieL. S9 peptidase family; YeiG or FrmB are not in MEROPS yet, but it has homologs.

Protein: regulator protein that represses frmRAB operon
Description: Negative regulator of the frmRAB operon
Comments: The frmRAB operon is negatively regulated by frmR, is induced by formaldehyde, and probably degrades formaldehyde. An amber suppressor allows readthrough of frmR, adding 7 aa, which inactivates FrmR, causing stimulation of frmRAB transcription. frmR and rcnR are paralogs.

Description: Outer membrane protein, function unknown
Comments: The predicted 19 aa signal peptide of YaiO is consistent with an observed secB-dependent precursor cleavage that is blocked by azide (Marani, 2006).

Description: Predicted family 2 glycosyltransferase, function unknown
Comments: YaiP overlaps the N-terminus of YaiX by 47 codons, which is unusual.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Taurine ABC transporter ATPase
Comments: Null

Protein: taurine ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein
Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Taurine ABC transporter periplasmic binding protein
Comments: Cbl regulon. tauA and ssuA are paralogs.

Function: Transport; Transport of small molecules: Amino acids, amines
Description: Taurine ABC transporter permease
Comments: Null

Description: Predicted PIG-L family deacetylase
Comments: YaiS has the Pfam PF02585 signature.

Description: Dipeptide and tripeptide permease D
Comments: Major Facilitator Superfamily (MFS).

Protein: GTP cyclohydrolase-like radiation resistance protein; metal-binding
Description: GTP cyclohydrolase-like radiation resistance protein; metal-binding
Comments: YbgI belongs to the GTP cyclohydrolase 1 type 2/NIF3 family (InterPro IPR002678; Pfam PF01784) whose most characterized prokaryotic member is the Helicobacter pylori GTP cyclohydrolase 1 type 2 (HP0959) (Choi, 2013). A ybgI mutation is one of many selected in a strain evolved for resistance to high levels of ionizing radiation; a single ybgI deletion mutant has a 2-3 orders of magnitude drop in survival after radiation exposure as compared to a ybgI+ strain (Byrne, 2014). Although YbgI is labeled as a putative GTP cyclohydrolase in many annotations of YbgI orthologs, there are several reasons to consider a substrate related to but distinct from GTP for YbgI. First, GTP cyclohydrolase 1 activity has been purified from E. coli and only FolE was isolated (Yim, 1976). Second, a folE mutant has a phenotype that cannot be satisfied by a presumably still intact copy of ybgI (Klaus, 2005). Third, the amino acid sequence identity between HP0959 and YbgI is only 27% (29/105) and only the last 101 amino acids align to YbgI using blastp; this is usually considered as too divergent to assume isofunctional orthology. Fourth, YbgI provides significant protection from radiation damage and may be involved in the degradation of radiation-damaged nucleotides; ybgI linkage (genetic neighborhood) to two genes involved in DNA repair, nei and phr, is conserved across many bacterial genomes perhaps indicating that they work together; consistent with this hypothesis the Phr product is a DNA photolyase that repairs cyclobutylpyrimidine dimers in DNA and Nei is part of the damaged base excision repair (BER) pathway. There is some evidence from high-throughput studies that YbgIJK-Nei might be a protein complex. YbgI is a member of the widely conserved protein family UPF0135. YbgI has a dinuclear metal site. HT_Cmplx40_Cyt: YbgI+YqhD.

Description: Putative allophanate hydrolase, subunit 1
Comments: There is some evidence from high-throughput studies that YbgIJK-Nei might be a protein complex.

Description: Putative allophanate hydrolase, subunit 2
Comments: There is some evidence from high-throughput studies that YbgIJK-Nei might be a protein complex.

Description: Function unknown, low abundance protein, UPF0271 family
Comments: Null

Description: Pseudogene reconstruction, CP4-57 putative defective prophage
Comments: UPF0401 family. In frame stop codons 8 and 11 were translated as Xs. A frameshift at codon 60 was hypothetically corrected in the protein sequence.

Protein: regulator of aidB expression; inner membrane protein
Description: Regulator of aidB expression; inner membrane protein
Comments: Null

Description: Fimbrial protein, function unknown
Comments: The first 23 aa of YgbO are predicted to be a type I signal peptide. YbgO is encoded in the ybgDQPO fimbrial operon. The C-terminal domain of paralogs yqiI and ybgO may be distantly related to FimA.

Description: Putative periplasmic pilus chaperone, function unknown
Comments: Probable false positive lipoprotein prediction, Cys not conserved. First 20 aa are a predicted type I signal peptide. YbgP has Ig-like domains: pfam PF00345 aligns to N-terminal residues 21-143, and pfam PF02753 aligns to C-terminal residues 150-223.

Description: Putative outer membrane fimbrial subunit export usher protein; function unknown
Comments: FimD family. First 21 aa are predicted to be a type I signal peptide.

Description: Putative ABC transporter ATPase
Comments: The putative ybiHybhGFSR operon encodes a predicted transcriptional regulator (YbiH) and four proteins of a predicted ABC-type transporter complex YbhGFSR, containing two ABC permease family members (YbhSR), a predicted ATP-binding cassette protein (YbhF), and a predicted membrane fusion protein (YbhG) usually associated with RND-type efflux pumps. No predicted periplasmic binding protein is associated with this predicted ABC transporter YbhGFSR, suggesting that it is an exporter, which is consistent with the presence of a membrane fusion protein (YbhG) allowing for export transit across the periplasm. YbhG (f332) was mistakenly predicted to be a periplasmic binding protein, leading to the mis-classification of YbhGFSR as a putative importer (Linton, 1998).

Protein: putative membrane fusion protein (MFP) component of efflux pump, membrane anchor
Description: Putative membrane fusion protein (MFP), function unknown; probable exporter YbhGFSR; signal anchor
Comments: The putative ybiHybhGFSR operon encodes a predicted transcriptional regulator (YbiH) and four proteins of a predicted ABC-type transporter complex YbhGFSR, containing two ABC permease family members (YbhSR), a predicted ATP-binding cassette protein (YbhF), and a predicted membrane fusion protein (YbhG) usually associated with RND-type efflux pumps. No predicted periplasmic binding protein is associated with this predicted ABC transporter YbhGFSR, suggesting that it is an exporter, which is consistent with the presence of a membrane fusion protein (YbhG) allowing for export transit across the periplasm. YbhG (f332) was mistakenly predicted to be a periplasmic binding protein (noted as subfamily "v"), leading to the mis-classification of YbhGFSR as a putative importer (Linton, 1998). YbhG has a predicted 20 aa signal anchor.

Description: Fe(II)-dependent oxygenase superfamily protein; function unknown
Comments: YbiX is related to PiuC, an iron-regulated P. aeruginosa protein. Fur regulon. 3/121 YbiX peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is not removed (Maillet, 2007).

Description: TonB-dependent ferric iron outer membrane transporter; siderophore receptor for ferri-dihydroxybenzoylserine, ferri-dihydroxybenzoate and other catecholate siderophores; surface receptor for colicins G, H, and E492
Comments: Fiu transports catechol-substituted cephalosporins. Fiu is in the Fur regulon. The fiu promoter region binds ArcA and fiu is repressed by ArcA (Federowicz, 2014). Fiu is regulated during colony morphogenesis. The first 31 aa of Fiu are predicted to be a type I signal peptide.

Description: Stimulates colanic acid mucoidy, YhcN family, periplasmic; suppresses biofilm formation; repressed by McbR
Comments: The first 22 aa of McbA are predicted to be a type I signal peptide. Periplasmic protein. MqsR activates McbR transcription.

Description: 23S rRNA m(6)A1618 methyltransferase, SAM-dependent
Comments: YbiN is rlmF; rlmF- has a slow growth phenotype (Sergiev, 2008).

Description: Mechanosensitive channel protein, intermediate (MscS-like) conductance
Comments: YbiO is a novel mechanosensitive channel protein of intermediate (MscS-like) conductance and is transcriptionally regulated by NaCl (Edwards, 2012). mscS, mscK(kefA), mscM(yjeP), ybiO, ybdG and ynaI are paralogs of the MscS family. RpoS regulon.

Description: OPG biosynthetic phosphoethanolamine transferase; transmembrane ; EptAB family
Comments: OpgE is the OPG biosynthetic transmembrane phosphoethanolamine transferase responsible for adding the phosphoethanolamine substituents to the OPG backbone in the periplasm (Bontemps-Gallo, 2013). Osmoregulated periplasmic glucans (OPGs) were originally called membrane-derived oligosaccharides opgE(ybiP) mutants do not have defects in LPS structure as determined by mass spectrometery, indicating that OpgE(YbiP) modifies a substrate other than LPS (Klein, 2013).

Description: Mn(2+)-responsive manganese regulon transcriptional regulator
Comments: Null

Protein: putative ArsB family transporter; inner membrane protein
Description: Putative ArsB family transporter; inner membrane protein
Comments: YbiR is a member of the IT (Ion Transporter) superfamily (Prakash, 2003). YbiR is amember of the ST(3) structural class based on hydropathy profile (Lolkema, 2003). YbiR is closely related to the arsB transporter family and is also related to the CitT and CitM families of citrate transporters. A profile specific to the YbiR family (cd01117) has been created in the CD database at the NCBI.

Description: L,D-transpeptidase linking Lpp to murein, periplasmic
Comments: LdtB(YbiS) has an active site cysteine that is kept reduced by DsbG and DsbC to reverse sulfenic acid formation (Depuydt, 2009). The ldtB-ybiT divergent operon promoter region binds FNR; ldtB(ybiS) expression is repressed by FNR (Federowicz, 2014).

Description: ABC-F family putative regulatory ATPase, function unknown
Comments: YbiT is a procaryotic ABC-F family member defined by two ABC transporter-related predicted ATP-binding domains (Pfam:PF0005) joined by a linker domain (Pfam: PF12848); other ABC-F family members include eucaryotic translation-related factors and the E. coli K-12 proteins EttA, Uup, and YheS (Bo√´l, 2014; Chen, 2014). The E. chrysanthemi YbiT ortholog plays a role in plant infective fitness. The ldtB-ybiT divergent operon promoter region binds FNR and ybiT expression is activated by FNR (Federowicz, 2014). 3/102 YbiT peptide masses from MS analysis confirm this start codon and indicate that the initial Met is not removed (Maillet, 2007).

Description: DUF1479 family protein
Comments: The ybiU promoter region has an ArcA binding site (Federowicz, 2014).

Description: Sugar phosphatase; preference for fructose-1-P, ribose-5-P and glucose-6-P; phosphoramidase and acetyl phosphatase; HAD12
Comments: HAD superfamily. The natural substrate(s) and physiological role of YbiV is unknown. In vitro activities demonstrated by Kuznetsova et al. (2005, 2006). A clone of ybiV was isolated as a multicopy suppresssor of a lethal ygjD deficiency (Handford, 2009).

Description: Pyruvate formate-lyase homolog, function unknown
Comments: The fsa-ybiYW divergent operon promoter region binds FNR and ArcA (Federowicz, 2014).

Description: Undecaprenyl pyrophosphate synthase; dimeric
Comments: Null

Function: Putative enzyme; Central intermediary metabolism: Pool, multipurpose conversions
Description: Glyoxalase II, hydroxyacylglutathione hydrolase, Zn(2+) cofactor
Comments: OtherPDB (S.typhimurium): 2QED.

Description: Predicted SAM-dependent methyltransferase, function unknown
Comments: Null

Description: Novel verified lipoprotein, function unknown
Comments: The first 18 aa of YafT are a type II signal peptide.

Description: Pseudogene, C-terminal fragment; overexpressed fragment localized to inner membrane
Comments: A compete YafU is predicted to be 204 aa, using sequence from Shigella sonnei 53G, unfinished, Sanger Center, and many subsequent unfinished E. coli and Shigella genomes. A deletion has apparently removed the N-terminus of YafU in K-12. The predicted complete sequence of YafU is : MTEFDDNGKIIFNLNALKYTKASYFEILGEKYIKITTSSPWLLEKLGKYIFSSRAPQVLELAIGWRGALSESIKGVKFCIWFSVAWRTIEFIMSSERDLVNFLGDFSMDVAKAVIAGGVATAIGSLTSFACVSFGFPVILVGGAILLTGIVCTVVLNEIDAQCHLSEKLKYAIRDGLKRQQELDKWKRENMTPFLYVLNTPPVI

Protein: putative NAD(P)-binding C-N hydrolase family amidase
Description: Predicted C-N hydrolase family amidase, NAD(P)-binding, function unknown
Comments: YafV is a member of the C-N hydrolase family (Pfam PF00795).

Protein: CP4-6 prophage; antitoxin of the YkfI-YafW toxin-antitoxin system
Description: Antitoxin component of toxin-antitoxin protein pair YkfI-YafW; CP4-6 putative prophage remnant
Comments: Null

Description: Function unknown, CP4-6 putative prophage remnant
Comments: Null

Protein: lipoprotein, inner membrane; degP regulator; CP4-6 prophage
Description: Inner membrane lipoprotein, function unknown; overproduction stimulates degP expression; CP4-6; putative prophage remnant
Comments: yfjS and yafY are homologs. The first 17 aa of YafY are a type II signal peptide (Matsuyama, unpublished, cited in Miyadai, 2004). Although overproduction of YafY induces degP expression, YjfS does not; chimeric protein experiments demonstrate that the N- and C- termini of YafY have the degP stimulatory determinants (Miyadai, 2004). Originally, the annotation of yafY was fused to the upstream pseudogene ykfK. It is possible that a YkfK-YafW chimeric pseudogene product is made in vivo, but no function would be expected since cleavage of the type II signal is likely to be blocked in any chimeric protein synthesized. Expression of the native YafY lipoprotein gene in the chromosome has not yet been reported. E. coli B has a third protein in this family (UniProtKB: A2UFU7), 55% identical to YafY and YfjS, that demonstrates conservation of the shorter ORFs and their lipoprotein signals in this novel prophage gene family.

Description: Function unknown, CP4-6 putative prophage remnant
Comments: Null

Description: Putative GTP-binding protein, function unknown, CP4-6; putative prophage remnant
Comments: Paralogous to yeeP and yfjP.

Protein: CP4-6 prophage; putative DNA-binding transcriptional regulator
Description: Predicted DNA-binding transcriptional regulator; CP4-6 putative defective prophage
Comments: The function identified in Genbank U57080 for PerR is that it is a regulatory gene for peroxide resistance in stationary phase (Loewen P.C., Switala J., Volkert M.R., Peroxide sensitivity genes of E. coli, unpublished 1996). LysR family.

Description: Pseudogene, retron-type reverse transcriptase family, CP4-6; putative defective prophage; N-terminal fragment
Comments: Null

Description: S-methylmethionine permease, CP4-6 putative prophage remnant
Comments: Met regulon.

Description: S-methylmethionine:(seleno)homocysteine methyltransferase; CP4-6 putative prophage remnant
Comments: Met regulon.

Description: 2-keto-3-deoxy gluconate (KDG) aldolase, tetrameric; CP4-6 putative prophage remnant
Comments: Overexpression of YagE confers resistance to several antibiotics, including norfloxacin, ampicillin and streptomycin (Bhaskar, 2011).

Description: Predicted dehydratase, function unknown, CP4-6 prophage; thymol sensitivity determinant
Comments: A transposon insertion in yagF confers thymol resistance (Shapira, 2007). yjhG, yagF, ilvD and edd are paralogs.

Description: Putative sugar symporter, function unknown, CP4-6; putative prophage remnant
Comments: yagGH is predicted to be an operon involved in uptake and catabolism of an unknown sugar substrate. Major Facilitator Superfamily (MFS).

Description: Putative beta-xylosidase, function unknown, CP4-6; putative prophage remnant
Comments: yagGH is predicted to be an operon involved in uptake and catabolism of an unknown sugar substrate.

Description: Function unknown; Fur regulon
Comments: Null

Protein: CP4-6 prophage; putative DNA-binding transcriptional regulator
Description: Function unknown, CP4-6 putative prophage remnant
Comments: Null

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: p-Aminobenzoyl-glutamate hydrolase, B subunit; PGH; manganese-dependent; required for p-aminobenzoyl-glutamate utilization
Comments: abgAB expression is required for catabolism to feed p-aminobenzoate auxotrophs (Hussein, 1998; Carter, 2007). AbgAB (PGH) catalyzes the hydrolysis of p-aminobenzoyl-glutamate to p-aminobenzoate (Carter, 2007; Green, 2010). The abg operon is silent and an AbgR inducer has not been found (Hussein, 1998; Carter, 2007). AbgB is a member of the M20 peptidase family. abgA and abgB are paralogs. AbgABT does not degrade dipeptides; the physiological role of abgABT should be clarified when the inducer for AbgR is elucidated (Green, 2010).

Function: Enzyme; Degradation of small molecules: Carbon compounds
Description: p-Aminobenzoyl-glutamate hydrolase, A subunit; PGH; manganese-dependent; required for p-aminobenzoyl-glutamate utilization
Comments: abgAB expression is required for catabolism to feed p-aminobenzoate auxotrophs (Hussein, 1998; Carter, 2007). AbgAB (PGH) catalyzes the hydrolysis of folate metabolite p-aminobenzoyl-glutamate to p-aminobenzoate (Carter, 2007; Green, 2010). The abg operon is silent and an AbgR inducer has not been found (Hussein, 1998; Carter, 2007). AbgA is a member of the M20 peptidase family. abgA and abgB are paralogs. AbgABT does not degrade dipeptides; the physiological role of abgABT should be clarified when the inducer for AbgR is elucidated (Green, 2010).

Protein: putative DNA-binding transcriptional regulator of abgABT operon
Description: Predicted regulator of the abgABT operon
Comments: The abg operon is silent and an AbgR inducer has not been found (Hussein, 1998; Carter, 2007). LysR family.

Description: DNA endonuclease, function unknown
Comments: SmrA(YdaL) has DNA endonuclease activity (Gui, 2011). The two E. coli Smr proteins were identified and named smr based on homology to the C-terminal domain of MutS2 which has an N-terminal domain homologous to MutS but is not found in E. coli; mutS2 is usually found only in strains lacking smr genes (Moreira, 1999). Although the mnemonic for Smr is small mutS-related, mutS2-related is used since the Smr proteins do not have a region homologous to MutS itself.

Description: Diguanylate cyclase, csgD regulator; also regulates GGDEF protein YaiC(AdrA)
Comments: YdaM has an N-terminal PAS domain with a second PAS domain followed by a PAC domain then a C-terminal diguanylate cyclase GGDEF domain; there may be a degenerate PAC structural domain between the first and second PAS domains since PAC domains are usually associated C-terminal to PAS domains. RpoS regulon (Weber, 2006). YdaM expression is thermoregulated and may act as a thermosensor for curli control (Weber, 2006). YdaM/Gmr(YciR) constitute an RpoS-regulated c-di-GMP synthesis/degradation module inversely regulated by Hns and controlling the expression of curli genes (Weber, 2006). YdaM has diguanylate cyclase activity in vitro (Weber, 2006).

Description: Zn(II) transporter
Comments: YdaN has been characterized as a zinc transporter in Salmonella, but no experiments have yet been done in E. coli (Worlock, 2002).

Protein: tRNA s(2)C32 thioltransferase, iron‚Äìsulfur cluster protein
Description: tRNA s(2)C32 thioltransferase, iron‚Äìsulfur cluster protein; dimeric; forms 2-thiocytidine
Comments: TtcA has ATP-dependent tRNA s(2)C32 thioltransferase activity in vitro (Bouvier, 2014). TtcA has been shown to be required for the formation of 2-thiocytidine s(2)C32 in Salmonella and E. coli (Jager, 2004). 2-thiocytidine s(2)C32 is present in three Arg tRNAs (CCG, UCU, ICG) and in Ser tRNA(GCU). The attachment site of Rac is a 26 bp repeat region flanking Rac: 1409923-1409948 and 1432983-1433008 (A. J. Clark, pers. comm., June, 1998). The ends of Rac are marked at the left end of these repeat regions to delineate attB and attP. This Rac integration event is within the ttcA gene; the first 17 aa of TtcA are Rac prophage-derived. The ttcC' pseudogene is the remnant 17 aa displaced from the original chromosomal ttcA gene. 25 bp encoding four mismatches immediately preceed the 26 bp exact repeat. Representative of both alleles are found in sequenced E. coli and Shigella genomes. This is analogous to e14 integration into the icd gene producing the icdC' remnant pseudogene.

Description: Integrase gene, Rac prophage
Comments: Null

Description: Putative exisionase, Rac prophage
Comments: YdaQ is a member of the DUF1233 family of putative exisionases.

Protein: Rac prophage; putative DNA-binding transcriptional regulator
Description: Rac prophage repressor
Comments: racR encodes a functional repressor of the Rac prophage, personal communications, A.J. Clark, February, 1994, (preliminary results), and June, 1998. Rac integrase and repressor function and the Rac prophage can be induced to excise from the E. coli chromosome, but does not form viable virions. racR was identified in a personal communication of unpublished DNA sequence (2527 bp) and annotation from A.J. Clark, H. Samra, J. Li, C.C. Chu, C.S. Laufer and J.B. Hays, November, 1993; revised June, 1996. Although RacR does not show significant sequence homology to phage lambda cI repressor, it is approximately the same size, also has a predicted HTH motif, and is divergent from a cro

Protein: Rac prophage; putative DNA-binding transcriptional regulator
Description: Putative Cro-like repressor, Rac prophage
Comments: The prediction that YdaS and YdaT form a toxin/antitoxin pair was tested and YdaST is not a toxin/antitoxin pair (Sevin, 2007; Christensen-Dalsgaard, 2010). YdaS has a likely false positive signal peptide prediction of 22 aa.

Description: Required for swarming phenotype; Rac prophage
Comments: The prediction that YdaS and YdaT form a toxin/antitoxin pair was tested and YdaST do not form a toxin/antitoxin pair (Sevin, 2007; Christensen-Dalsgaard, 2010).

Description: Rac prophage, function unknown
Comments: Null

Description: Pseudogene, Rz homolog, Rac prophage
